IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it unveils the identity, biosynthesis and physiological roles of natural products produced by human oral pathogens that are important for their survial in human bodies, or produced by oral probiotics that fight against competing pathogens. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to increasing understanding of chemical ecology and physiology of oral microbes, pathogenesis of oral infection and microbiome and their impacts on oral health and disease, and laying the foundation for advances in maintaining oral health and treating oral diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Several studies have demonstrated that exposure to higher concentrations of particulate matter (PM) leads to worse lung function growth, but the effects of specific PM sources and composition on disease course and lung function growth among children with asthma are largely unknown. We will conduct a prospective cohort study of 300 multi-ethnic children, the Texas Home Assessment of Asthma and Lung Exposures (TexHALE) study to examine associations between: 1) lung function growth; 2) persistence of disease severity; and 3) biomarkers associated with airway remodeling and lung function decline with PM exposure (sources, composition, and concentrations). The proposed aims will greatly advance our current understanding of the natural history of asthma, which is critical for developing interventions that modify the trajectory of childhood asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Disrupted circadian rhythms are often a hallmark of neurodegenerative and neurological diseases, including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's, and it is becoming apparent that mitochondrial metabolic function plays a role in this disruption. We propose to use the power of Drosophila genetics, behavior, and physiology to determine the molecular and cellular links between perturbed metabolism, altered circadian rhythms, and neurological dysfunction. Additionally, we will establish the mechanistic basis of the ketogenic diet's ability to improve circadian function in the context of mitochondrial disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) also known as chronic lung disease of prematurity affects 10-15,000 newborns each year in the US with those born < 1 kg weight having a much greater risk. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) can measure not only the structural integrity of lung parenchyma and tracheal airway but also novel functional defects in lung perfusion and ventilation. Novel MRI techniques will be used to identify the root causes of BPD in each infant and assign a patient specific severity score.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Adaptive immune responses involve the differentiation of CD4+ T cells into subsets that have different effector or regulatory functions. Our new data identifies novel signaling networks that drive the regulatory T cell versus Th17 cell fate choices. Challenges remain in controlling T cell activation leading us to query cell-intrinsic mechanisms of T cell activation which could aid in engineering T cells for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with a history of adverse pregnancy outcomes (APOs) are at increased risk of future cardiovascular disease. The goal of this study is to design a tool to help clinicians identify which women with APOs are most likely to develop CVD and suggest how to help reduce their risk. We will achieve this by: 1) using data from two large, national, longitudinal cohorts as well as a cohort derived from electronic health records of women recently delivering in North Carolina to identify the most common pathways from APO to cardiovascular risk factors to cardiovascular events; 2) engaging clinical experts to design the decision support tool based on the pathways and predicted risks revealed by the statistical analyses; and 3) soliciting feedback from practicing clinicians who would use to tool to help women with a history of APOs to reduce their risk of future cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black and Latinx people who use opioids (PWUO) bear a disproportionate burden of opioid-related overdose deaths. This proposal aims to adapt an evidence-supported Cultural Structural Humility (CSH) training to interactive video modules for peer recovery coaches (PRCs) that goes beyond a social determinants of health (SDH) framework to also include stigma reduction, health habitus, and patient navigation, and refine an artificial intelligence (AI)-driven texting tool to reinforce core CSH principles. The pilot RCT involves PRC completion of interactive video modules to facilitate telephone-based care coordination combined with AI- driven CSH-enhanced texting to deliver social services information addressing SDH to enhance receipt of buprenorphine among emergency department-recruited Black and Latinx PWUO.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our previous studies have found decreased acetylcholine receptor currents and cell excitability in cardiac vagal neurons are associated with cardiac vagal dysfunction, which contributes to the high mortality in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. This proposal will focus on the potential mechanisms responsible for cardiac vagal neuronal dysfunction in T2DM. The significance of this project is to provide potential strategies to improve cardiac vagal function and to reduce mortality in patients with T2DM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over half of all patients receiving taxane- or platinum-based chemotherapy for breast or gastrointestinal cancers experience a dose-limiting toxicity called chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN), which can involve numbness, tingling, pain, and sensitivity to cold in the hands and feet. There are few effective treatments for CIPN because the development of CIPN in humans is not well understood. This project will learn more about how the brain’s processing of bodily sensations might play a role in CIPN to inform new biomarkers and treatments for CIPN that will help alleviate the burden of chemotherapy on patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE: Electrochemical generation of NO (E-NOgen) from simple inorganic nitrite using Cu(II)-ligand complexes is a completely new and promising technology to create NO on demand for inhaled NO (INO) treatments, use in oxygenators to prevent systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) during extracorporeal circulation, and to create novel antimicrobial/thromboresistant intravascular (IV) catheters. However, current Cu(II)-ligand catalysts are quite sensitive to dioxygen (O2), with increasing O2 levels leading to dramatically decreased NO generation rates. In the proposed research, completely new Cu(II)-ligand catalysts will be synthesized that greatly decrease the O2 sensitivity of the E-NOgen systems, and new materials and enzyme coatings will be developed that improve NO output (reducing loss of NO via reaction with O2 in the materials), enabling higher levels of NO production for a wide range of medical applications.

PHR: The thermogenic beige adipocytes improve metabolic homeostasis by dissipating energy as heat. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative The ARIC neurocognitive cohort will now answer the compelling need to better understand risk of Alzheimer's dementia and Alzheimer's related dementias (AD/ADRD) among the oldest-old (85+ years) where current risk factors are not predictive. ARIC takes a comprehensive approach by studying a large diverse group of people from middle age to the oldest age with over three decades of rigorous data collection on every aspect of their lives. This renewal builds on very high productivity (245 papers since 2009) to continue rigorous data collection (proposed visits 11-13 accumulating 4732 dementia cases, half over age 85 by 2028) with a focus on blood biomarkers and outcomes across every aspect of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Non-contact anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries are accompanied by severe short- and long-term consequences, including early-onset osteoarthritis. The proposed research will identify kinematic and morphologic factors that are associated with elevated tension within the ACL functional bundles. Since elevated ACL tension reflects increased vulnerability to ligament failure, the proposed studies will provide crucial criteria that will identify those who are at high risk for injury and also enable targeted intervention strategies to those who are likely to benefit from injury prevention training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Public Health Relevance Statement: Lung infections caused by Gram-negative `superbugs' is very difficult to treat due to the resistance to almost all current antibiotics except polymyxins. Inhaled polymyxin therapies have been increasingly used as the last resort globally; however, the lack of appropriate delivery system and dearth in pharmacological information have led to insufficient efficacy and pulmonary adverse effects. Our multi- disciplinary project will develop innovative aerosol delivery systems of polymyxin combinations with cutting-edge technologies to provide much safer and efficacious treatments for deadly Gram-negative lung infections.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The intestine and the liver are anatomically and physiologically connected, referred to as the gut-liver axis, which also plays a key role in the pathogenesis of several liver diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Polymicrobial infections are an increasing concern for human health. In this project, we will study the inter- kingdom interaction between the pathogen Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium (STm) and the opportunistic pathogenic yeast Candida albicans in the gut. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular response and adaptation to stress is a fundamental aspect of normal tissue homeostasis, and in cancer, cellular adaptation manifests detrimentally as cancer cell resistance to therapy. This project addresses the current lack of methods for multiome single-cell and spatial fate tracking and computational cell fate prediction in systems where cell population dynamics are shaped by survival and adaptation. The proposed experimental and computational methods are generally applicable to the study of time-dependent cellular processes in biology and medicine, and the data generated will advance our understanding of drug resistance in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The primary goals of this project are to understand the network brain activity that underlie slowness of movement (bradykinesia) in Parkinson's disease and to identify specific neural pathways associated with improved bradykinesia via deep brain stimulation (DBS). Specifically, we look to describe the pathophysiological activity in the pallidum and pallido-motor cortex (M1) network that are associated with slowness of movement (bradykinesia), a cardinal sign of PD, their spatial topography within the internal segment of the globus pallidus (GPi) and to identify activation of pallidothalamic pathways through coherence- based directional deep brain stimulation, which results in improved bradykinesia. Data from this project will provide the rationale for targeting substructures and/or pathways within or around GPi for patient-specific, physiologically-based stimulation and for the development of closed-loop stimulation paradigms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: A more durable vaccine for respiratory viral pathogens, including SARS COV2 and influenza, is the long term goal of many laboratories. We have discovered a novel population of CD8 T cells in mice vaccinated through skin with MVA vectors that respond rapidly and efficiently to viral infection and challenge of lung without compromising lung parenchymal space. Our goal is to fully understand how these cells are generated, how they interact with lung vasculature, and how to enhance their protective capacity, in order to devise the best approach for reproducibly preventing morbidity and mortality after lung viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Pancreatic cancer is the second leading cause of cancer-related death, with less than 5% survival after 5 years; although patients succumb to metastases, there are no specific diagnostic markers or therapeutic strategies aimed at treating metastases, particularly due to an almost complete lack of knowledge on the molecular drivers of metastatic progression. Using a combination of comparative transcriptomics and a novel functional screen, we identified a novel metabolic pathway (that includes an aminoacid transporter and a conjugating enzyme) in metastatic lesions, which inhibition completely halted the growth of metastases without affecting the primary tumors; furthermore, preliminary data indicate that they may provide metabolic fitness for metastatic cells to grow in these foreign niches, indicating that these lesions evolve by acquiring non-genetic adaptations. In this proposal, we will take advantage of biochemistry, cell biology, mouse models and samples from human patients in order to molecularly characterize this pathway, with the potential to change treatment for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Decentralized clinical trials are a new form of clinical study designed to expand access to studies and reduce the burden on study participants by using technology, such as mobile phones, to collect data from home. This study creates a new way to identify new onset atopic dermatitis (eczema) and grade the severity of the skin condition using a mobile phone by parents or guardians. This will allow a more patient-centered approach to testing the best ways to treat and prevent eczema and allergies – a significant global health problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Statement Chronic social defeat stress, a rodent paradigm widely used for investigating the effects of stress on circuits underlying mood and anxiety disorders, reliably leads to deficits in social interaction. This project addresses the role of fear circuits in mediating stress-induced social avoidance by targeting 1) amygdala input to the nucleus accumbens, 2) prelimbic input to the amygdala, and 3) by characterizing dynamic patterns of neural activity between all three regions. The findings have the potential to significantly broaden our current understanding of how chronic exposure to a social stressor modulates networks mediating learned social behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE IgE is an antibody produced by B cells in people with food allergies and asthma, and it can cause life-threatening anaphylaxis, especially in those with food allergy. We discovered a new type of T cell that promotes B cell production of IgE, but we do not know how the signals from this T cell control the IgE B cell response. Our lab developed the techniques necessary to discover these molecular pathways in human and mouse B cells that promote anaphylaxis-inducing IgE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common dementia characterized by progressive cognitive decline, and there are obstacles prevent the development of new therapeutic strategies and their translation to human patients. This proposal is based upon analysis of human AD cases and animal models, as it bridges multiple aspects of AD pathology: discovery of unique oxidative stress pathway, new aspects of microglial biology and dysfunction, and basic mechanisms of cell adhesion/phagocytosis in the context of disease. We will answer how exactly oxidation causes microglial dysfunction in AD and how to prevent/inhibit their detrimental consequences in AD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) The proposed research is directly related to public health because understanding the mechanisms of small cell lung cancer initiation and progression is expected to give rise to new types of diagnoses, treatments, and preventions for small cell lung cancer. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Parents require skills to initiate and sustain protective family communication about sexuality and health with gay, bisexual, or queer (GBQ) male adolescents. The proposed study is relevant to public health as it is centered on helping parents answer and meet the sexuality-specific questions and needs of GBQ youth after they disclose sexual orientation. This study seeks to test the efficacy of Parents ASSIST as a parent-child sexuality communication intervention that educates and trains parents to be purveyors of inclusive health information as GBQ sons come of age at home.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of prostate cancer is 1.6, and the mortality rate is 2.5 times higher in African-American men when compared to Caucasian men. The reasons for this increased risk for African-American men are multifactorial social, behavioral, economical, and systemic differences that result in biological tranformities leading to cancer. Combined strategies based on biomedical research, social/behavioral investigations and community engagement are required to combat this disease in the African-American community, and the Center for Cancer Research and Therapeutic Development (CCRTD) at Clark Atlanta University (CAU) is focused on the trilateral approaches to conduct basic research in prostate cancer, train the next generation of scientists in prostate cancer and build trust in the African-American community through engagement, education, outreach, and culturally- sensitive dissemination of our research agenda.

PHR: Chemoresistant prostate cancer is lethal with no cure. This Research Project is to develop bromocriptine, an approved non-oncology drug, as a safe, effective, and affordable precision therapy for the subtypes of chemoresistant prostate cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The overarching goal of this proposal is to enable clinical use of linear-energy-transfer (LET) in spot scanning proton therapy (SSPT) for head and neck (H&N) cancer based on patient outcomes with adverse event (AE) sites contoured using following-up medical images (CT, PET, and MR etc.) to minimize the risks of AEs. We will develop dose-LET volume histogram (DLVH) based plan evaluation and treatment planning methods in SSPT for H&N cancer management using patient outcomes and following-up medical imaging analysis-derived dose-LET volume constraints (DLVCs) and develop the empirical AE models using domestic seed spot analysis based on medical imaging analysis. The success of this study will open new avenues in SSPT plan evaluation and treatment planning, leading to precision radiation therapy and improved clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromatin and its fundamental unit, the nucleosome, constitute a mechanical barrier that controls DNA accessibility and is, therefore, a major mechanism of control of gene expression. Here, we combine biophysical approaches including optical tweezers, single-molecule fluorescence, cryo-electron microscopy/tomography, and in vivo quantitative confocal imaging to investigate how epigenetic modifications, pioneer factors, chromatin remodelers, chromatin- associated proteins, and histone chaperones modulate the magnitude of the mechanical barrier of a single nucleosome and nucleosome arrays, and how they affect transcription by Pol II. The precise measurement of these mechanistic details will provide the physical framework to understand how gene expression is regulated by chromatin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dealing with cancer places great stress not only on the patient but also on that patient's spouse or partner, and couples find that communicating about cancer and how it is affecting their lives and relationship can become challenging even in the best of relationships. This study looks at how couples dealing with cancer communicate with each other across settings and time (within a single conversation and over the course of days and months), and whether patterns of communication can be identified that are associated with better or worse long-term emotional and relationship adjustment and well-being. This information will be used to develop screening tools to identify couples who may need more support and to explore how these tools can be used in clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial dysfunction leading to metabolic dysregulation is a key component in the development of chronic kidney disease, a growing global health problem. The proposed studies will use a model to study kidney cell type-specific mitochondria to define the role of local ketone metabolism within the kidney. As suppression of a key ketogenic gene is associated with kidney disease, these studies will not only advance our understanding of kidney cell type-specific metabolism, but also identify potential therapeutic interventions to enhance kidney ketogenesis and prevent kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Simultaneous brain-behavior quantification for mental states can provide novel neural-physiological markers to enable personalized therapies for diverse mental disorders but remains immensely difficult. Our interdisciplinary team will develop novel hardware and software tools that address several challenges on the physiology, behavior, machine learning, and ethics fronts to enable multimodal neural-physiological-behavioral sensing and machine learning for mental states. Our multimodal, convergent, and integrated tools will likely enable unique brain-behavior insights into human emotion functioning applicable to broad domains of mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methionine adenosyltransferase (MAT) is an essential enzyme as it is responsible for the formation of S- adenosylmethionine, a key molecule that is required for normal cell function. Normal liver expresses mainly MAT1A and patients with alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) have reduced expression of MAT1A. We have found MAT1A protein is selectively depleted in the nucleus and mitochondria in ALD, and this can lead to abnormal gene expression and mitochondrial injury. The goals of this project are to understand the underlying mechanisms for depletion of MAT1A protein in these organelles, their consequences and whether targeting them can protect from the development of ALD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, an RNA regulation mechanism through NUDT21 is demonstrated to play a critical role in regulating macrophage function and inflammation during Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), a prevalent and life-threatening lung injury. We designed a series of cellular and animal studies to prove whether modulating the NUDT21 pathway in macrophages could attenuate ARDS. These studies can ultimately lead to the discovery of new targets for the treatment of ARDS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will employ state-of-the-art molecular, biochemical, and genetic techniques in mice to identify the cell types and mechanisms that regulate and functionally recruit the IGF-2/IGF-2R system in the hippocampus to form long-term memory. It will test the hypotheses that IGF-2 released by specific cell types, such as pericytes, activates IGF-2R expressed by target cells, such as neurons, to regulate, via vesicle trafficking, de novo translation induced by learning and its coupling to autophagy, a fundamental molecular node that controls plasticity changes essential for memory formation. Targeting this novel mechanism should provide important insights for treating disorders associated to memory impairment.

PHR: PIs: Bradshaw, Elizabeth M., Ph.D. and Wassim Elyaman, Ph.D. Title: Microglia antigen presentation in the CNS of Alzheimer's disease Project Narrative Relevance to public health. This project is of direct relevance to Alzheimer's disease, as we are studying isolated immune populations from the CNS of individuals with Alzheimer's disease. We will be examining the interaction of the pathogen hypothesis and the CNS immune cells in the human system.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Reports of adverse experiences in childhood are highly prevalent among US military personnel and Veterans. Chronic stress in early childhood alters the immune system and increases inflammation in response to challenges in adulthood. In this proposal, we will determine if chronic stress in early childhood is a risk factor for persistent symptoms after mild traumatic brain injury TBI. Although the majority of TBIs in US military personnel and Veterans are mild, and recovery occurs in most mild TBI patients after 1-2 weeks, a subset have persistent symptoms such as cognitive problems lasting for weeks to months. This proposal will determine if a history of chronic stress in early childhood limits the recovery trajectory after a TBI that occurs in adulthood. We will identify the underlying molecular mechanisms that are initiated by chronic childhood stress to result in worsened outcome after TBI. We will also test a therapeutic that will target these molecular mechanisms and determine if this therapeutic improves behavioral recovery in the chronic phase of TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The SLC6A1 gene, which encodes the GABA transporter GAT1, is implicated in a spectrum of neurodevelopmental disorders including epilepsy, autism, and intellectual disability, collectively named SLC6A1 syndrome. Although the cellular and circuit mechanisms by which SLC6A1 mutations cause SLC6A1 syndrome remain unknown, my preliminary data show state-dependent seizures in thalamocortical circuits in a novel mouse model of SLC6A1 syndrome. Here I will use electrophysiological and genetic tools to determine whether thalamic circuits are key regulators of epileptic seizures associated with SLC6A1 syndrome, with the aim to eventually aid the clinical management of network dysfunction in SLC6A1 syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Melanoma is the most aggressive form of cancer, which is characterized by rapid spread from skin to vital organs such as liver, kidneys, heart and brain, and while it represents only about 4% of skin cancer cases, it accounts for 75% of all skin cancer deaths. A number of new therapies became available within past decade, however, a significant portion of patients don't respond to the treatments or develop resistance over time. The investigators and collaborators of this proposal identified an enzyme (GCDH), which is associated with these aggressive and resistant melanomas, as well as pancreatic cancers, and, when inhibited, promotes cancer cell death, which the team will exploit in the proposed work to identify and validate chemical compounds that inhibit GCDH and establish potential of the enzyme as novel promising therapeutic target for melanoma and pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability of blind individuals to regain sight through medical interventions and to use compensatory/assistive technologies varies greatly and is hard to predict, in part due to changes in the blind brain that may prevent it from processing sight efficiently later in life. With our team’s expertise in assistive technologies, advanced neuroimaging techniques and mechanisms of brain plasticity, we will investigate individual differences across scales in the brains of blind individuals, revealing key insights into how the brain develops and matures across different individuals. We will explore how individual profiles of brain plasticity relate to compensatory abilities, aiming to enable personalized treatments from unique neurobehavioral fingerprints which will improve the success of sight restoration outcomes for millions of blind individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a global health problem that greatly increases the risk for developing hypertension. An important contributor to obesity-related hypertension is excessive sympathetic nervous system outflow to cardiovascular organs. This proposal will determine if the hormone angiotensin-(1-7) provides cardiovascular protection in obesity by engaging brain circuits to reduce sympathetic outflow and blood pressure. These studies will advance our understanding of brain mechanisms contributing to blood pressure elevations in obesity, as well as inform on the potential for targeting angiotensin-(1-7) in the treatment of obesity-related hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biosynthetic gene clusters that encode the production of aryl polyene (APE) virulence factors are widespread among Gram-negative human pathogens. This project aims to investigate unresolved questions regarding APE cell envelope localization and environmental conditions that control their expression, by linking molecular genetics analysis to biochemical function. Our research will yield APE biosynthesis inhibitors that will inform development of antivirulence strategies, and identify molecular tools that will enable functional studies in non- model bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: In the changing ecosystem, we are faced with the evolving challenges of healthcare needs and inability to treat many chronic conditions, thus requiring discoveries and healthcare management strategies to improve health- related quality of life and develop cures; which are disproportionately affected by the paucity of physician scientists. Utilizing the “cells to society” multidisciplinary team-science approach, we aim to engage a diverse pool of MD students in hands-on research training and mentorship. This “Summer of Mentoring and Research Training (SMART)”, is anticipated to fill the gap that exists in the availability of physician-scientists to address the evolving global health challenges through research, discovery and awareness.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE STATEMENT Disorders of hemochorial placentation are a significant human health issue. There is a paucity of knowledge regarding the regulation of trophoblast stem cells, their differentiation into invasive/extravillous trophoblast cells that effectively invade into the uterus and restructure uterine spiral arteries and establish the uterine-placental interface. Experimental dissection of fundamental mechanisms underlying the derivation of the invasive/extravillous trophoblast cell lineage is a key to understanding the etiology of placentation-related diseases and a necessity for establishing appropriate and efficacious diagnostic and therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Persons with HIV (PWH) on antiretroviral therapy have a high risk for metabolic disease that contributes to poor health outcomes. Adipose tissue T cells regulate adipose tissue function and are frequently altered in PWH. We seek to understand the specific adipose tissue immune cell populations that may contribute to metabolic disease and investigate the role of viral reservoir in maintaining inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Conventional opioids (prescription and illicit) are being replaced by the herbal supplement kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) during pregnancies, and multiple clinical cases have been associated with serious withdrawal symptoms in newborns presumably due to in utero kratom exposure. There is an urgent need to mechanistically investigate if kratom intake during pregnancy results in neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS) as an outcome. A combination of systemic pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic studies are proposed in this R21 proposal to identify risks (or benefits) of kratom use during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid and alcohol polysubstance co-use is common and worsens treatment outcomes. In rodents, the neuropeptide oxytocin reduces opioid and alcohol intake and/or seeking and is theorized to act through dopamine and glutamate regulation in the nucleus accumbens. The proposed experiments will explore the utility of oxytocin as an effective therapeutic for oxycodone+alcohol polysubstance use and investigate whether these effects are accompanied by alterations in dopamine and glutamate efflux in the nucleus accumbens.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Abnormal fetal growth affects ~15% of all babies and increases the risk for injuries at delivery and to develop obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease in childhood and later in life. Altered placental function is believed to directly contribute to changes in fetal growth and to better understand the underlying causes of these conditions we will identify key mechanisms regulating placental function and how the placenta directly influences the insulin-secreting cells in the fetus. This research may help design novel treatments to alleviate abnormal fetal growth and its short and long-term adverse consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human mobility underlies infectious disease transmission and determines the spatial and temporal dynamics of outbreaks and endemic disease dynamics. Yet, we do not understand how best to incorporate individual or population mobility patterns into models of infectious diseases. Here, we propose to perform the first systematic analysis of existing mobility data and models to identify which models perform best in specific circumstances using a range of simulations and data from historic outbreaks.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will establish the feasibility and acceptability of a novel tailored, dyadic, resiliency intervention, “Resilient Families (R-FAM).” R-FAM aims to improve emotional distress and couple functioning in parents with babies in Neonatal Intensive Care Units (NICU)—who are at increased risk (30-50%) for acute and chronic distress. R-FAM has the potential to enhance family adjustment, child development, and ultimately inform a new and improved standard of care in NICUs across the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRTIVE Chronic pain is a leading cause of disability and major public health concern; thus, research aimed at improving our understanding of non-pharmacological approaches to pain management is crucial. Although individuals with chronic pain demonstrate interoceptive deficits, and mind-body therapies (MBTs) are purported to improve chronic pain conditions, limited research has directly examined interoception as a mechanism of change in MBTs. This predoctoral training and research project builds upon an existing program of research to study changes in interoceptive awareness as a mechanism of change in MBTs for chronic low back pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aim of this project is to understand changes in the brain underlying the emergence of social and emotional regulation during adolescence. Here, we will use cutting edge neurotechnologies coupled with carefully designed behavioral assessments to study changes in connectivity between the prefrontal cortex and the amygdala during adolescence. The findings from this study will impact our understanding of adolescent brain development and the early foundations of mental disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB), causes 1.6 million deaths per year globally, and thus there is an urgent need to develop new treatment approaches. Our proposed research is significant to public health because a better understanding of the host non-coding RNA landscape driving susceptibility to tuberculosis disease could lead to the development of better diagnostic biomarkers and adjunctive host- that seeks fundamental knowledge on the causes of pathogenicity that helps to reduce the burden of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Many patients with temporal lobe epilepsy have repeated spontaneous seizures that cannot be controlled with existing drug therapies. Epileptic circuit activity is characterized by excessive production of electrical signals at a specialized part of brain cells called the axon initial segment that is innervated by a unique but poorly understood regulatory interneuron. In this project, we will leverage recent technical breakthroughs to determine mechanisms underlying alterations in the ability of these interneurons to control abnormal electrical activity patterns in chronic temporal lobe epilepsy and evaluate the efficacy of closed-loop interventions directed at these cells for seizure control and amelioration of cognitive deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Diabetes increases the risk of cognitive impairment and dementia although the underlying mechanisms remain incompletely understood. We aim to evaluate newly developed, noninvasive measures of cerebral arterial compliance and blood flow in order to determine whether early functional brain changes proceed the development of irreversible cerebrovascular lesions and cognitive decline in older adults with diabetes and non-diabetic control participants. We will also examine the role of treatable/potentially modifiable mechanisms underlying cognitive changes, with the ultimate goals of advancing our understanding of the pathogenesis of diabetes-related cognitive dysfunction and identifying individuals at risk for cognitive impairment so that interventions to reduce dementia risk can be started as early as possible in order to improve health and functioning.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Brachial plexus birth injury, the most common nerve injury in children, is a traumatic injury occurring at birth that causes muscle paralysis, abnormal growth of the shoulder bones, and lifelong impairment of arm function. Almost nothing is known about the timing and drivers of changes to bone from altered passive mechanical loading from short muscles, reduced functional loading, and direct nerve injury effects following brachial plexus injury occurring at birth. The proposed work will significantly advance understanding of how deformity develops and persists, and ultimately enable more effective and consistent treatments – addressing both muscle and bone – for brachial plexus birth injury and other perinatal neuromuscular injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have established several unique lines of mice that enable us to elucidate the important functions of low abundance cytoplasmic actins in normal and diseased skeletal muscle. Of greatest immediate relevance to public health, we propose experiments that will mechanistically explain the dramatic, but reversible muscle weakness in dystrophic muscle exposed to lengthening, or eccentric contractions. While protection from eccentric contractions is well accepted as proof-of-concept for new therapies to treat muscular dystrophies, the cause of weakness is poorly understood. We are proposing to elucidate the mechanisms through which each type of actin contributes to muscle cell maintenance to provide the foundation for therapy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Although short-term exposures to ambient air pollutants and weather variables are independently associated with risk of suicide death, little is known about the effects of multi- environmental exposure mixtures on suicide. We will use our access to unprecedented data resources to quantify the combined effects of short-term ambient air pollutant and weather exposures on suicide death in the context of a person’s individual, familial and genetic characteristics. Results from this study may lead to the development of clinical, educational and/or pharmacological interventions for suicide, targeted at high-risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Gastrointestinal syndrome (GIS) is a disorder induced by anti-cancer radiotherapy and chemotherapy for which there is no effective treatment. Release of free heme upon either gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding or injury exacerbates colonic inflammation resulting in tissue damage. The work proposed here is designed to define the mechanisms by which free heme regulates gene expression during response to genotoxic and inflammatory stimuli as well as to assess therapeutic potential of hemopexin, a heme scavanger, in the GIS models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Crohn's disease is a chronic remitting and relapsing illness that results in intestinal inflammation, unwanted gastrointestinal symptoms and can lead to serious complications including surgery, hospitalizations, growth delays and poor quality of life. As there are limited treatment options approved for use in children and relapses are common, we will conduct a cluster-randomized clinical trial in children and young adults with moderate to severe Crohn's disease starting infliximab (anti-TNF). We will assess patient reported and disease modifying outcomes (endoscopic healing) between patients who received infliximab using an innovative, precision dosing strategy (treat-to-target) and those who received infliximab with the conventional dosing approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Natural killer (NK) cells are part of the immune system’s first line of defense, recognizing virus-infected or tumor cells and killing them to protect the host. Infection by coronaviruses (including SARS-CoV-2) may render the infected cell a target for killing by NKs, but the mechanism is largely unexplored given the focus on adaptive immunity to coronaviruses. Here, we will investigate a stress-induced signal for innate NK activation that we hypothesize is induced by coronavirus infection and may allow for recognition and killing of the infected cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative High-accuracy protein synthesis is a defining feature of the ribosome, ensuring that the encoded peptide sequences are faithfully generated. During the elongation phase of translation, the ribosome must move by a three-nucleotide increment; failure to do so results in frameshifting errors, leading to the accumulation of errant protein products that can aggregate and cause disease. This proposal is focused on understanding the mechanism by which the ribosome maintains its reading frame during stalling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Atrial fibrillation (AF), the most prevalence arrhythmia, is a public health burden. Atrial myopathy is a major underlying cause of AF. The precise molecular mechanisms underlying the evolution of AF-promoting atrial myopathy are complex and poorly understood. The proposed work will elucidate the causal role of cardiac fibroblast inflammasome signaling in the development of AF- promoting atrial myopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recognizing the limitations associated with the conventional radiologic criteria for the selection of patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) for curative liver transplantation (LT), we aim to develop an integrated blood-based analysis using HCC circulating tumor cells (CTCs) for LT candidate selection. The long-term goal is to conduct exploratory development and prospective clinical studies of the proposed assays for phenotypic and molecular profiling of HCC CTCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate the neural circuits and mechanisms responsible for integrating the opposing drives of avoiding threats and seeking for rewards. Whereas exaggerated reward seeking is a hallmark of substance abuse and eating disorders, persistent avoidance is the most debilitating symptom of many fear-related disorders. Our ethologically-relevant paradigm combining natural threats with food cues will lead to a better understanding of how the brain computes threatening and rewarding information to generate distinct patterns of behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The aims of this project are to establish a diverse cohort of youth at high-risk for type 2 diabetes (T2D), and to follow them longitudinally with 1) in-depth assessment of clinical, epigenetic and biochemical measures, as well as social determinants of health, and 2) survey for the emergence of T2D, in collaboration with a consortium of centers. This will allow us to gain new insights into disease risk and pathogenesis, and design precision intervention with the ultimate goal of prevention of youth-onset T2D, in accordance with NIH’s mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Experimental and clinical studies have demonstrated that chronic myocardial infarction is associated with adverse remodeling of the left atrium, which in turn has an adverse impact on left atrial function. Surprisingly, we have observed very high rates of cardiomyocyte cell cycle activity in the left atrium of infarcted mice. Here we propose to use a novel genetic model to determine the impact of atrial cardiomyocyte cell cycle activation on left atrial structural and functional remodeling following infarction, with the hope that the information gained from these studies may suggest interventions aimed at reversing compromised left atrial function following infarction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The overall goal of our proposed research is to understand why having health care coverage (or eligibility for health care coverage) is not sufficient to allow equal access to elective surgical care; despite successful efforts to expand coverage through Medicaid expansion and the Affordable Care Act (ACA), potentially elective surgical care is often not addressed until it becomes an emergency, particularly for vulnerable populations. We will use a multiphase mixed method approach to 1) identify modifiable factors for emergent presentation and explore the trajectory of progression to elective versus emergency surgery using billing data and EHR in a convergent mixed-methods design, combining quantitative variables with qualitative narrative data, 2) identify and quantify additional modifiable factors from the patient perspective that are not available in clinical or administrative datasets using an exploratory sequential design, using identified domains to conduct systematic review and meta-analysis for quantitative data, and 3) determine which modifiable factor or factors identified will have the greatest impact for future intervention strategies using Markov modeling. With this data we can model and understand what influences the persistent disparity in the ability to access elective surgical care despite increased coverage, and predict which factors contribute the most to the disparities and thus hold potential for the greatest impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Gestational diabetes (GDM) is a public health problem because it increases pregnancy-related adverse outcomes and long-term health risks for both a mother and her offspring. Our proposal investigates how insulin-producing pancreatic β-cells normally adapt to pregnancy, and how these processes are defective in GDM. This work has potential to reveal fundamental mechanisms of how β-cells dynamically respond to changing insulin demands following specific metabolic stressors, and to identify new strategies to expand β-cells for therapeutic purposes in all types of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative The applicability of polymer-based drug delivery systems (DDSs) has been significantly restricted by critical technological challenges, such as the undesired immunogenicity of polyethylene glycol (PEG) broadly used in DDSs, the lack of PEG alternatives with optimal comprehensive properties, the scarcity of clinically valid DDSs for combination therapy, and the deficient understanding on topological effects of polymer scaffolds. To address these challenges, we aim to develop multifunctional biodegradable zwitterionic polymer-drug conjugates (ZPDCs) as novel PEG-free multidrug co-delivery systems with favorable biomedically relevant properties. A library of ZPDCs with different main-chain topology and other structural features will be prepared and their structure-dependent biointerface properties will be systematically investigated through biochemical, cellular and in vivo studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This study will elucidate how sleep, vascular disease risk factors, nocturnal hypertension and cognition/brain health inter-relate in both men and women of diverse ethnic backgrounds. Thus, we will hope to identify important factors that influence individual susceptibility in age-related declines in cognition that serve as targets (sleep quality, sleep apnea, nocturnal blood pressure) for mitigating risk for developing Alzheimer's Disease and its devastating effects on cognition, independence and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: White matter damage is a major factor underlying cognitive impairment in both cerebrovascular diseases and Alzheimer’s disease, but the factors mediating the damage have not been fully established. The studies will investigate the role of ApoE4 in the damage to the white matter. The findings deriving from the proposed study will advance our knowledge of the factors causing white matter injury and will suggest new putative therapeutic targets to counteract the devastating cognitive impact of white matter damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  As many as 92% of patients diagnosed with ALS are faced with the decision to have a feeding tube placed or to continue eating as their primary source of nutrition despite difficulty swallowing. At present, we lack an understanding of patient and caregiver goals and concerns surrounding this decision, and practice patterns surrounding feeding tube placement are highly variable. The primary objective of the proposed study is to develop and test a shared decision- making tool (i.e. decision aid) that improves patients’ knowledge about the decision, addresses patients’ goals and concerns surrounding the decision, and improves patient and healthcare provider communication throughout the decision-making process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Coronary heart disease (CHD), leading to myocardial infarction (MI) and post- MI heart failure (HF), is a  major cause of morbidity and mortality in the US. w3- polyunsaturated fatty acids, like eicosapentaenoic acid  (EPA), improve outcomes in CHD and HF. Free fatty acid receptor 4 (Ffar4) is a G- protein coupled receptor for  long- chain fatty acids including omega- 3 fatty acids. In the heart, our data suggest that Ffar4 has a dual role as  an omega- 3- independent, fatty acid nutrient sensor, and the mechanistic basis for EPA cardioprotection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Metabolic disease and insulin resistance are consequences of the expanding global obesity epidemic, and are associated with extensive microvascular and macrovascular morbidity and mortality. Hypertriglyceridemia, a prominent feature of insulin resistance, is a source of excess cardiovascular risk particularly among patients with type 2 diabetes; however, current treatments for hypertriglyceridemia have been inadequate to reduce this excess cardiovascular risk. These studies in rodents and humans will identify subgroups of insulin resistance that drive hepatic triglyceride production by separate mechanisms, allowing for the development of more effective, targeted therapies for the dyslipidemia of insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The devastating effects of the COVID-19 pandemic have reverberated through every aspect of our civilization. While SARS-CoV-2, the viral etiology of COVID-19, seems to spare infants in terms of actual infection, it is currently unknown whether maternal infection during pregnancy will have long-term effects on children born during the pandemic. Detecting COVID-19-related early neurobehavioral effects on mothers and the next generation will provide insights into intervention strategies and contribute significantly to our understanding of children's developmental origins of health and disease and stress science in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – New treatments for anxiety disorders are critically needed and a more complete understanding of pathological anxiety at the molecular, cellular and circuit level will provide a foundation for new treatment development. Using our non-human primate model of extreme anxiety, the proposed studies will use neuroimaging, molecular sequencing techniques and chemogenetics to understand the extent to which neurons in the basolateral amygdala can serve as treatment targets. Additionally, these studies will serve as a proof-of- concept to understand the feasibility of developing chemogenetic approaches for the future treatment of severe and refractory psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with locally advanced rectal cancer (LARC) commonly have poor tolerability to total neoadjuvant therapy, which reduces cancer control and survival benefit of this treatment. We propose to investigate the dose- response of aerobic training (AT) on total neoadjuvant therapy tolerability in patients with LARC. Results from this investigation will identify the AT dose that maximizes total neoadjuvant therapy tolerability in LARC, and will provide essential evidence supporting integration of AT into clinical cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The buildup of misfolded proteins can cause Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD), which are becoming more prevalent as the population continues to live longer. This project will leverage a new genetic technology to greatly enhance our understanding of the intricate networks of molecular chaperones, which are the cell’s natural defense system against protein misfolding. This new approach will uncover the specific molecular chaperones that can serve as future targets for therapeutics against ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 has quickly become the most impactful healthcare, social, and economic crisis of our lifetime. The pandemic has disrupted everyday life abruptly and unpredictably at a global scale, and all predictions indicate that the virus will become endemic and cause regular outbreaks in the form of mutants. The impact of the pandemic is even more pronounced for racial and economic minorities, and for socioeconomically disfavored individuals and groups. To assist in the resolution of these crises, we plan to develop a single-shot, room- temperature stable, double-nanoencapsulated mRNA vaccine for COVID-19. This vaccine, in addition, can be easily modified to cover mutant viruses that constantly emerge, and it will be a significant component of the vaccination armamentarium during the current and future pandemics.

PHR: Project Narrative Meniscus injuries are very common and frequently lead to early onset osteoarthritis, a leading cause of disability. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Clostridioides difficile is a toxin-producing bacterium that is a frequent cause of hospital-acquired and antibiotic-associated diarrhea. The United States Centers for Disease Control reports that in 2017, there were 223,900 estimated cases of C. difficile infection (CDI) in hospitalized patients with an estimated 12,800 deaths in the United States. This program is designed to provide the discovery and advanced immunological understanding needed to create durable and effective vaccines for the prevention of CDI in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The cerebellum is a structure that is critical for control of movements. However, activities of cerebellar neurons are often difficult to interpret in terms of behavior. Here, we propose new algorithms and experimental procedures that will significantly improve the ability to tackle the question of neural population coding in the cerebellum, ultimately producing a better understanding of how the cerebellum learns to precisely control movements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NHGRI Genome Technology (GT) Program supports innovation, development, and early dissemination of genomic technologies. The goal of the Genome Technology Coordinating Center (GTCC) is to accelerate technology development and progress in the field of genomics through its support of GT grantees. To achieve this, the GTCC will pursue three over-arching objectives: 1) coordinating interactions among NHGRI Genome Technology grantees to enhance communication and encourage setting and meeting of performance objectives, 2) managing an Opportunity Funds program to promote early-stage development of innovative technologies, and 3) facilitating outreach by grantees to share results of their efforts with the scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative We discovered that the host has evolved physiological defenses that promote the asymptomatic carriage of pathogens through a phenomenon we call “metabolic bribery”. This involves physiological responses in the host that operate to provide metabolic substrates to the pathogen, taming their virulence and preventing their ability to cause disease. We plan to decipher the host metabolic adaptations that occur in asymptomatic carriers that facilitate metabolic bribery, the interplay between the adaptive immune system and the cooperative defenses to promote cooperation between the host and a pathogen, and develop a mechanistic understanding for how cooperative defenses promote the evolution of attenuation of a pathogen and commensalism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Computer-assisted interpretation of renal histopathology using whole slide imaging (WSI) has dramatically advanced both the research and practice for the diagnosis and scoring of specific causes of chronic kidney disease (CKD). However, current phenotyping approaches are restricted to investigating two dimensional (2D) sections, which are error-prone due to the heterogeneity of kidney tissue (e.g., glomeruli) across three dimensional (3D) serial sectioning. We seek to enable AI-empowered 3D interpretation of routine digital renal histopathology, so as to (1) allow renal pathologists to perform a reproducible 3D phenotyping on serial 2D whole slide images (WSI), (2) advance the characterization of kidney-allograft rejection phenotypes on kidney transplant patients with cutting-edge 3D computer vision, and (3) equip clinical scientists with an advanced 3D spatial transcriptomics analytics tool to investigate the anatomical-molecular associated causes of chronic kidney disease (CKD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Depression and anxiety disorders are major public health problems but our understanding of and treatment for these prevalent disorders remain lacking. To address these unmet needs, we propose an integrated research program through a unified Conte Center that will investigate the role of cortico-striatal-midbrain and nociceptin circuitry in approach-avoidance behaviors and in the pathophysiology of depression and anxiety disorders, towards the goals of identifying (1) novel treatment targets and (2) markers that map disease course. This will be achieved by bringing together a highly interdisciplinary team with complementary expertise and an established track record of successful collaborations, and who will be tackle these scientific challenges through experiments across species (mice, non-human primates, and humans) and units of analyses (genes, molecule, cells, circuits, physiology, behavior, and self-report).

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetically-engineered mice are instrumental to better understand human development and disease and to develop and improve drugs and therapeutics. The Mutant Mouse Resource and Research Center at the University of Missouri provides a unique repository for importing, storing and distributing a vast number of genetically-engineered mice, germplasm, embryonic stem cells and related reagents. The center also performs critical broad-based research and services to ensure quality, reproducibility and translatability of mouse models with an emphasis on the role of complex gut microbiota in model phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative While prostate cancer screening reduces death from prostate cancer, it does so at the cost of unnecessary treatment of men with nonaggressive disease. To address this, we propose to identify inherited genetic changes that influence survival time after a diagnosis of prostate cancer and incorporating such genetic information into prostate cancer screening tools. If successful, this will enable more precise prostate cancer screening, reducing both death from prostate cancer and unnecessary treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF SCIENCES, TECH & TECH OF BAMAKO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Seasonal malaria chemoprevention (SMC) provides regular administration of antimalarial medication to children during the malaria transmission season to protect them from malaria episodes. One concern is that SMC impairs the acquisition of protective immune responses, thereby increasing the risk of disease in later years. With a multi-season cohort study of malaria incidence among Malian children receiving SMC, we will determine how SMC affects malaria vulnerability across pediatric populations and the location of parasite reservoirs in the community, which are both crucial to guiding control interventions and eventually eliminating malaria in regions such as Mali.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Primary care settings lack interventions to address the childhood obesity epidemic that are feasible and sustainable without requiring significant resources. We propose to modify and test an intervention shown to lower children’s BMI so that it is feasible, sustainable, and easily disseminated in a real-world clinical setting. If successful, we will be able to provide recommendations to providers and health care systems that help prioritize future intervention strategies and research investments to reduce obesity in children that can be quickly translated into other settings and widely adopted after the study period, with the goal of halting and reversing the childhood obesity epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Schistosomiasis is an infectious parasitic disease afflicting ~200 million people worldwide. Current therapy depends on a single drug (praziquantel) with an unknown mechanism of action despite 40 years of clinical use. Our laboratory recently identified targets for praziquantel action that will allow praziquantel binding sites to be defined and pharmacologically exploited in both the parasite and infected human host to treat this disease.

PHR: Narrative: We seek to learn how to harness the ability of ion channels and electric fields in tissue development and regeneration. To this end, we will explore the role of ion channels and bioelectric fields in guiding tissue development using two avian skin morphogenesis models: 1) the orientation of feather bud elongation along the anterior – posterior axis, 2) the patterning of alternating yellow and black longitudinal pigment stripes in Japanese quail.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: The worldwide mortality from perinatal hypoxic–ischemic (HI) injury reached 1.15 million in 2010. Perinatal HI brain injury also causes long-term neurological disability and morbidity in infants. Our project is focused on the novel, unexplored cause and mechanism of tissue damage in the brain after oxygen deprivation and proposed studies will unravel potential pharmacological targets for improving the outcome of ischemia/reperfusion and our results also help to establish a mechanistic basis of hypothermic neuroprotection in HI-reperfusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have discovered that the immune privilege status of the avascular tissues in the anterior segment has led to a unique response to eye trauma, injury and pathogenesis that involves the activation and recruitment of immune cells to the lens for the purpose of preserving/restoring homeostasis. With lineage tracing studies we will identify the ontogeny of lens tissue resident immune cells and of the immune cells recruited to the lens in response corneal wounding, and determine their immunomodulatory functions in maintaining anterior segment homeostasis following corneal wounding as well as in the inflammatory disease uveitis. We also will examine the potential harmful outcomes of the persistence of these lens associated immune cells in the development of eye pathologies including cataract and glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies are warranted to elucidate the genetic and biochemical underpinnings of lung squamous cell carcinoma (LUSC), the second most common lung cancer type. Based on the preliminary results presented here, we postulate that chromosome 3q amplification reshapes the Golgi secretory pathway and creates a therapeutic vulnerability of LUSC. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This proposal is relevant to public health because it will reveal and characterize how important bacterial pathogens resist antibiotic treatment. We know that bacterial pathogens can form slow-growing, multicellular communities called biofilms that dramatically influence their susceptibility to clinically relevant antibiotics, but we know very little about whether and to what degree bacterial pathogens employ biofilms during infection. We expect the results of these experiments to yield short-term benefits in terms of treatment decisions for patients and long-term benefits in terms of providing the groundwork for novel therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is still a clinical diagnosis because no mechanistic quantitative, objective, and reliable measures exist to assist in diagnosis and classification of this condition. Such measures will further our understanding of the pathophysiology of different chronic pain syndromes, help clinicians make informed decisions and improve clinical care, and provide highly needed quantitative measures to be used in clinical trials of novel analgesics. In this proposal, we test whether the brain signature of chronic low-back pain is specific to low-back pain or generalizable to other chronic musculoskeletal conditions like knee arthritis pain or neuropathic chronic pain, or other chronic negative affective conditions like major depressive disorder, and whether this neural signature is modulated by patients’ age or sex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fear generalization is defined as the overgeneralization of fear from a conditioned, fear-inducing stimulus to novel, neutral stimuli. Fear generalization is a core symptom often observed in anxiety disorders and post- traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Here, we will first identify the neural ensembles mediating fear generalization in adolescent and adult mice of both sexes and then pharmacologically manipulate these neural ensembles with (R,S)-ketamine as a therapeutic for ameliorating generalized fear behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mapping polyclonal humoral immune responses to evaluate on and off target antibody responses is a critical component of rational, structure-based vaccine design. To this end we recently developed a methodology to directly image polyclonal immune responses using electron microscopy to map epitopes on immunogens and viral glycoproteins such as HIV. We now plan to increase throughput, improve resolution, and apply to non-IgG immunoglobulins such as IgA.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Understanding human body plan development will shine light on the etiology of congenital diseases and contribute to regenerative medicine. I have established in vitro models of human somite formation using pluripotent stem cells and will construct novel models recapitulating human limb development. Building on my finding that cell sorting underlies somite anteroposterior patterning, I will continue using these models to illuminate mechanisms of pattern formation along the body axis and appendages.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  One crucial goal of Down syndrome (DS) research is to understand the transition from normal developmental progression to the onset of aging-related cognitive decline, including determining when early indicators of decline emerge. Although language is a critical area of focus in DS, there are no data in DS on the development of many of the spoken language metrics implicated to decline with the progression of Alzheimer’s Disease in the general population. In this project, we propose to extend existing Expressive Language Sampling procedures, which are recommended for investigations of language development in DS, into a much-needed toolbox of psychometrically sound metrics that can be used to elucidate language development across the lifespan, bridging the conceptual gap between assessing development and age-related declines in DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Childhood undernutrition is a pervasive, pressing global health challenge whose associated morbidities (immune and metabolic dysfunction, stunting, neurodevelopmental abnormalities) are inadequately treated with current interventions. The contribution of the gut microbiota to pathogenesis is underexplored. This project seeks to understand (i) mechanisms by which a promising microbiota- directed complementary food (MDCF-2) is able to significantly improve the weight gain in children with moderate acute malnutrition, (ii) how biotransformation of its component glycans influences postnatal microbiota and host development and (iii) how to design next-generation MDCFs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The National Institutes of Health, the World Health Organization and the Center for Disease Control are concerned that the development of antibiotics is lagging behind the rise of drug resistance and the evolution of bacterial pathogens. Knowledge of enzymatic transition states has evolved as an efficient method of drug design. This proposal applies transition state technology to the problem of antibiotic resistance and disruption of the gut microbiome in the potentially lethal colitis caused by Clostridioides difficile. The use of novel transition state analogs against the major toxins from C. difficile will protect the gut, preserve the gut microbiome and avoid the use of antibiotics that cause the development of antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: There is a critical unmet need for imaging tools that accurately risk stratify atherosclerotic patients based on their inflammatory phenotype and identify those where a given therapy is indicated and then monitor its effect. The monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 / C-C chemokine receptor type 2 (MCP-1/CCR2) axis is of particular interest because of its role in atherosclerotic lesion formation and its progression. In this proposal we will perform the initial evaluation of the imaging performance of a PET radiotracer [64Cu]DOTA-ECL1i in humans with peripheral carotid and femoral arterial atherosclerosis and obtain key biological information that is foundational for the design of future studies to assess its capability for diagnosis, prognosis assignment and evaluation of new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching objective is to elucidate the specificity and mechanism of breast tumor suppression in response to signaling from the CD36+ fibroblasts (FBs). We address a gap that is mostly unexplored by taking advantage of the FBs component of the stroma. This initiative will be supported by rigorous quantitative assays and novel computational methods to assess the response of the tumor microenvironment to secreted factors by CD36+ FBs. The proposed project is relevant to public health because it will justify the use of secreted factors as therapy or preventative agent in breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH American Indians/Alaska Natives (AI/AN) have a high prevalence of commercial cigarette smoking and a low rate of cessation. This may be attributed to the rate of nicotine metabolism, which is predominately determined by genetic variation and has informed the type of pharmacological treatment associated with enhanced smoking cessation. This project will set the stage for personalized cessation treatment interventions in AI/AN by examining the rate of nicotine metabolism among AI/AN smokers and perceptions of and barriers to using genetically-informed data to inform cessation treatment among AI/AN smokers and their healthcare providers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Relevance to Public Health: Defect in trophoblast lineage development results in early pregnancy loss or leads to pregnancies that are associated with intrauterine growth restriction or preeclampsia, which are leading causes of maternal death and premature birth. These are major public health concerns. Therefore, a better understanding of trophoblast cell lineage development and function is critical to gain insights into important features of pregnancy loss and pregnancy associated disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to investigate if the early stage osteoarthritis (OA) affects the mechanical properties of knee joint tissues in an MRI detectable manner prior to morphological alterations. We will perform knee joint evaluation under mechanical loading that mimics our standing position, using novel quantitative MRI techniques that are insensitive to tissue orientation in the MRI scanner. After accelerating our techniques (UTE-MRI), we will determine if the variation pattern of UTE-MRI under loading is distinct for early stage OA patients, and if bone structure for early stage and mild OA knees improves to support the defected knee regions in a detectable manner by MRI and CT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Steroid sex hormones such as 17β-estradiol (estrogen) are important regulators of immune responses. Although estrogen is generally immunoprotective, our data show that it contributes to the pathogenesis of chronic inflammatory diseases such as IBD by impairing the differentiation and function of regulatory T cells (Tregs). This project seeks to identify the mechanism(s) by which altered estrogen signaling impairs Treg- mediated immunosuppression in the chronically inflamed intestine, with the ultimate goal of developing novel approaches for the treatment of IBD.
