IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Massachusetts General Hospital for Children (MGHfC) Digestive Disease Summer Research Program is an NIH-NIDDK-funded educational program that was established in 2015 to engage early-career students in projects that explore various aspects of digestive disease and encourage these students to consider a career in the biomedical sciences. Undergraduate and medical students participate in a 10-week didactic program each summer that includes mentored supervision of independent research, faculty lectures, peer-to-peer scientific presentation / discussion, and career development activities. Providing an independent mentor- supervised research experience for students at an early stage is known to be effective at fostering a strong interest and appreciation for biomedical research and significantly increases the likelihood that a student will pursue future research opportunities and eventually enter the biomedical research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria are dynamic organelles that actively change their shape to accommodate cellular requirements. Cancer cells can exploit this adaptation to support their energy demands or resist to drug-induced cell death. This proposal aims to 1) determine the precise molecular mechanisms cancer cells alter their mitochondrial morphology during acquisition of drug-resistance and 2) evaluate the therapeutic potential of combining small molecules targeting mitochondrial structure with cell death-inducing agents in acute myeloid leukemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related hearing loss impacts a large share of the population and can have debilitating consequences with respect to productivity, social isolation, and mental health. A chief complaint of older listeners is poor speech understanding in noise, and the goal of this research is to use sophisticated behavioral and electrophysiological methods to discover the relationships between spatial hearing deficits, auditory streaming, individual variability, and hearing aid directional processing that can lead to enhanced and more precise treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will characterize a novel form of proteostasis. By describing how the response to intracellular pathogens improves tolerance of heat shock, we may find new ways to manage and treat aging-related diseases associated with disruptions in proteostasis. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission to seek fundamental knowledge about living systems in order to reduce the burden of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the rapid adoption of electronic cigarettes (e-cigs), particularly among the youth, the short- and long- term health effects remain unknown due, in part, to a lack of an e-cig specific biomarker of exposure. The proposed study will utilize the unique structures of the free radicals generated in e-cig aerosols by common e- liquid solvents, propylene glycol and glycerin, to develop a universal, e-cig specific, biomarker of exposure. The results of this study will provide a valuable tool for researchers and regulators in evaluating e-cig exposure and the short- and long-term effects associated with their use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: A key study reported that TDD rates among newly treated elderly ranged from 7.2% for those taking Risperidone to 11.1% for those taking olanzapine after 2 years of treatment. Earlier meta-analyses estimate TDD frequency in women to be 26.6% and in men 21.6%. Ethnically Chinese and Malaysian mental health patients were studied in Singapore and patients taking anti-psychotic medications were found to have TDD in 40% and 29% of cases respectively. Regardless of prevalence, TDD is a threat to patient adherence and quality of life. TDD only remits in a minority of cases and can be permanent. With 50 million prescriptions for anti-psychotics written annually, more than 44 million persons living with a chronic mental illness are at risk of developing TDD. There are likely over 1.65 million patients living with TDD and the number of patients with TDD is expected to grow with the aging population and increasing off-label use of antipsychotics. This trend is likely accelerated with the increased isolation of existing patients and the increased need for psychiatric treatment due to the pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE In this application, we propose to perform comprehensive functional assessment of an intergenic risk locus for systemic lupus erythematosus on chromosome 12q12. We hypothesize that this locus modulates neighboring long non-coding RNAs and protein-coding genes, resulting with alterations in multiple biological pathways relevant to lupus. This locus presents an ideal model to study how intergenic risk variants contribute to autoimmune disease pathogenesis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop and evaluate an app-based digital mental health intervention (DMHI) for young adults with repeated NSSI, who are not currently engaged in traditional psychological treatment. We will employ user- centered design methods to understand young adults’ specific needs and preferences, which will then guide the development of a scalable, low-intensity DMHI for this population. Our aim is to develop an app that can provide resources (e.g., psychoeducation and skills) to a large numbers of young people with NSSI who are currently unable or uninterested in accessing traditional psychological treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Africa, the birthplace of modern humans, is the single most informative continent for understanding the human genome and human disorders with worldwide impact. Since most genomic research has not involved African populations, generations of human genetic history are missing from our understanding of human genetics and complex disease. In this study, we will use novel whole genome sequencing strategies to characterize the genetic bases of schizophrenia in the Xhosa population of South Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maintenance of cell shape and growth pattern is necessary for proper function, development and differentiation for most organisms. This project will investigate how cells modulate their shape and growth pattern in response to its corresponding cell-cycle stage. In the long term, understanding how cell-cycle cues regulate cell shape can potentially lead to novel therapeutic and diagnostic targets for diseases such as cancer and neuronal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: RELEVANCE The goal of this project is to analyze the cell-type specific proteomes of presynaptic terminals and analyze how specific actin modulatory pathways within govern transmitter release and plasticity. In particular this grant focuses on the roles of Trio, a Rho-family GEF strongly implicated in human brain disorders. Uncovering these molecular mechanisms of presynaptic physiology can be expected to lead to better insights of disorder etiology and potential therapeutic approaches- both major goals of the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acne vulgaris affects nearly every human being and costs the United states approximately $1.3 billion/year, yet most acne treatments are temporary and kill a microbe that is sensitive to light from the sun. The microbial biology leading to this susceptibility is poorly understood, but recent work indicates that acne can be cured using a non-antimicrobial drug that favors microbes with specific differences in this biology. Using samples from this recent work, we will identify which microbial metabolic pathways associate with acne remission and if the biology of light susceptibility can be targeted to cure acne rather than temporarily clear it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Muco-obstructive airway diseases, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, cystic fibrosis (CF), and non-CF bronchiectasis are punctuated by exacerbations that lead to mucous hypersecretion by secretory cells and mucous plugging of the airways. Little is known about how the airway epithelial cells returns to normal during resolution. In this application, we propose that resolution of airway exacerbations occurs by degradation of the mucin granule in secretory cells by the autophagy pathway.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project is relevant to public health because Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE) is a type of brain injury that occurs in 1-3 per 1000 births. There is a great need to develop a bedside test in neonates with HIE to accurately predict which babies may have brain injury. Thus the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing therapies that will help reduce the burden of human disability.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Emotion regulation (ER) problems are prevalent in young children living in poverty, and while high quality early care and education (ECE) programs are positioned to prevent child ER difficulties, they often fail to do so because teachers lack internal support to help them sustain evidence-based teaching practices and skills. Training ECE directors to provide enhanced supervision to their teachers may promote positive effects of ECE programming and adaptive ER in children. This study aims to refine and then test an intervention focused on training and supporting ECE directors in Reflective Practice and Supervision to dually target teaching and child outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Despite expected exponential increases in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias, and an overabundance of research indicating that preoperative cognitive impairment is a major risk factor for negative post-operative outcome, we know very little of AD cognitive, biomarker, and anesthesia/surgical interactions and have little to no evidence-based perioperative medical care strategies for AD patients. Via the K07 mechanism and institutional support, the applicant will leverage novel perioperative clinical and state-of-the-art institutional facilities to develop an institutional wide research and training program addressing these problems. The proposed program will result in improved awareness of cognition and memory status in older adults prior to surgical procedures with anesthesia, intensify collaborative research addressing brain-behavior-anesthesia interactions through both animal and human research approaches, and promote translation of research findings to clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Osseointegrated prostheses are a novel alternative to a socket that directly mount the prosthesis to the residual limb via a bone anchored implant providing more normative load transmission between the ground and residual limb; yet its effect on the mechanical environment of the joint remains unknown. This project will be the first to rigorously investigate the longitudinal effects of osseointegrated prostheses across multiple biomechanical domains using medical imaging and computational modeling. By quantifying its effect on muscle composition, cartilage loading mechanics, and cartilage health, we can begin to determine if prosthesis osseointegration plays a positive role of osteoarthritis progression in this population differently than a socket, which has vast clinical implications including informing targeted rehabilitation and patient eligibility criteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intellectual Disability (ID) and Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) are the most common developmental disorders, affecting ~3-4% of children in the U.S. Human genetics studies have revealed that mutations in subunits of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex are recurrently mutated in individuals with ID/ASD. The proposed study will develop new model systems and experimental tools to study the function of SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complexes during normal brain development to help understand the specific changes that occur during brain development in children with ID/ASD and to inform development of new therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The major goals of the Overview are to build upon the leads using cleavage-independent, NFL trimer-liposomes and heterologous prime:boosting that generated bNAbs in a subset of rabbits to translate this remarkable progress at multiple sites of HIV Env vulnerability into non-human primates (NHPs). We propose to use negative stain EM Polyclonal Fab:trimer Epitope Mapping (EMPEM) to better guide boost selection in NHPs from both trimer-liposomes and lipid particle encapsulated mRNA expressing membrane-bound trimers (Projects 1 and Core C, Core B and Projects2) followed by structural analysis of cross-neutralizing antibodies in complex with trimer (Core C), administered by Core A in a multi-faceted approach. The efficient elicitation of tier 2 cross- antibodies in either adult or juvenile NHPs would be a significant step forward toward the goal of generating an effective HIV-1 vaccine to have a substantial impact on improving human public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The purpose of the HIV and Substance Use Cohort Coordinating Center for Emerging and High Impact Scientific Cross Cohort Studies: HIV SUCCESS for the HIV/AIDS and Substance Use Cohorts Program is to coordinate and support a collaboration of longitudinal cohorts to address emerging and high priority research in the setting of substance use and HIV. We are well-positioned to provide operational support for cohorts and a platform for harmonizing data to address important research questions as we supply infrastructure and resources matched with innovative methodological approaches, scientific leadership including substance use and HIV research expertise, administrative support for protocol development, implementation and dissemination, development of future HIV and substance use research through mentorship, and most importantly a multi-disciplinary team with expertise in substance use treatment and research, clinical HIV, data integration, substance use intervention implementation, epidemiology, biostatistics, and clinical informatics. As the HIV SUCCESS coordinating center, we will bring our vast experience with cohort collaborations such as CNICS, STTR, ROI, ARCH, and NA-ACCORD and with harmonizing HIV data across cohorts which will allow us to generate new knowledge at the intersection of HIV and substance use to inform future research and clinical care in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the current project is to use advanced cognitive, physiological, and neuroimaging techniques to critically evaluate whether aerobic exercise boosts fear extinction learning processes and thus, reduces subsequent fear responding (when tested 24hrs later) in trauma-exposed adult men and women with and without Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). This research has the potential to inform the neurobiological mechanisms responsible for reducing the return of fear in adults with PTSD, and thereby could lead to improved treatment approaches for the millions of Americans currently diagnosed with PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The prevalence rate of asthma is higher in pre-pubescent and aging males, and in post-pubertal females, suggesting a role for female sex steroids such as estrogens in modulating this disease. However, studies suggest a possible role of other signaling mechanisms interplaying with estrogens. Kisspeptin is a crucial regulatory protein involved in female puberty as well as a modulator of sex steroids. In this context, we propose that a decrease in expression of kisspeptin and their function in asthmatics compared to non-asthmatics (specifically females) conveys a possible sex specific role of kisspeptin in asthma. Our studies use human airway smooth muscles from both male and female asthmatics vs. non-asthmatics, along with animal studies where we control estrogen levels. These studies will substantially enhance our understanding of how and why kisspeptin signaling influences the asthmatic airway. This is a necessary and clinically important step if we are to develop novel therapeutic strategies for asthma, possibly in a gender/sex specific fashion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite advances in understanding the immuno-pathogenesis of RA, disability remains high due to persistent inflammation and joint damage from increased osteoclast (OC)-mediated bone erosion and decreased osteoblast (OB)-mediated bone formation. Remissions are rare. We will evaluate how a novel subset of B cells, expressing the transcription factor T-bet, contribute to ongoing disease activity and inhibit bone-forming OBs and activate bone-eroding OCs, thus contributing to inflammation and joint destruction. This research is important because a better understanding of disease pathogenesis will ultimately lead to new therapies and allow patient- tailored treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) affects more than 2.5 million (US civilian and veterans) annually and accounts for 30% of all injury-related fatalities, with ~75% of these categorized as mild TBI (mTBI) or concussion. Repetitive mTBI injuries induce cumulative adverse effects which may continue for many years after the original injury, with trauma representing one of the strongest environmental risk factors for developing neurodegenerative disorders. This proposal will investigate the underlying mechanisms and explore therapeutic strategies for treating repetitive mTBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE. Pregnant females with severe obesity are more likely to experience adverse perinatal health events including gestational diabetes, preeclampsia and preterm labor as well as birth babies with discordant growth patterns. Rigorous interventions targeting gestational weight gain and dietary quality have not translated to markedly improved perinatal health among this population suggesting a need for innovation. This pilot study aims to test the safety, acceptability and preliminary efficacy of time-restricted eating on weight, cardiometabolic risk markers and perinatal health outcomes among pregnant Black females given they suffer disproportionately from both severe obesity and adverse health events in the perinatal period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Immunologic memory, by which the immune system “remembers” previous exposures to pathogens by responding faster and better, is critical to health, including vaccination responses. After initial exposure to a pathogen, some B lymphocytes that can make antibodies also change to become longer-lived and to respond differently than they did originally, becoming “memory B cells”. We are trying to understand the molecular basis of these changes and the types of memory B cells that are generated, which will in turn help understand resistance to pathogens, vaccine responses, and possibly some autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Current retinal prostheses for treating blindness caused by photoreceptor degeneration lack the necessary spatial resolution to provide high acuity vision. Intraretinal stimulation achieved by ultrasmall carbon fiber electrodes can elicit responses from single retinal ganglion cells without inadvertently activating nearby axons. The project will investigate basic mechanisms of intraretinal stimulation, optimize stimulation parameters, and assess functionality and biocompatiblity of an intraretinal stimulation array in a large-eye animal model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The continuing need for additional therapeutic drugs to treat mental health disorders involving monoamine signaling provides a compelling reason to further our understanding of how monoamine signaling is regulated. In this proposal we intend to employ novel transporter interacting molecules and identify structural elements within the dopamine transporters that determine transporter function and regulation. This will enable a systematic evaluation of the therapeutic potential of these activities in preclinical animal models for a broad spectrum of disorders involving aberrant monoaminergic signaling including ADHD, depression, anxiety, schizophrenia and drug and alcohol abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Over 80% of patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) develop metastases in the liver and have worse outcomes than those with primary tumors. This proposal focuses on determining the role of liver endothelium-secreted LRG1 in promoting mCRC tumorigenesis, and elucidating the involved mechanisms. This project will identify a new signaling pathway by which the liver endothelium microenvironment promotes mCRC development and will identify potential targets for developing new therapies to treat patients with mCRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Agitation frequently occurs when patients experience mental health crises, and use of invasive measures like physical restraints to manage agitation are disproportionately used on racial/ethnic minorities and socioeconomically disadvantaged individuals in the emergency setting. This study will use system dynamics modeling, a rigorous simulation modeling and systems science method, to describe, measure, and reduce disparities in agitation care by developing mental health interventions and assessing their potential benefits and costs on key equity outcomes through partnerships with patients, clinicians, and healthcare administrators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medical marijuana use among adults 50 and older has more than doubled in the past decade with exponential increases projected in this demographic by 2050, and prescription opioids are one of the most common treatments for pain management in this population. The current proposal seeks to examine effects of daily medical marijuana use for 12 months or greater and the combined effect of prescription opioid use to identify whether medical marijuana and/or prescription opioid use affects performance on an open-road driving task in adults 50 and older who endorse chronic or severe non-malignant pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adverse morbidity Streptococcus inflammation  pregnancy outcomes, including premature birth and stillbirth, are the leading causes of neonatal and mortality. A frequent cause is Intrauterine infection, which occurs when bacteria like Group B (GBS) ascend from the vagina into the uterus and invade the amniotic cavity, leading to and tissue damage. As maternal GBS colonization of the female genital tract (FGT) represents the major risk factor for adverse pregnancy outcomes my research seeks to elucidate the molecular mechanisms that govern the dynamic aspects of GBS vaginal carriage and ascension to the FGT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  Hundreds of drugs have failed in clinical trials to treat acute ischemic stroke (disease that affects 600,000 Americans annually) due to the inability of concentrating the drug in the brain tissue without causing non-tolerable side effects. To overcome these failures, we will develop a new nanotechnology, in which we package drugs into 100-nanometer drug carriers that are targeted to the key cells in the injured area of the brain (endothelial cells). Using these targeted nanocarriers (that concentrates the drug 200 times in the injured site), we will answer fundamental questions in pharmacology and biology of acute ischemic stroke, while at the same time finding a new treatment approach.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The 2020 Dietary Guidelines have highlighted vitamin D as a nutrient of concern; increased risk of vitamin D3 deficiency is observed in Black individuals, individuals with obesity and in pregnant women. The proposed project will use an innovative, trideuterated vitamin D3 approach to obtain the first kinetic data on D3 and 25(OH)D3 dynamics in non-pregnant and pregnant White women and Black women with and without obesity. Findings obtained will identify non-modifiable (genetic ancestry and functional consequences of vitamin D metabolism genes) and modifiable factors (maternal vitamin D status and BMI) that influence vitamin D utilization across gestation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Liquid biopsies have made significant strides in cancer medicine but substantial questions remain, such as whether cancers which shed little tumor DNA into blood could be detected with higher sensitivity methods. This proposal builds on work performed during the first cycle of this grant, aiming to develop and optimize a new technology, DS-DR-MAESTRO (minor allele enriched sequencing through recognition oligonucleotides), that affords extremely high sensitivity to detect circulating tumor DNA. The optimized DS-DR-MAESTRO technology will be applied in detecting MRD in samples collected from esophageal cancer patients, a type of cancer that is notorious for shedding low amounts of DNA in circulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in our understanding of the underlying genetic abnormalities in myelofibrosis (MF) and the development of JAK2 inhibitors, MF remains an aggressive chronic myeloid malignancy due to persistence of JAK2-activating mutations in patients undergoing JAK2 inhibitor therapy, the emergence of drug resistance, and a propensity for transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Thus, there is an urgent need to devise new treatment strategies that target the molecular and genetic aberrations driving MF development and clonal expansion, particularly in triple negative MF patients who lack mutations in the JAK2 kinase pathway. This R01 research program focuses on defining the roles of a new MYC-alarmin circuit that we have shown is sufficient to provoke MF, and to preclinically assess the therapeutic potential of targeting this pathway to improve outcomes in MF.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Several psychotherapies for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) have a strong evidence base for their efficacy, but nonresponse rates are high, particularly among older Veterans. Accumulating evidence indicates that memory deficits and poor learning of therapy contents adversely affect psychotherapy treatment response in PTSD. However, limited research has examined methods for increasing learning of therapy contents in psychotherapy for PTSD. The proposed study aims to examine the feasibility of integrating an intervention to increase learning and memory of psychotherapy content into the provision of a widely used psychotherapy, cognitive processing therapy (CPT), for older adults with PTSD. The ultimate goal of this line of research is to develop novel rehabilitation interventions to increase functioning for individuals with PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Despite current therapeutic strategies, human subjects with diabetes and peripheral artery disease (PAD) suffer from an increased risk of critical limb ischemia (CLI), a more severe condition associated with impaired growth of new blood vessels, ischemic rest pain, impaired wound healing, and a higher risk of limb amputation and cardiovascular death. We have identified a novel pro-angiogenic microRNA, termed miR-130b, in both mice and human subjects with diabetes and increasing severity of PAD. The proposed studies will provide a detailed understanding for how miR-130b promotes critical angiogenic signaling pathways and functional responses in ischemic limbs with the goal of developing novel therapies for overcoming “angiogenic resistance” in the treatment of diabetic critical limb ischemia.

PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because it will contribute to our understanding of the cardiac transcriptional response to stress induced hypertrophy that occurs in both human and rodent models of heart disease. The goal of this project is to determine the function of the Mediator kinase to regulate cardiac gene expression utilizing new genetic and pharmacologic tools combined with NextGen sequencing technology. This research aligns with the NHLBI's mission to promote the prevention and treatment of heart disease by advancing our understanding of the transition from the basal to hypertrophic gene programs through the Mediator kinase and the potential for developing a new therapeutic strategy to treat cardiac dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thrombosis is the uncontrolled formation of a blood clot that blocks a vessel, often linked to inflammation and inflammatory disease, and is the leading cause of death and disability worldwide. The primary goal of this research program is to determine mechanisms linking fibrin(ogen) to thrombus formation and hemostasis using new tools that selectively reduce circulating fibrinogen or specifically suppress fibrin matrix formation. This research is highly relevant to public health as it will foster creative discoveries for minimizing the morbidity and mortality associated of thrombotic diseases, including inflammation-associated thrombosis, while providing critical insight into new anti-thrombotic treatments that are expected to be safer than the current options.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Power systems for powered mobility devices, including power wheelchairs and scooter, have not changed significantly in decades. They have generally revolved around Lead-acid batteries, but some more recently are using Lithium-Ion batteries. Both Lead-Acid and Lithium-Ion batteries have limitations in terms of range, charging time, safety, and environmental impacts. Nickel-Zinc batteries may present many advantages to Lead- Acid and Lithium-Ion batteries, but aren’t able to directly replace them on powered mobility devices due to a small cycle life when used in low power situations. This limitation may be ameliorated if the Nickel-Zinc batteries are combined with supercapacitors. This project will develop a Nickel-Zinc and supercapacitor hybrid power system and evaluate the range of the system compared to Lead-Acid and Lithium-Ion batteries using standard range tests. The results may provide a power system that is safer, more environmentally friendly, and able to be charged faster for Veterans who use powered mobility devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple myeloma (MM) and non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) are common immune system cancers that pose a substantial public health, personal and financial burden; treatment is expensive, and for some more aggressive subtypes, more than half of patients die within five years of diagnosis. Certain occupational exposures such as pesticides or solvents (i.e., benzene) have been shown to be risk factors for these cancers, but it is not known whether lower-dose environmental exposure to those agents also increases risk to the general population. The studies proposed in this application will make use of extensive residential histories for participants in eight large study populations, and of routine environmental monitoring for pollutants, to provide much-needed insights into the association of lower-level exposure to single and mixtures of environmental pollutants with risk of MM, NHL, and common NHL subtypes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Cigarette smoke (CS) contributes to the development of severe influenza virus pneumonia. However, innate immune mechanisms by which CS exacerbates flu-induced lung injury are not well understood. The proposed study will introduce a novel paradigm that occlusion of lung microvasculature by neutrophil-platelet aggregates promotes CS-induced flu severity and potentially identify a new therapeutic target in the platelet-neutrophil signaling.

PHR: Chlamydia trachomatis is the leading bacterial cause of sexually transmitted disease worldwide. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will lead to new diagnostic biomarkers that can identify women at increased risk of poor reproductive outcomes after infection and identifying people for targeted treatments and more frequent screening. This will reduce the burden of involuntary infertility and improve the health of young people so is well aligned with the NIH’s mission that seeks to apply knowledge to ‘enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability’.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is an autosomal recessive disorder of cilia structure and function, characterized by chronic infections of the respiratory tract, male infertility, and disorders of organ laterality (situs inversus). In the current proposal we hypothesize that cytoglobin, a novel heme protein of yet unknown function, controls spatiotemporal nitric oxide (NO) levels in cilia in airway ciliated cells and during development, via interactions with NO synthases, necessary for normal ciliary function and left/right asymmetry of the heart. Our work aims to bridge a critical gap in knowledge about the role of NO signaling in normal ciliary function and the development of PCD and situs inversus, and has the potential to change our current paradigm for diagnosis and therapy of ciliopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Triple-negative Breast Cancer (TNBC) is more common and exhibits higher aggressiveness in African American women as compared to their European American counterparts, with socio-economic and lifestyle factors being unable to fully account for this significant racial disparity. Our proposed studies will delineate the molecular mechanisms associated with TNBC aggressiveness with an overarching goal of identifying the etiologic factors contributing to outcome disparities in African Americans. Our proposed studies will also unravel novel surveillance and therapeutic avenues, thereby guiding and improving the clinical management of this deadly disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This unique project will identify key timing and drivers of maternal-child cardiovascular health (CVH) starting during preconception in a diverse population. The results and products of this work will directly inform family- level and population-level strategies that address the psychosocial contexts of diverse families to promote ma- ternal and child CVH. This project aligns with the NHLBI Division of Cardiovascular Sciences’ strategic vision themes and priorities, including addressing social determinants of health and health inequities, promoting CVH across the lifespan including in infancy and early childhood, and reducing maternal cardiovascular morbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to develop α3β4-selective nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChRs) negative allosteric modulators as novel pharmacotherapies for cocaine use disorder. Because the α3β4 nAChRs have been implicated in the addictive properties of nearly all drugs of abuse, these antagonists have the potential to have a significant and far-reaching impact on the treatment of drug addictions. Thus, this research is relevant to the National Institute on Drug Abuse’s strategic goal to “develop new and improved treatments to help people with substance use disorders achieve and maintain a meaningful and sustained recovery.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The variation in gut microbiota strain composition between individuals is a major determinant of the functional impact of a gut microbiota on its host. However, we know little of how our gut microbiota strains are acquired, retained, or transmitted. Using a sensitive microbial strain tracking algorithm, metagenomics, and human fecal samples from fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) recipients as well as fecal samples from families of various size, we will test hypotheses of how gut microbial strains are transmitted therapeutically in FMT and naturally in families to establish basic science principles of gut microbiome strain transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cilia dysfunction causes a wide range of human disorders with polycystic kidney disease (PKD) being a common manifestation. One of the central questions in PKD research is how the selective cilia import (i.e. cilia gating) of PKD proteins, particularly polycystins mutated in Autosomal Dominant PKD (ADPKD), is regulated in kidney cells. This proposal aims to combine the simple and efficient C. elegans model with disease-relevant renal cell models to uncover the novel role of Autosomal Recessive PKD (ARPKD) protein DZIP1L in establishing a functional cilia gate to promote cilia import of polycystins, reveal how dysfunctional cilia gating leads to renal disorders, and further shed light on the molecular link between the pathogenesis of ARPKD and ADPKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lyme disease is the most common vector-borne infection in the United States, with nearly 500,000 cases per year. The bacterium Borrelia (Borreliella) burgdorferi causes Lyme disease when it is transmitted to humans by a tick vector. Bacteria, including B. burgdorferi, can themselves be infected by bacteriophages (phages), a type of virus. This application proposes to fill a knowledge gap regarding the fundamental understanding of B. burgdorferi phage biology, including the molecular basis of phage replication and the mechanisms by which phage facilitate movement of genes between bacteria, enhancing the persistence of B. burgdorferi in nature via reinfection of its hosts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The most common cardiovascular problem observed in extremely preterm infants is patent ductus arteriosus, an extra blood vessel found in babies before or just after birth that often requires surgery. Following surgery, almost 50% of preterm infants can develop Post-ligation Cardiac Syndrome (PLCS), a condition that requires additional care and for which there are no known treatments. The proposed Milrinone for Prevention of Post- ligation Cardiac Syndrome (MIDAS) trial will aid in establishing whether milrinone (a common cardiac medication) reduces the risk of PLCS in extremely preterm infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection could be a risk factor for progression of AMD as a result of viral latency in the choroid/RPE, since there is a significantly higher association of anti-HCMV IgG titers with neovascular AMD and HCMV DNA was present in choroid/RPE samples from human cadavers. Our goal is to investigate the mechanism by which latent cytomegalovirus infection in the choroid/RPE contributes to the pathogenesis of AMD, thereby potentially opening new avenues for treatment. The proposed research is relevant to public health and NIH’s mission because increasing our understanding of the pathogenesis of AMD has the potential to yield new, more efficacious and less invasive treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) affects 2.5 million Americans, is rising in prevalence, and is associated with substantial morbidity and mortality. Myocardial interstitial fibrosis contributes to HFpEF, but few tools are available to diagnose or treat it. This proposal will investigate blood markers for diagnosis of myocardial fibrosis, and whether an approved heart failure drug, sacubitril/valsartan, reduces myocardial fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The ability to regulate when and how emotions are used to guide cognition relies on the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), a key area that provides a unique cortical integrative node for otherwise segregated cognitive, motor and limbic networks. Our previous R01 (MH116008) showed how ACC exhibited specialized inhibitory and neuromodulatory features, and diversity in its extrinsic outputs to cognitive/motor and limbic areas. Using anatomical tract-tracing, optogenetics, slice physiology, high-resolution microscopy and computational modeling in rhesus monkeys, this renewal aims to assess cellular and circuit properties of short-range intrinsic interconnections across functionally distinct rostral ‘cognitive’, ventral ‘limbic’ and dorsal ‘motor’ ACC subdivisions, which are important neural substrates for multimodal integration and are differentially affected in affective disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cause of Crohn’s disease (CD), where inflammation attacks the intestines and other body sites, is still unknown, and treatment regimens remain inadequate for many patients with severe disease. We recently discovered Debaryomyces hansenii, a fungus present in many processed foods, in human intestinal wounds and found that it inhibits the repair of damaged tissue in murine models. We propose to determine how this fungus drives the progression of CD to gain new insights into CD and to identify new avenues for therapy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite its clinical importance, the underlying basis of diabetic cardiomyopathy remains unclear. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Studies have found that fewer than half (48%) of children from low-income families are ready for elementary school compared to the 75% of children from moderate or high-income households. School readiness prior to entering elementary school is a critical target for intervention due to robust evidence that it may act as a protective factor for low- income students who start elementary school at a disadvantage due to lack of resources, family stress, and fewer opportunities. The proposed study has the potential to improve outcomes for these children by identifying modifiable teacher behaviors, and promoting children’s potential for learning, adaptation, and academic success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Alcohol-related liver disease and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease with inflammation, fat and fibrosis are risk factors for liver cancer and the two most common reasons for liver transplant in the United States. In this project, we aim to identify the molecular mechanisms that alter lipid metabolism and explore genetic variations that may lead to these conditions. This will provide a better understanding for targeted therapy aimed at liver diseases and metabolic syndromes in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this proposal is to develop a fully automatic algorithm to extract geometric features from brain vessels of stroke patients in real-time and the effects of ischemic stroke on vascular alterations. We will use these features to improve the prediction of major complications and long-term outcomes after stroke and acute reperfusion therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a disorder characterized by lung scarring and has a prognosis worse than that of most cancers. Identifying IPF at very early, but detectable, stages could lead to earlier treatment and improved outcomes for those at risk for this disease, and improving our understanding of early disease pathogenesis could lead to newer, more targeted, medical therapies. This proposal aims to improve our understanding of both early disease pathogenesis, and detection, by providing a comprehensive characterization of the proteins and genetic factors in those at risk to develop early stages of pulmonary fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pain is a common and disabling symptom of cancer, yet patients of color are half as likely as White patients to receive adequate pain management, likely because they are prescribed fewer and less potent opioids. This proposal will examine the scope and key drivers of racial and ethnic disparities in opioid management across the cancer care trajectory, using a multi-level analysis of Medicare and Medicaid claims data linked to comprehensive information about physicians, practices, systems, and neighborhoods. Findings will elucidate key mechanisms by which racism undermines equitable pain management, and will be used to design a scalable multi-level intervention to promote equitable cancer pain management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Infantile nystagmus syndrome, an involuntary oscillation of the eyes that develops in the first six months of life, is both visually and socially debilitating, but how and why it develops is poorly understood. This project aims to understand how and when development of the neural circuitry responsible for eye movements is altered in a mouse model of nystagmus. This work will both provide fundamental knowledge about neurodevelopment and identify new therapeutic targets for treatment or prevention of infantile nystagmus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As we get older, our lenses can become stiff and cloudy, which can lead to vision problems such as cataract and presbyopia (difficulty seeing things up close). This happens because of a buildup of damage caused by oxidation, which is a process that occurs naturally in the body. This study will look at the specific reasons why oxidation occurs and how it contributes to lens aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Identifying the risk for severe immune-related adverse events will have a major public health impact as risk assessment-based monitoring will facilitate early detection and prompt management of immune-related ad- verse events, minimizing the progression to life-threatening or fatal events. Thus, this approach will reduce treatment-induced symptom burden and mortality, while significantly improving treatment adherence and treat- ment outcome. This strategy aligns with NCI Cancer Moonshot Blue Ribbon Panel 2016 recommendations to systematically gather patient-reported outcomes and develop innovative patient-based approaches to facilitate adherence to effective therapies and improve patients’ quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Current clinical thresholds for bone mineral density (BMD) are controversial, as the conventional T-score method often classifies patients who suffer from fragility fractures as “normal”, particularly in minority women. This project aims to develop Person-specific Precision Thresholds (PPTs) for BMD in individual minority women by utilizing big data and advanced modeling techniques to account for the numerous individual-level differences. Developing next-generation PPTs can significantly improve disease diagnosis, prevention, and risk management, ultimately reducing healthcare disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Dysferlinopathies are muscular dystrophies that affect thousands of Americans. They are caused by the absence of the protein dysferlin, and the subsequent failure of the muscle cell to maintain normal control of calcium signaling and to repair itself after injury. We have identified small proteins that can “fix” both of these faults. Here we proposed to optimize their activities, learn how they work, and test them in mice to learn if they provide effective therapies for these muscular dystrophies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance) In the proposed study, our aim to is develop study procedures for a randomized controlled trial to evaluate scoliosis-specific physiotherapy for adolescent idiopathic scoliosis. Over the course of the award, we will develop our protocol and manual of operating procedures, fulfill appropriate regulatory requirements, and develop and test our recruitment procedures. In so doing, we will be prepared to conduct a rigorous trial that will fundamentally add to the evidence base for non-operative management of adolescent idiopathic scoliosis, with the ultimate goal of preventing progression and the need for invasive surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular pathogen that can cause serious disease in immunocompromised individuals, such as AIDS patients, and fetuses, and is also a major cause of blindness in otherwise healthy individuals. In this proposal we will determine the mechanisms by which stimulated primary human cells inhibit Toxoplasma growth and how the parasite’s secreted effectors counteract these mechanisms. This will provide valuable insights into how human cells detect and destroy Toxoplasma and how Toxoplasma counteracts this, potentially leading to novel therapeutics and allowing prediction of the virulence of specific Toxoplasma strains in humans.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it elucidates the molecular mechanisms of obesity- related changes to plasma bile acid levels and hepatic drug transport. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver dysfunction is a major driver of pathology in obesity and diabetes, and we have discovered a new metabolite-driven pathway that appears to be required for exerting these effects. This program will determine the importance of this newfound signaling pathway in preventing obesity and diabetes pathogenesis, and examine mechanisms through which this is achieved. We expect that this will lead to the development of new treatments for metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Klebsiella pneumoniae is a leading cause of antibiotic-resistant hospital-acquired infections and childhood mortality. In this study, we will determine what types of antibodies are associated with protection against Klebsiella pneumoniae. We will also study human antibody responses against a variety of molecules that coat the outer surface of Klebsiella pneumoniae to identify the ideal targets of a new vaccine for this bacterium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The basic pathogenetic mechanisms of Human papilloma virus positive head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HPV+ OPSCC) remain incompletely understood. This proposal seeks to overcome a substantial gap in knowledge by advancing on our recent technological developments to study the molecular impact of HPV to host tumor genome integrations on the host transcriptome. Furthermore, we will also advance the general understanding of when HPV integration events drive cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Cocaine use disorder (CUD) remains a vast problem in the United States due, in part, to the high economic and health costs, and, unlike other drugs of abuse, there is no FDA-approved medication for treatment. Although there are many factors that influence CUD, there is a strong interaction between stress and drug use in human cocaine users which is problematic as stress is an unavoidable and powerful contributor to CUD. The proposed research is relevant to human health sciences as understanding the neurobiological mechanisms that are responsible for the long-term consequences of stress-drug interactions on susceptibility to drug-seeking behavior remains an important and necessary area of study with the ultimate goal of developing new and more effective therapeutic strategies for managing CUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (3-sentence limit) Recent advances in hyperpolarized metabolic imaging, pioneered by our team and others, allow real-time in vivo tracking of metabolic conversions of injected hyperpolarized 13C-pyruvate to downstream metabolites in multiple metabolic pathways, resulting in new imaging biomarkers to indicate aberrant cellular metabolism, inform dis- ease progression, and guide treatment decisions. One of the major hurdles for widespread clinical translation of this novel technique is most standard clinical scanners have only proton imaging capabilities and cannot detect 13C signals. In this feasibility study, our team will develop and validate a simple, smart, cost-effective scanner “add-on module” that will enable the transfer of polarization-enhanced signals from 13C to proton and enable metabolic imaging of hyperpolarized 13C compounds on a standard clinical MRI scanner via indirect 1H detection.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is more prominent in women and has greater severity in the Hispanic and Black populations. One in 4 veterans has arthritis (25.6%), compared to 1 in 5 civilians. RA is a disabling autoimmune disease that is associated with depression, cardiovascular disease, and psychosocial stress as well as being more prominent in women. Our clinic at the Jesse Brown VA sees around 700-900 RA patients annually. There is no cure for RA and up to 50% of RA patients do not respond to current therapies. Therefore, we aim to find a novel therapy that can slow or reverse RA pannus formation. To resolve the critical barrier in RA treatment, we have identified a novel pathway that plays a central role in pannus formation by linking immune cell activation with joint blood vessel formation. The goal of our proposal is to understand the mechanism of the identified unique pathway and to evaluate whether the blockade of its function may be more effective than the current standard of care therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: About 10% of Americans develop an autoimmune disease, reflecting a breakdown in the induction of T- or B-cell tolerance in the thymus, bone marrow or periphery. This study focuses on a newly discovered mechanism of T-cell tolerance induction: deletion or diversion to a regulatory-cell phenotype of self-reactive thymocytes through contact with thymic mimetic cells. Mimetic cells, via expression of appropriate lineage- defining transcription factors, take on the mantle of peripheral cell-types, while still maintaining their identity as thymic stromal cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adults in the US spend over 50% of their waking day being sedentary, i.e., in a sitting or lying posture. Being sedentary is known to confer higher risk of diabetes and heart disease, yet sedentary time has increased greatly the 1960s given the rise of technologies that have automated jobs and incorporated screens into occupational and leisure activities. In this project, we will use advanced computation techniques to accurately quantify an individual’s sedentary behavior patterns with the ultimate goal of developing guidelines for reducing sedentary behavior and promoting healthy living, wellbeing and longevity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Anal /fecal continence (FI) is a major medical illness, as it affects many Veterans, and it affects their quality of life. Many FI patients develop symptoms after about 5 decades of life and the risk increases with advancing age, the reasons for which are not clear. Currently, there are no effective preventive strategies. The major focus of this proposal is to understand and evaluate pathophysiological changes. These studies will also evaluate the application of a novel multimodal intervention approach to prevent FI in an animal model. We believe the proposed studies will have important therapeutic implications for the treatment strategies for FI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The skull roof is an exquisite set of patterned bones that encase the brain and sensory organs of all vertebrates. In humans, calvarial defects such as craniosynostosis, which occur in 1/2500 live births, have detrimental consequences for brain and sensory organ development. The objective of this proposal is to define the role of substrate-based cell migration in regulating normal skull development as a key mechanism underlying craniofacial pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the causative agent of human tuberculosis, a devastating infectious disease, which infects millions of people and kills ~1.5 million annually. M. tuberculosis can replicate inside macrophages, where it becomes antibiotic tolerant and harder to kill. The aim of this proposal is to identify new anti-tubercular agents which target intracellular bacteria and to determine the mode of action of these agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative  Many psychiatric disorders are characterized by dysregulation of perception and attention, for instance, the hypervigilance seen in individuals with obsessive-compulsive or anxiety disorders when they are exposed to potentially threatening situations. The proposed research examines how novel measures of visual activity obtained with electroencephalography can be used to predict symptoms of obsessive-compulsive and anxiety disorders. Establishing reliable and valid quantitative indices of perception and attention that vary systematically with self-reported symptoms is a necessary step towards objective assessment of the brain circuits underlying emotional dysfunction in these disorders, and ultimately to inform evidence-based intervention and treatment efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: The mission of GMOD and JBrowse is to make genome data accessible using the tools of the dynamic web. The size of genomic datasets can be daunting to users, particularly as the number of sequenced species and strains proliferates. We propose to add machine learning tools to help navigate these datasets, along with user interface enhancements that exploit evolutionary similarity, and improvements to performance and usability via a series of benchmarks and outreach operations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is a major unmet medical problem that afflicts twenty percent of the population at some point of their lives and is inadequately treated by opioids, which have life-threatening side effects and abuse potential. This proposal aims to identify and characterize new receptors that mediate nerve growth factor (NGF) -induced pain and to determine how NGF and its receptors signal from subcellular compartments to cause chronic pain. A deep understanding of how NGF signals pain will provide insights into the mechanism and treatment of chronic pain, with implications for other diseases that are mediated by growth factors, including cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: How coordinated neuronal activity arises in the cortex is still poorly understood, yet could be the basis of cortical function. In a past award we discovered that activating neuronal ensembles in mouse visual cortex using holographic optogenetics leads to predictable changes in visual discrimination, and we now propose to explore how these ensembles are formed and how they work. This work could help control cortical activity via activation of trigger cells in ensembles and thus provide novel strategies to ameliorate amblyopia and cortical cerebral visual impairment by reconfiguring abnormal circuits.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a disease with very high morbidity and mortality and can occur as secondary to evolution of myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS), a group of diseases seen in older patients and have a high prevalence in the aging VA population. The work proposed here should have a major impact in this area by driving the development of new agents that target unique components of a novel pathway (ULK1) that we have identified in AML leukemia cells. The results of these studies could ultimately result in the development of novel therapeutic agents for refractory AML and MDS, or new strategies combining standard chemotherapy with ULK1 targeting agents and/or lead to the design of completely new anti-leukemia agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Graft versus host disease (GVHD) of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract is one of the major complications associated with allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) and leads to significant morbidity and mortality. The goal of this project is to critically examine the role of an inflammatory cytokine, termed granulocyte- macrophage colony stimulating factor, in the pathophysiology of GVHD in the GI tract. The ultimate objective of this proposal is that, through these preclinical studies, we will gain new insights into this disease which will lead to the development of novel clinical approaches for the treatment of this complication after allogeneic HSCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Stem cells (SCs) are natural units of tissue repair and homeostasis, and their versatility holds promise for tissue regeneration. This research uses the skin epithelium as a model to delineate the crosstalk that SCs undergo with their local microenvironments which enable SCs to self-renew and survive long-term during normal tissue homeostasis and in response to injuries. Understanding how SCs cope with stress and with breaches in the epithelial barrier is a fundamental prerequisite to ascertaining the potential of SCs for regenerative therapies and to devise new and improved therapeutics for inflammatory disorders and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a heterogeneous disease, due to different groups of biologic processes. Genetic variants and small molecules, called metabolites, may help identify these processes and explain differences in COPD. In our study, we will classify groups of genetic variants into pathways, and examine how they relate to metabolites, as well as gene expression and proteins. We will then investigate how this information can be used to subset COPD, identify gene by environment interactions, and identify new drug targets. This work will lead to a greater understanding of disease processes in COPD and more specific treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a comprehensive study to evaluate the efficacy and feasibility of implementing InvesT1D, an innovative, ethically-sensitive, patient- and stakeholder-centered intervention that aims to improve management of type 1 diabetes by offering adolescents financial incentives for engagement in diabetes self- care behaviors. If this intervention is effective and cost-effective, it could have a significant impact on the health and quality of life for the over 80% of adolescents with type 1 diabetes who are struggling to meet glycemic targets. The development and evaluation of this intervention can also serve as a model for health interventions targeting other health conditions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Research on this competitive renewal evidenced that CYP11A1-derived secosteroidal derivatives are excellent candidates to serve as radioprotectors and chemopreventive agents in UVB induced cancerogenesis, because of their high efficacy to inhibit BCC and SCC growth in vitro, and 20(OH)D3 mediated inhibition of skin carcinogenesis induced by UVB in the Ptch1+/-/SKH-1 mouse model. In addition, alternative nuclear receptors (NR), in addition to the vitamin D receptor, have been identified for (OH)nD3. This justifies continued preclinical testing of our CYP11A1-derived (OH)nD3 for inhibition of UVB-induced skin carcinogenesis and tumor growth, and to identify the specific NR pathway(s) activated by these different OH)nD3. The studies should define novel OH)nD3 s as therapeutic and chemopreventive agents against UVB-induced carcinogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project discovers a novel mitochondria-enriched miRNA, miR-128, is important to synchronize cellular and mitochondrial biological process during cardiac remodeling. This miRNA will be an important target to direct correct or circumvent mitochondria abnormality in dysfunctional cardiomyocytes that accompanies heart failure. This proposal incorporates epigenomic information to investigate underlying mechanism involved in aberrant miRNA activation during heart failure and provides proof of principle that enable precise engineering of transcription regulation in cardiovascular medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The family of RAS oncoproteins drive tumor growth and have been widely characterized in cancer; however, non-classical RAS proteins remain poorly studied despite their relevance in this disease. We have discovered a novel cellular mechanism that results in the degradation of the non-classical RAS oncoproteins RIT1 and MRAS and it is mediated by a complex that includes the protein LZTR1. Our work into this mechanism will lead to novel insights into the regulation of non-classical RAS oncoproteins, the relevance during tumor formation, and potential innovative therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deuterium metabolic imaging (DMI) is a novel 3D method to image metabolism of deuterium-labeled substrates in healthy or diseased human brain and has shown great clinical potential to detect aberrant metabolism in patients with high grade brain tumors. To establish the clinical value of DMI on larger patient populations and different neurological diseases, the method must migrate from dedicated (ultra)-high-field research MR scanners to the more commonly available clinical field strength of 3T. Successful development of the technical innovations in this proposal will guarantee an optimal implementation of DMI at 3T, thereby driving its further development and validation via use in larger, diverse patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Proton therapy allows superior tumor targeting and normal tissue sparing, and can potentially unleash the full potential of SBRT in liver tumor treatment. However, proton therapy delivery is greatly challenged by the intra-treatment liver tumor motion, especially for the increasingly popular and dominant pencil beam scanning (PBS) technique. This project fulfills the urgent unmet clinical needs of motion management in proton therapy, by developing the first dosimetry-guided and closed-loop system that combines simultaneous real- time imaging and on-the-fly plan adaptation, to deliver high-precision doses to moving tumors to improve liver disease care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Hypokalemic periodic paralysis (HypoPP) is a rare inherited disorder of skeletal muscle in which recurrent episodes of severe weakness, and the risk of progressive weakness with loss of ambulation, are caused by mutations of either calcium channel or sodium channel genes. Contemporary management of symptoms, with lifestyle changes or empirical usage of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, is inadequate with diminished quality of life and no effective means to prevent late-onset permanent muscle weakness. This project builds upon the insights from our 30 years of investigating pathomechanisms of HypoPP to the rational design and preclinical testing of new pharmacologic approaches to mitigate acute attacks and of gene therapies for a more durable management that may also prevent late onset myopathic weakness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Harnessing the activity of natural immunoregulatory molecules to treat chronic inflammation is an attractive strategy to address the limited effectiveness and deleterious side-effects of conventional anti-inflammatory drugs. The proposed research will develop a new anti-inflammatory therapy based on synthetic multivalent nanoassemblies of galectin-1 and galectin-3, carbohydrate-binding proteins that are natural regulators of inflammation. Combining galectin-1 and galectin-3 into a synthetic nanoassembly will address the biochemical features of wild-type galectins that have limited their therapeutic effectiveness to date, thereby leading to a potent new class of anti-inflammatory therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Engineering full organs that can functionally integrate with the body is a major challenge in regenerative medicine. In this study, we are developing methods to tissue engineer complex dental structures and discovering mechanisms driving their integration with healthy tissues, specifically investigating innervation and anatomical bone attachment. This study will lead to new effective dental therapies and translate to improving regeneration and integration of organ systems throughout the body.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study is relevant to public health because expanding access to colorectal cancer screening through pharmacies located in medically underserved communities will improve prevention and early detection of cancer. Supported by preliminary work demonstrating the acceptability, feasibility, and estimated effect of the PharmFIT intervention, this is the first trial to systematically evaluate pharmacy-based CRC screening using FITs in the US. Findings related to the impact, implementation, and cost of PharmFIT will generate new knowledge about interventions delivered by community pharmacists and contribute to NCI’s mission to fund research that will reduce cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury is a common cause of hospitalization, and when the kidney is unable to repair itself, this can result in chronic kidney dysfunction requiring lifelong morbidity, dialysis or even transplant. We have discovered a signaling pathway that promotes kidney repair and restores kidney function after acute kidney injury. This grant will explore how our newly discovered enzyme system regulates this signaling pathway and participates in kidney repair in mouse models, and then will correlate this with human clinical data from acute kidney injury patient samples. Finally, we will assess the efficacy of drugging this pathway in kidney repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Children requiring surgery for congenital heart disease are at an increased long-term risk for hypertension, chronic kidney disease and end-stage kidney disease. The proposed study will enroll 350 children and follow them annually to characterize the natural history and clinical profiles of hypertension and chronic kidney disease. The study aims to detect modifiable risk factors and identify novel methods for clinical diagnosis that can be used to inform consensus guidelines for blood pressure and kidney function follow-up after surgical repair of congenital heart disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Mutational processes that underlie human cancer leave mutational signatures identifiable by whole genome sequencing. Precision Oncology aims to target these underlying mutational processes. Seminal work by the Sanger Institute has identified mutational patterns, including single and doublet base pair substitutions, indels, and copy number alterations, and structural variants, that are indicative of defects in DNA replication and repair, mutagen exposures, and enzymatic modification of DNA. These mutational signatures could be prognostic or predictive. Determining if these mutational signatures predict treatment response in Veterans could provide expanded therapeutic indications for larger numbers of Veterans. At a fundamental level, whether the mutational signatures identified in civilian tumors are found in tumors from United States Veterans and whether novel signatures might develop due to war-time exposures is unknown. Identification of these novel mutational signatures may reveal new therapeutic targets and inform preventative measures to reduce exposure risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will enhance our understanding of smoking and cancer-related health disparities among sexual orientation and gender identity (SOGI) minority (e.g., lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender) adults in the United States. The limited knowledge base regarding the prevalence and how SOGI-specific state-level policies are associated with smoking disparities among SOGI minority adults has hindered the ability to address cancer-related outcomes and design more effective lung cancer screening, prevention, and intervention efforts. The integration of multiple data sets with common smoking, gender identity, and sexual orientation measures will allow our research team to examine innovative research questions related to SOGI- specific policy factors associated with smoking behaviors, low dose computed tomography lung cancer screening eligibility and use, and smoking-related health outcomes among adults that cannot be adequately addressed with one data set alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The research proposed in this application consists of a rigorous crossover study to determine whether glucocorticoid receptor antagonism attenuates behavioral and neuroendocrinological responses to experimentally induced stress in non-treatment-seeking patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD), the pharmacodynamic effects of alcohol (ALC), and drinking, craving and stress in the natural environment. The proposed study is innovative and important because it might spur the development of PT150 as an adjunct therapy for alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Autonomous programs of cell death are targetable vulnerabilities for cancer treatment. However, most programs of cell death are poorly understood and only active in specific contexts suggesting additional fruitful areas for cancer drug target discovery exist. In our project, we have identified a novel cell death mechanism controlled by the p53 tumor suppressor in small cell lung cancer that we aim to functionally characterize and develop strategies to exploit for therapeutic gain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: It is important to develop and implement more effective interventions for improving long-term weight loss. There is some evidence that mind-body interventions, specifically yoga, have the potential to contribute to improved weight loss; however, these interventions have not been extensively studied within the context of a comprehensive behavioral weight loss intervention. This study proposes to implement a novel intervention that combines yoga with a behavioral weight loss intervention to examine its effectiveness on potentially enhancing weight loss and other health outcomes in adults with overweight or obesity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Unique characteristics and service experiences of Veterans place them at an increased risk for sustained alcohol misuse. This excessive alcohol consumption positively correlates with hepatic disorders, including alcoholic hepatitis, a clinically challenging spectrum of alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD). Here, we propose to identify the mechanism by which alcohol consumption disrupts gut barrier integrity and gut dysbiosis to promote endotoxemia and the subsequent development of alcoholic hepatitis. Our project also seeks to identify the therapeutic benefit of administering betaine, a safe, bioavailable, highly soluble, and naturally occurring compound, in maintaining the integrity of the intestinal barrier, preserving the gut microbiome, and preventing liver inflammation. We hope this treatment option will ultimately prevent ALD progression and lessen the economic burden to the VA health care system.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will contribute fundamental knowledge about how state-level social policies that provide economic resources and supports for low-income and other socially disadvantaged groups of U.S. women during the childbearing years can intervene upon public health priority maternal mental health outcomes and disparities. Findings will cue policy makers to action and inform cross-sector “women’s health in all policies” approaches to reduce poverty, maternal morbidity and mortality, and promote maternal health equity across the reproductive life course and for generations of families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is a leading cause of vision loss, impacting an estimated 80 million individuals worldwide and incurring an annual healthcare cost of $6-8 billion. Lowering intraocular pressure is crucial for preventing and slowing the progression of glaucoma, but monitoring it continuously, especially during sleep, presents a challenge. This proposal aims to develop and optimize a unique platform of smart soft contact lenses that can provide continuous, 24-hour monitoring of intraocular pressure, prioritizing safety and high tolerance among the majority of glaucoma patients and those suspected to have the condition.
