IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Male factor infertility is responsible in as much as 50% of cases of couple infertility, and has been observed to represent an early life predictor of later life disease risk. Conventional semen parameter analysis remains the most prevalent diagnostic tool for assessing male fertility, but semen parameters – as proxies for true biological measures of sperm function – poorly predict male infertility and reproductive success. This proposed research builds on exciting preliminary data suggesting sperm mitochondrial DNA as novel biomarkers that directly measure sperm fitness and holds promise to improve our understanding of the etiology of male reproductive health and take a critical step toward developing interventions for male sub- and infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Anti-seizure medications are commonly prescribed to suppress seizures and seizure-like epileptiform electrical activity of the brain detected by electroencephalography (EEG) in patients with acute brain injury. While suppressing epileptiform electrical activity of the brain may minimize its harmful effects, anti-seizure medications have significant adverse effects and there is limited to no evidence on the risks vs. benefits of treatment. This project will use observational data from a multi-center EEG dataset of 46,000 patients to determine whether treatment of epileptiform electrical activity with anti-seizure medications improves mortality and functional outcomes, and to provide high quality evidence to guide clinical decisions in patients with acute brain injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  At present there exists a disconnect between the emerging diversity in interneuron cell types and its functional impact on cortical circuit organization. In the present grant we aim to demonstrate that there exists a presently unbeknownst selectivity of SST cINs for pyramidal and interneuron populations, such that cortical circuits are comprised of lock and key connections between specific subtypes. My proposal by coupling our expertise in studying the development of cortical interneurons, transcriptomics and both anatomical and optogenetic circuit cracking, promises to bridge this gap.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methods for sequencing newly transcribed RNA molecules, or “nascent” RNAs, have become widely used in the study of transcription, with broad implications for both basic biology and human disease. However, these methods produce complex data sets that are challenging to analyze, and limited software for analysis is available to the scientific community. We propose to develop a powerful new statistical and machine-learning framework, and a well-engineered open-source software implementation, that together will enable a wide variety of new and improved analyses of nascent RNA sequencing data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Stroke is a leading cause of death and disability worldwide but without effective therapy. We propose that the oxidative stress activated Ca2+-permeable TRPM2 orchestrates ischemia injury cascade by integrating multiple signaling pathways and various cell types at both local as well as systemic levels, and that TRPM2 can be an effective therapeutic target for ischemic stroke. We will use multidisciplinary approaches to delineate the mechanisms by which TRPM2 mediates ischemia injury, and how TRPM2 can be a multimodal target of a holistic therapeutic approach, and our results will provide novel insights into the role of TRPM2 in ischemic brain stroke and may ultimately prove that it is a better target for treatment of ischemic brain stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal aims to elucidate fundamental mechanisms by which control of fat metabolism is regulated during host-bacteria conflict through alternative splicing and expression of lipases that control endocannabinoid production and immune responses. The proteins and processes being investigated here are conserved in humans so the study will potentially open up avenues for non-antibiotic-based therapeutics for treatment of bacterial infections and inflammatory diseases. Hence, this project is highly relevant for human health and fits the NIH mandate of unraveling fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burden of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older Korean Americans, like other ethnic minority and immigrant older adults in the United States, are largely unserved by existing hearing care models. Community health worker-partnered models of hearing care that leverage over-the-counter hearing care and build local capacity, such as through faith-based organizations, are new, critical, and relevant to meeting the hearing care needs of rapidly increasing ethnic minority older adults such as Korean Americans. This first-in-kind, multidisciplinary proposal will build the evidence for a community health worker-partnered model of hearing care specifically designed for older adults and their communication partners with significant language and cultural barriers, strengthening a community-based model of hearing care that will benefit resource-poor ethnic minority older adults and their communication partners more broadly.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative: While animal embryos receive approximately equal amounts of DNA from each of their parents, nearly all of their cytoplasm is inherited from the female gamete. This cytoplasm contains information in the form of maternal proteins and mRNAs that are used by the embryo prior to “zygotic gene activation”, the point at which maternal mRNA is cleared and the embryo becomes reliant upon its own genome. We seek to understand how this maternal information is stored in the cytoplasm during oogenesis, then decoded after fertilization. We use C. elegans, a well-established genetically tractable invertebrate model organism, to study this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement  This project will studies a gene, CAVEOLIN1 that has been associated with a major blinding eye disease, glaucoma, and with the major risk factor for this disease, eye pressure. These current studies will define how this gene controls pressure in the eye and will also focus on the function of genetic variants that are linked to increased risk of developing glaucoma. The outcome of these studies will identify novel therapeutic mechanisms to lower eye pressure thereby reducing the risk of development and progression of glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stigma is an important social determinant of health among stigmatized adults, yet previous research has not comprehensively tested the impact of multiple forms of stigma on blood pressure, a strong predictor of future cardiovascular disease and mortality. Findings from this study will provide the best evidence to date on mechanisms by which anticipated and vicarious stigma influence blood pressure. This study is a critical step for identifying mechanistic targets for future interventions and policies to reduce the adverse effects of stigma on cardiovascular disease risk in stigmatized adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Narrative Worldwide, migraine headache is the most common neurological disorder and comes with great socioeconomic burden. Mast cells are a type of immune cell located in the thin covering of the brain, called the meninges, and have long been linked to migraine. In this proposal we plan on examining a receptor family, Mrgpr, specifically expressed on mast cells; and their role in linking neural and immune systems to migraine-induced pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Relevance Dry eye disease, ocular pain and ocular discomfort present significant challenges to our quality of life. There has been recent interest in therapeutics directly targeting the activity of ocular cold sensory neurons, due to their key involvement in eye physiology, dry eye disease and ocular discomfort. Our proposal aims to dissect the function and activation mechanisms of the cold and menthol receptor TRPM8, a critical thermosensitive component of ocular cold sensory neurons, which will set the stage for the development of novel drugs to combat dry eye disease and ocular pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Salmonella enterica serotypes are invasive enteric pathogens spread through fecal contamination of food and water sources and induce the disruption of intestinal barriers during infection and chronic inflammation. Vitamin D and the vitamin D receptor (VDR) are known to play a protective role in the pathogenesis of bacterial infection and digestive diseases. Our proposed studies are designed to investigate intestinal tight junctions regulated by the VDR and to develop novel therapeutic targets by enhancing function of intestinal VDR for alleviating bacterial infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) is an elegant lifesaving procedure for severely sick patients with heart valve diseases. TAVR is very safe, but in some TAVR patients their artificial heart valves degrade and fail, for reasons that are not known. This project will determine how blood cells become activated in TAVR patients in order to help develop better therapies for heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This project aims to understand how communication pathways between epidermal keratinocytes and melanocytes that promote the UV tanning response are hijacked in the developing melanoma niche to drive oncogenesis. A central player in keratinocyte:melanocyte communication is the keratinocyte adhesion molecule desmoglein 1, which is downregulated in response to UV or signals from transforming melanocytes and melanoma cells. We will test the idea that desmoglein 1's loss stimulates keratinocytes to produce extrinsic factors that inturn cause melanocytic cells toadopt new fates that drive tumor progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will quantify the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on the cognitive status of the older U.S. population and how the pandemic and attendant public health and social measures affected mortality and well- being among persons living with dementia and the older population in general. The project will use data on a large nationally representative sample and develop an enhanced model of cognitive status to estimate changes in ADRD trends before and following the COVID-19 pandemic in the population and in subpopulations. Our results will provide insights on the distribution of the medium- and longer-term burden of the pandemic on the older population and will aid with resource and policy planning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The heart-surrounding pericardium provides mechanical protection to the ever-beating heart and supports cardiac development, growth, and regeneration; yet, its development remains understudied. We use the zebrafish as our model to visualize, track, and analyze the earliest stages of pericardium formation and its molecular control. Insights into the mechanisms of pericardium development are critical to understand congenital heart anomalies and the in vitro generation of therapeutic cell types for cardiac regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Stroke and neurodegenerative disease affect hundreds of thousands of individuals each year, leading to profound losses of motor function and severe impairments in daily living. In order to restore or replace lost functions in afflicted individuals, it is necessary to understand — and leverage — the brain’s remarkable learning capacity. This project aims to understand the different kinds of cognitive strategies people employ when learning a novel sensorimotor skill, which could prove to be critical in guiding rehabilitation training protocols that help people transfer gains made in the clinic to the real world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our work has pioneered efforts to establish coagulation factor XI (FXI) as a safe and effective target to prevent thrombosis without increasing bleeding. Beyond activating FIX, we have identified mechanisms by which activated FXI promotes platelet activation, inflammation, and endothelial cell dysfunction, suggesting that the molecular steps of FXI activation and activity are ideal targets for the treatment and prevention of cardiovascular disease. Our work will provide mechanistic insights and preclinical proof-of-concept data for translating FXI inhibitors for use in thromboinflammation associated with hyperlipidemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary aims of this randomized, single-blinded, 2x2 sham-controlled trial are to 1) evaluate synergistic impact of 8-weeks of transcutaneous auricular vagus nerve stimulation (taVNS) + cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) on post-meal gut-brain communication; 2) determine the sequential relationship between treatment- associated changes in GI-related anxiety and both clinical functional dyspepsia (FD) improvements and meal- induced physiological outcomes; 3) investigate whether post-treatment changes in gut-brain physiology mediate improvements in FD clinical outcomes. Using our fully non-invasive framework including gastric and brain MRI and taVNS, we aim to evaluate the potential synergy of taVNS and CBT in FD, by assessing the gut-brain physiological response to prandial challenge, linking physiological with symptom improvements.

These results will directly inform breast screening guidelines to improve the health of transgender people who are too often invisible in national data collection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance. Pregnancy confers unique susceptibility to infection by Listeria monocytogenes and other pathogens that primarily reside inside cells, as a means to evade protection by antibodies. We recently showed deacetylation of glycosylated antibodies expands their protective scope to intracellular infection, and this application will further investigate how pregnancy-modified antibody protect against perinatal infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Many people, especially older adults, take multiple medications and are therefore at high risk for dangerous drug interactions—a major clinical and public health issue. Medications that act in the brain are very commonly used yet may cause serious side effects such as blood clotting or bleeding, especially in the setting of drug interactions. This study will generate real-world evidence about which drugs adversely interact with three major classes of medications that act in the brain (i.e., antipsychotics, benzodiazepines, and antidepressants) to cause venous thromboembolism or serious bleeding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adeno-associated virus (AAV) vectors have become the leading biologics in the clinical treatment of several monogenetic diseases but pre-existing immunities and toxicities at high doses limit their wide-spread utilization. In this project we will characterize the interactions of the AAV capsids with human antibodies, proteins of the innate immune system, receptors, and other intracellular proteins. This project will guide our capsid engineering efforts to overcome the challenges of the host immune responses and efficient gene transfer thereby improving clinical efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Photoreceptor cells utilize a prototypical G-protein signaling cascade, called phototransduction, to convey the presence of light. Genetic mutations and environmental factors that affect the performance of phototransduction cause many different forms of blinding diseases through mechanisms that are poorly understood. Investigation of these mechanisms will help in the design of treatment options for visual disorders arising from dysfunction of the phototransduction cascade.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to develop an improved therapeutic strategy for immune checkpoint inhibitor-resistant melanoma. Although immunotherapy with checkpoint inhibitors has revolutionized treatment for advanced melanoma, only 40-60% of patients experience lasting medical benefits from this therapy. Notably, Veterans have an increased risk of developing and dying of melanoma compared to the general population. Thus, identifying new mechanisms to target melanoma is critical to improve survival in Veterans with this disease. Inflammation has been demonstrated to influence melanoma growth and response to checkpoint inhibitors. However, no therapy developed to date is designed to target it. NLRP3 is a central driver of melanoma autoinflammation, making it an attractive target candidate. This project will evaluate how NLRP3 regulates melanoma response to checkpoint inhibitors and will explore its potential as therapeutical target.

PROJECT_TITLE: To Elucidate the Biological Function and Translational Potential of NLRP3 in Immunotherapy-resistant Melanoma
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Special Emphasis Panel[ZRD1 ONCE-A (01)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Failure of pancreatic β cells underlies the progression of all forms of diabetes. We investigate critical functions of the transcription factor and diabetes gene PDX1 through intra-molecular regulation of protein stability, and inter-molecular interactions regulating subcellular/subnuclear localization, in part through phase separation. The results from these studies will deepen our fundamental understanding of Pdx1 and help to design better strategies to generate and expand β cells in vitro and in vivo, with the potential to identify new nodes for intervention to prevent or delay the onset of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Personality disorders in youth are associated with profound personal and societal burden, but very little is known about the processes underlying personality impairment in youth, hindering efforts to identify effective interventions for this vulnerable population. For this prospective longitudinal study, a clinically diverse psychiatric outpatient sample of 160 early adolescent youth and 80 healthy comparison youth without a history of psychopathology (ages 10-13; 50% female) will be recruited to test neurophysiological alterations in social acceptance processing and self-referential processing as predictors of personality impairment over two years. Findings will guide the development of preventative efforts to mitigate the personal and societal burden associated with personality impairment within this sensitive developmental period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genicular artery embolization (GAE) is a new minimally invasive treatment option for the millions of patients suffering from osteoarthritis of the knee. While initial results for GAE are promising, there is potential for a large placebo effect with this therapy. The proposed pilot study will compare GAE to a sham procedure to help provide an initial understanding of any placebo effect and help us design a larger future study to prove GAE is an effective treatment for knee osteoarthritis.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because its overarching goal is to develop an effective therapy for one of the most debilitating manifestations of Parkinson’s disease: freezing of gait. The project is relevant to NIH’s mission because it aims to further the understanding of factors that underlie effective response to DBS in patients with freezing of gait in order to improve efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Meiosis is a cell division program that is essential for the formation of both eggs and sperm and therefore critically important for human reproductive health. Errors during meiosis are a leading cause of miscarriages, infertility and birth defects such as Down Syndrome in humans. This application will investigate the regulation of the synaptonemal complex, a structure required for promoting accurate meiotic chromosome segregation in most organisms from yeast to humans, thereby laying the foundation for the development of effective preventive strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Licensed flu vaccines suffer from loss of protection due to antigenic drift, lack of cross protection of zoonotic viruses, and poor immune responses in populations at greatest risk of complications from infection. We propose to develop a next generation flu vaccine that will provide broad and durable protection by chemically synthesizing compounds composed of cross-reactive T- and B-epitopes and an in-built immuno adjuvant. This research directly addresses goals in the NIAID strategic plan for developing a universal influenza vaccine and will provide candidate universal influenza vaccines as well as novel vaccine designs and adjuvants for other vaccine applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study aims to delineate the specific mechanism(s) by which TIP60-mediated acetylation stabilizes ΔNp63α levels and modulates the DNA damage response, apoptosis, therapeutic resistance and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) tumor progression using a combination of in vitro and in vivo models. This study is relevant to public health because it will provide (1) a mechanistic insight into the development of resistance to standard treatment modalities for SCC, (2) identify novel therapeutic targets in SCC with elevated TIP60 and ΔNp63α, and (3) assess the efficacy of TIP60 inhibition in sensitizing patient-derived (PDX) cisplatin-resistant head and neck SCC tumors to cisplatin and IR therapy. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission pertaining to the pursuit of fundamental knowledge to enhance health and reduce disability, and specifically to support of research into the mechanism of action of cancer therapeutic agents in both in vitro and in vivo model systems and the identification and validation of new druggable targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression affects half of those suffering from Parkinson's disease (PD) and is associated with reduced quality of life and accelerated disease progression, however, traditional antidepressants are ineffective in PD. We will combine PET and MR imaging to identify synaptic deficits and network alterations that are distinct to depression in PD, which could represent important new treatment targets. We will also examine the mechanistic effects of ketamine in PD for the first time – to establish its ability to target synaptic and network-level deficits, which could help pave the way for the use of ketamine and other synaptic-enhancing interventions as novel and effective treatments for depression in PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is one of the top ten leading causes of death in the United States, and results in over 700,000 preventable deaths per year worldwide, while the numbers who attempt suicide or have suicidal thoughts are many folds higher. All of these suicide outcomes are known to have strong genetic underpinnings, however, large gaps remain in our understanding of specific genetic or biological risk factors. This project will conduct a comprehensive investigation of the genetic risk factors for suicide attempt, death and ideation through worldwide collaboration, in the Suicide Working Group of the Psychiatric Genomics Consortium.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inherited disorder in which mutations in the phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) gene causes a buildup of the amino acid phenylalanine in the body and, as a result, a variety of serious medical problems. The most common PAH mutation identified in PKU patients, the R408W mutation, does not respond to a standard medical therapy. We seek to use two types of CRISPR gene editing technology, called base editing and prime editing, to directly and permanently correct the R408W mutation at the DNA level in the liver, a strategy that could potentially cure a large number of PKU patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project proposes to leverage large-scale sample collection that was conducted during an existing cluster- randomized trial in order to study the effects of azithromycin mass drug administration on antimicrobial resistance, including long-term effects, spillover effects to untreated groups, and co-selection of resistance in non-macrolide classes of antibiotics. The project will use phenotypic methods as well as metagenomic deep sequencing to characterize the nasopharyngeal and gut resistome and microbiome of target and non-target groups. The results of this work will contribute to decision-making by national and international policymakers involved in azithromycin mass administration for child survival and will enhance our understanding of the relationship between antibiotic use and emergence of community antimicrobial resistance.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Gastrointestinal problems are common during wars, and these exert significant adverse effects on the health of service members involved in warfare. Veterans returning home from the Iraq and Afghanistan have reported high rates of comorbidity between post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Studies have shown that repeated stress induces gastrointestinal symptoms, such as diarrhea, constipation, and dysregulation of the gut microorganism, confirming a potential link between stress and gastrointestinal symptoms. However, the underlying mechanism of stress-induced gastrointestinal dysfunction is not known. The enteric nervous system plays a major role in the regulation of gastrointestinal function and the proposed study is aimed at understanding the role of a membrane receptor called LPA1 in the enteric nervous system in stress- induced intestinal dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertension is the most prevalent risk for cardiovascular disease, diabetes, obesity, chronic kidney disease and obstructive sleep apnea and patients with “treatment-resistant hypertension,” defined by inability to achieve blood pressure control despite use of ≥3 antihypertensive drugs, are at particularly high risk of these adverse outcomes. We propose that treatment-resistant hypertension stems, at least in part, from gut dysbiosis and associated gut inflammation, neuroinflammation promoting autonomic nervous system activation, or both; and, that minocycline (an antibiotic with anti-inflammatory properties) can ameliorate these disorders. We aim to conduct a randomized clinical trial of minocycline versus placebo, to determine the extent to which these mechanisms contribute to the blood pressure-lowering effect of minocycline, and whether these mechanisms may differ in Black and White Americans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Clostridioides difficile is the leading cause of nosocomial diarrhea in the United States and an important source of morbidity and mortality among U.S. Military Veterans. C. difficile infection (CDI) can result in a spectrum of diseases that range from mild diarrhea to pseudomembranous colitis and can include life- threatening complications such as perforation of the colon, toxic megacolon, and sepsis. CDI pathology is associated with the action of one or more toxins: toxin A (TcdA), toxin B (TcdB), and the C. difficile transferase toxin (CDT). While TcdA and TcdB are considered the primary drivers of symptoms, multiple studies suggest that CDT increases the severity of CDI. The increasing prevalence of CDT containing clinical isolates and the potential for developing CDT as an effective vaccine antigen necessitate a deeper understanding of how CDT functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mechanisms by which cell-surface attachment factors function in cell binding, tropism, and virulence of arthropod-borne viruses are poorly understood. This project will elucidate in molecular detail how chikungunya virus (CHIKV) engages host glycosaminoglycans as attachment factors and define the contribution of specific glycan binding to CHIKV infectivity, dissemination, tropism, and disease outcomes. These studies will enhance an understanding of the structure-function relationships of CHIKV-glycosaminoglycan binding and may foster development of improved therapeutics targeting virus-glycosaminoglycan interactions to block infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Treatment, management, and prevention of cancer involves a series of decisions over time based on accruing patient information. This research will develop methods for the design and analysis of specialized clinical trials that are ideally suited to discovery and evaluation of overall strategies for cancer treatment, management, and prevention over an entire sequence of decisions, with the goal of identifying strategies that lead to the greatest expected patient beneﬁt.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE As the bladder fills, it must remain compliant enough to expand and store urine but stiff enough to expel urine when muscles contract to void. Surprisingly, the way in which we sense the need to void when the bladder is full is still poorly understood. The goal of this project is to understand how the structure of the bladder wall interacts with sensory nerves to create the feeling of fullness, which is imperative to understanding the pathology of bladder dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) and non-tuberculous mycobacterial diseases remain a global health emergency despite being curable and preventable. Current treatments are long, toxic and progressively ineffective with rising drug resistance and call for a specific focus on unexploited targets to develop new antibiotics. Lpd is a genetically validated target in Mtb and this application aims to explore Lpd tight binding inhibitors to identify features that can predict and improve their in vivo efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glial cells such as astrocytes and microglia are crucial for influencing neural circuit function including those that, like the amygdala, underlie responses to learned fear. However, upon repeated stress exposure, pro- inflammatory signaling is elevated in the amygdala, which dysregulates faithful assessments of environmental threats by glial cells and neurons. The goal of this proposal is to define how a candidate anti-inflammatory pathway driven by AREG+ microglia and EGFR+ astrocytes limits fear responses by suppressing the activation of the ETV1 transcription factor in astrocytes in the basolateral amygdala, which may uncover new therapeutic targets for neurologic disorders where aberrant activation of the amygdala is a hallmark.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nervous system interacts with the immune system and plays a crucial role in atopic dermatitis and other allergic skin diseases. The proposed research will investigate physiologic signals that induce itch and inflammation by acting on cutaneous nerves. The goal of this research is to understand how these signals mediate interactions between the nervous and immune systems and assess their potential as new drug targets for the treatment of itch and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young Asian Americans report an alarming rate of mental health problems—a major public health concern— due to acculturative and racial minority stresses, alongside the unprecedented surge in anti-Asian racism and bigotry provoked by the COVID-19 pandemic. This study will investigate how the intersections of culturally unique family process, racial experience and acculturative pressure impact young Asian Americans and their adjustments during transition from adolescence to young adulthood and pre and post COVID-19 pandemic. Results from the study will be used to develop comprehensive, evidence-based interventions to assist youths and young adults building the resilience to withstand adversities of acculturative and minority stress.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This proposal addresses a significant healthcare issue that affects Veterans, military personnel, and their families disproportionately to the general population. Here, work from Dr. Dhawan’s research program is focused on the investigation of mechanism/s and therapeutic targets in colon cancer progression and metastasis. Colon Cancer metastasis represent a major clinical challenge in the VA, since there are no current, effective therapeutic interventions, and metastatic colorectal cancer can result in therapy resistance and finally death. Work from her lab aims to provide a better understanding of mechanism/s of colon cancer progression and to increase opportunities for the development of novel treatment paradigms.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop a targeting strategy involving macrophage-targeting peptide ligands for targeted delivery of nanoplatforms that carry RNA therapeutics. Deploying existing or newly discovered peptides and deploying design rules from three broad classes of nanoparticles (lipid-based, tandem peptide-based, and mesoporous silicon-based) and it will identify an optimal nanoplatform to treat in vivo carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae (CRKP), Aspergillus fumigatus, and influenza A pneumonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a rare, progressive, and fatal neurodegenerative disease characterized by selective accumulation of α-synuclein in glial cytoplasmic inclusions (GCIs) within oligodendrocytes. We propose to use single nucleus RNA sequencing to understand how gene expression is perturbed in multiple cell types in the brain of MSA patients compared to healthy individuals. Uncovering these changes will allow us to understand the types of dysfunction that lead to neurodegeneration and identify their potential causes as possible therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Electrocardiographic (ECG) monitoring, in the hospital setting remains unsatisfactory as evidenced by the well- documented alarm fatigue problem, which threatens patient safety. Evidenced-based solutions, like the ventricular tachycardia algorithms we will create in this study, can only deliver benefits if transdisciplinary teams including nurses, physicians, engineers, data scientists, and software developers come together to create innovative solutions. Given the complexity of this substantial problem, it is vital that potential solutions have broad application in a variety of hospital settings and patient populations where ECG monitoring is utilized (i.e., ICU, step-down/telemetry).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative  Widespread genomic mosaicism in somatic cells of phenotypically normal individuals is now well established. We recently discovered a phenomenon of frequent hypermutability in adult brains (at least 3% of individuals over 40 years old). The origin(s) of the hypermutability is unknown and the goal of the proposed study is to firmly establish the origin(s). We have three hypotheses explaining hypermutability. Proving the hypothesized origins of hypermutability will be a fundamental contribution to understanding brain development and aging in humans and will lay the foundation for future studies of the underlying mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH

PHR: Project Narrative Emotional and cognitive impairments are prevalent in neuropsychiatric disorders such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). In particular, PTSD is characterized by a lasting inability to discriminate innocuous stimuli from ones that predict danger, and maladaptive coping strategies. Herein we propose studies using intersectional chemogenetics in mice in order to study brain pathways important for translational regulation of learned threat and to delineate molecular candidates for potential therapeutic intervention in PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using single-cell RNA-sequencing, we have identified that type II cytokine IL-13 receptor is expressed on enteric, DRG and Nodose ganglion neurons that innervate gut and lungs. Genetic deletion of IL-13R on the enteric sensory neurons inhibits worm expulsion and inhibits the production of neuropeptides like NMU and CGRP. Here we propose to study how these cytokine receptors expressed on neurons regulate development of the type II inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Suicide in youth is rapidly growing to where it is the second leading cause of death across the United States. Use of accessible tools have shown the potential to boost primary care providers’ detection of suicide risk and confidence and knowledge around addressing it; however, effective ways to address clinic and provider barriers that impact the sustained implementation of a pathway to manage at-risk patients remain underexplored. The proposed study will assess the impact of our Facilitated Suicide Prevention program-- which provides implementation support to assist practices in integrating screening, assessment, data analysis and management protocols into routine care through longitudinal feedback and coaching--on clinic adoption of a suicide prevention pathway and youth suicidality.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is a major public health problem among veterans. This application examines the mechanisms by which the pyruvate dehydrogenase kinase 4 (PDK4) and mitochondrial- associated ER membrane (MAM) mediates the pathogenesis of alcohol-induced liver injury. The results of our application have the potential to identify a new therapeutic approach for ALD by targeting PDK4.

PHR: Project Narrative Highly localized kinase signaling in brain learning/memory circuits is genetically dissected using separation of phases-based activity reporter of kinase (SPARK) biosensors for in vivo imaging. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The yeast Candida albicans is a normal resident of the human digestive tract and also one of the most common fungal pathogens of humans, causing both mucosal and systemic infections, particularly in immune compromised patients. This proposal seeks to understand how a deeply-conserved feature of Candida albicans—white-opaque switching—occurs in mechanistic terms and how it contributes to Candida’s ability to infect mammals. White-opaque switching enables two very different types of cells—each of which is stable through many rounds of cell division—to be produced from the same genome.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The ability to perform dynamic imaging of time-varying physiological processes in small animal models is critically needed to understand the progression of human disease and develop new therapies. This research will transform photoacoustic tomography into what has been promised for several decades—a quantitative imaging modality for dynamic functional and molecular imaging. The developed computational technologies will find widespread application in preclinical medicine and have immediate and sustained positive impact on preclinical science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences max) This project builds the CAMERA (Context-Aware Multimodal Ecological Research and Assessment) platform, which will fuse diverse data signals from a range of unobtrusive sensors to continuously predict transient internal states and level of cognitive function. This project will identify new features of human neural activity, physiology, behavior, and environment related to memory and anxiety (R61), and test whether we can use multimodal data to more accurately identify and modulate anxiety and memory performance states (R33). CAMERA will also open a pathway towards the use of multimodal data and machine learning for naturalistic research and translational studies related to other complex human internal states and behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Current diagnosis of diffuse gliomas necessitates a high-risk neurosurgical procedure for direct tissue acquisition, which offers limited information due to significant intra-tumoral spatial heterogeneity. The cerebrospinal fluid is in direct contact with the tumor and its microenvironment, which can be leveraged for identification of comprehensive proteogenomic signatures of both diagnosis and inform management. The work proposed here aims to develop and validate proteogenomic signatures for diffuse glioma diagnosis while also resolving challenges during patient follow-up, and establish the first-ever glycoproteomic profile in CSF of glioblastoma based on the largest prospective CSF cohort in diffuse gliomas to date, which will lead to a significant paradigm shift in their management.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed study will expand an existing longitudinal study (DZC-1), the first panel survey of reproductive lives in Brazil of any kind, to lengthen the observation interval of respondents by three years stands to generate one of the longest empirical records for examining the reproductive lives of a multiage (18- 34 in 2020) cohort of women (and their children) in response to highly consequential successive novel infectious disease crises. With established rapport with the community and instituted local survey capacity in an epicenter of Zika and Covid-19, our proposed approach advances critical knowledge on the extent to which Covid-19, and successive generalized epidemics, which have become increasingly common, are consequential to women's reproductive lives, including their young children's health. The findings promise to advance research and theory on successive novel infectious disease shocks by examining individual- and contextual-level effects on women's reproductive lives and trajectories, which can inform policy and outreach efforts to reduce unmet need for contraception and unintended fertility amidst major reproductive health crises.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to understand how chemical pollutants such as dioxins and aromatic hydrocarbons cause toxic effects. Such pollutants cause their toxic effects by activating a protein called the aryl hydrocarbon receptor, and we seek to understand how this protein communicates with other proteins and with DNA to cause toxic effects in the liver. Our results will improve our ability to predict how exposure to dioxins or related pollutants will affect human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative New technologies have the potential to transform interventions for speech sound disorder, a high-prevalence condition that negatively impacts social and academic participation, but there is a lack of rigorous evidence to substantiate this promise. This research will meet a public health need by systematically evaluating the efficacy of visual-acoustic biofeedback intervention delivered in-person versus via telepractice and assessing the potential for maintenance of treatment gains to be enhanced through home practice with artificial intelligence (AI)-mediated feedback. It will also test the hypothesis that the efficacy of intervention can be optimized when the choice of biofeedback technology is personalized to match the learner’s profile of sensory strengths and limitations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Type 3 transformation zone (TZ), which accounts for about 15% of women, impedes the effectiveness of cervical cancer screening with visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA), by limiting full visualization of the TZ. This study will evaluate the effectiveness of intravaginal misoprostol in converting Type 3 TZ (complete visualization of the TZ), reducing the likelihood of missed lesions. If successful, the results will be applied to cervical cancer screening programs in low-and-middle-income countries to improve the outcome of VIA when used as a standalone test or as a triage to HPV-DNA screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Cannabis is the third most commonly used substance in the United States and associated with physical harms, psychological harms, and other types of harms. The proposed study will use rigorous methods to examine an important population-level intervention that can increase risk perceptions, knowledge, and recall of cannabis- related harms—warning labels on cannabis packages. The expected outcomes of this project include comprehensive knowledge of cannabis warning regulations in the US, insights from state cannabis regulators, a set of evidence-based cannabis warnings, and information on whether large, evidence-based warnings increase risk perceptions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC) is the most common gastrointestinal emergency of premature infants with significant morbidity and mortality. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The objectives of this research are to characterize hippocampal and memory aging trajectories, and identify the combination of MRI measures that best predict accelerated memory decline in middle-age and older adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), compared to matched non-ASD. This is relevant to public health because findings will advance fundamental knowledge of brain aging vulnerabilities and mechanisms in ASD. Our long-term goal is identifying biomarkers and intervention targets for precision medicine care of aging autistic adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A national emergency in child mental health has been declared by multiple specialty organizations during the COVID-19 pandemic. While telehealth services have increased rapidly across the nation as promoted by government policy changes during the pandemic, no study to date has examined the extent to which state telehealth policy changes help address the national emergency and reduce disparities in child mental health care between mental health professional shortage areas and non-shortage areas. This proposed study aims to fill the gap through longitudinal analyses of comprehensive primary and secondary data.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A decrease in bone mass is one of the most common features of menopause (loss of estrogens), but the mechanisms responsible for this effect remain unknown. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Missing a liver lesion, or other subtle pathology, can have life-or-death consequences for patients. However, techniques that change CT images in a non-linear fashion are being commercially deployed based on simplistic assessments, such as noise reduction, rather than on maintenance of diagnostic performance. This work will provide the CT community tools to assess diagnostic performance for new CT imaging methods as they become available, facilitating optimization of dose reduction and ensuring safe clinical deployment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal aims to elucidate the physiological role and downstream effects of follicular fluid EV (ffEV) miRNAs on cumulus-oocyte complexes (COCs) in the domestic cat model. Building on our recent work in evaluating the roles of extracellular vesicles (EVs) in mediating gamete function and our experience in biomimetic/microfluidic cell culture systems, we will (1) determine the influence of gonadotropin stimulation regimes on EV production in vitro using a dynamic microfluidic system; and (2) specifically modulate (via inhibition or supplementation of miRNA mimics) EV miRNA cargo and assess the subsequent effects on vitrified oocyte developmental competence and downstream cell cycle pathways. These studies will generate new insight into the utility of ffEVs for future assisted reproduction applications, including oocyte vitrification, for human fertility preservation and genome rescue of valuable animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Unhealthy diets high in sugar and saturated fat (a “Western diet”) are commonly consumed by children and are associated with both obesity and cognitive impairments. The hippocampus is a brain region that regulates memory function and food intake control, and this region is particularly vulnerable to early life Western diet consumption. Here we investigate the biological and behavioral mechanisms through which early life consumption of a Western diet negatively affects memory function and feeding-related behaviors later in life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Genes encoding SWI/SNF complex subunits are mutated in over 20% of all human cancers, including the devastating childhood Rhabdoid Tumor. We have identified a gene that, when deleted, specifically kills rhabdoid cells. The proposed studies are designed to determine the normal function of this gene and the mechanisms by which its loss kills these cancers and, secondly, to explore novel approaches to circumvent therapeutic resistance in these aggressive cancers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as more than 80% of Americans do not meet physical activity levels associated with reduced cancer risk. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular pathways implicated in aging and longevity are under circadian regulation, and in turn, aging leads to circadian disruption and damped circadian gene expression. We hypothesize that age-related declines in circadian gene expression affect longevity pathways and health and therefore, interventions that can rescue circadian function may extend healthspan and lifespan. In addition, we have found that inflammation is a major contributor to aging and is rescued by circadian alignment of feeding under caloric restriction and so will test the candidate, Interleukin-1b, as a mediator of aging in a circadian context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While approximately 10% of human birth defects, including congenital heart defects, affect early neural crest development, the molecular mechanisms underlying these defects are largely unknown. The proposed experiments promise to illuminate the molecular and cellular processes that result in formation of the cardiac neural crest. The results of this study may inform upon diagnosis, therapeutic intervention and also yield approaches guiding maintenance of neural crest cells in the developing heart for the purpose of repair and regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Zika virus infections during pregnancy are linked to fetal mortality and morbidities often characterized by microcephaly and other congenital Zika syndrome developmental disorders, and this characteristic appears to be highly unique to Zika virus among flaviviruses. Here, we present preliminary evidence showing that spread of this virus at the maternal-fetal interface is linked to intercellular conduits known as tunneling nanotubes, which we show are induced in the placenta during ZIKV infection. We propose to investigate the relationship between the Zika virus and tunneling nanotubes in both cell and mouse models to establish a previously undescribed and important cellular mechanism for the vertical transmission of the virus that can be targeted for therapies that intervene with congenital Zika syndrome.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Disrupted sleep is a common and persistent symptom after traumatic brain injury, which can significantly complicate recovery. Chronic disturbances in sleep patterns may induce adverse changes in cognitive performance and over time lead to memory dysfunction. However, the mechanisms underlying cognitive deficits due to chronic sleep disruption following traumatic brain injury remain poorly understood. To improve quality of life in Service Members and Veterans with traumatic brain injury, an understanding of the varied mechanisms triggered by traumatic brain injury is required to prevent or optimally manage cognitive recovery over time post injury. Therefore, the goal of this project is to interrogate chronic sleep disruption and related cognitive deficits using a clinically relevant large animal model of traumatic brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cherenkov Excited Luminescence Molecular Sensing (CELMS) was invented to probe molecular tracers of tumor metabolism in vivo, utilizing a linear accelerator (Linac) as the x-ray source with a high-resolution, steerable beam. This renewal period will develop a translatable version of the technology that can work with any Linac, through key steps in low cost hardware, open source software, unique metabolic probes, and comparisons in large animal imaging for radiobiology applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide fundamental knowledge about a brain region involved in psychiatric disorders, including depression and addiction. Upon conclusion, we will understand the role of excitation/inhibition balance in activity regulation of the lateral habenula. This discovery will stimulate new therapeutic avenues directed at restoring excitation/inhibition balance in psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The microorganisms that normally inhabit the human gut, known as the microbiome, have recently been connected to successful treatment with immunotherapies. The objective of this project is to identify mechanisms of microbiome:immune cell crosstalk that can be modified to improve clinical outcomes for cancer patients. In this project we will determine whether mucosal-associated invariant T cells (MAITs), which recognize vitamin metabolite antigens produced by the microbiome, are one potential connection between the microbiome and responses to immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In a murine model of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, TY4, a novel synthetic RNA bioinspired by the contents of extracellular vesicles, exerts profound disease-modifying bioactivity. Here, we seek to understand the mechanisms of gene expression changes and anti-fibrotic effects in the heart. Discoveries made here will provide valuable insights for future development of anti-fibrotic agents for a variety of heart diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: NARRATIVE With the growing global epidemic of obesity, a greater understanding of the link between obesity and colorectal cancer outcomes is an important clinical challenge to address. Using innovative, state-of the-art methods, this study will identify the specific components of adipose tissue distribution and muscle mass that predict colorectal cancer treatment tolerance and survival. By applying a parallel comprehensive assessment of platelet activation, and related biomarkers in the blood, urine, and tumor, we will test, for the first time, the role of thromboinflammation in promoting colorectal cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are proposing a population-based study of cerebral palsy (CP) in California to investigate whether fetal exposure to multiple widespread environmental contaminants that may affect hormones in pregnancy contributes to congenital CP. We will also examine the role of maternal thyroid function in CP etiology and utilize a high- resolution untargeted metabolomics approach to elucidate exposure-disease mechanisms. public involved This project has high health relevance since i t will accelerate the generation of knowledge concerning biological mechanisms in CP etiology, inform environmental health policy, and possibly advance the primary prevention of CP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will take an important first step in the study of phage therapy for treatment of recurrent urinary tract infection (rUTI) in female kidney transplant recipients (KTR); a common condition that is associated with increasing multidrug resistance, sickness, loss of kidney function and death. The investigators will conduct a randomized phase I/II pilot clinical trial of targeted phage therapy versus placebo in asymptomatic female KTR with a history of rUTI due to Escherichia coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae to assess safety, tolerability, and feasibility of this approach, possible efficacy, and changes in the gut and urinary microbiome during the 180 days of the study. This highly innovative and impactful proposal will provide proof of concept data and also inform the design of a subsequent larger phase III clinical trial of phage therapy for rUTI treatment in KTR and will have broad downstream effects within the fields of infectious diseases and transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The overall goal of this project is to develop a new platform for the precision delivery of targeted radiotherapies to tumors. Over three specific aims, we will evaluate if proteolytically activated membrane binding peptides can be leveraged to deliver a more substantial dose of ionizing radiation to tumors than conventional radioligand therapies. In parallel, a lead drug candidate conjugated to copper-64 will be translated into cancer patients to assess safety, dosimetry, and pharmacokinetics, as well as the feasibility of tumor targeting using PET.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasma cells are an essential component of the humoral immune response against infections with pathogens such as influenza by secreting large amounts of neutralizing antibodies. The development of plasma cells is known to be regulated by a network of transcription factors, but the contribution of ion channels and their associated signaling pathways is not understood, which is a missed opportunity from a basic science and translational perspective because ion channels are excellent drug targets as demonstrated by the many drugs modulating ion channel function in the context of cardiovascular and neuropsychiatric diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atopic dermatitis (AD) and food allergy are among the most common chronic diseases of early childhood. These diseases often occur in the same individuals and many times lead to the development of hay fever and asthma, in a poorly understood process termed the allergic march. In this project we will investigate whether early-life barrier and immune abnormalities of the skin result in not only AD, but affect the overall immune system, leading to the allergic march.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The aim of the proposed research project is to determine how Breakpoint Cluster Region (Bcr) protein regulates the process in vascular endothelial cells to influence atherosclerosis, angiogenesis and peripheral insulin sensitivity, using newly generated mouse models. We anticipate that the new knowledge gained will deepen our understanding of vascular biology through investigation of a novel, previously unappreciated role of Bcr and its adaptor protein PDZK1. Considering the staggering impact of cardiovascular diseases and metabolic syndrome, the goal of the research project is in line with the objectives of the National Institute of Health to address these disorders through medical research.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will reveal novel mechanisms underlying the regulation of pre-mRNA splicing in brain development. It will have significant impacts on the field of RNA biology and neurodevelopment. Because pre- mRNA splicing is a fundamental cellular process that is often mis-regulated in human diseases, the molecular mechanisms revealed in this study will have broad implications for translational medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glutamine metabolism provides αKG and glutathione to regulate early and late stages of osteoblast differentiation, although the precise role of these two metabolites during physiological bone formation is not well understood. Data generated by this proposal will: 1) establish the necessity of Glutamate Oxaloacetate Transaminase 2 (GOT2) dependent αKG synthesis, 2) define the contribution of αKG to osteoblast energetics and metabolism, 3) define the regulation of RUNX2 by reactive oxygen species, and 4) establish the therapeutic feasibility of antioxidants to protect RUNX2 and stimulate bone formation patients with cleidocranial dysplasia. Our findings will have broad implications in bone development and the maintenance and regeneration of bone mass.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain is one of the common organs for breast cancer recurrence. With rising incidence, breast cancer brain metastasis has become a major problem in clinic. Metastasis is a multi-step process that requires the complex interplay between cancer cells and the stromal cells. In this proposal, we focus on how type I interferon response in astrocytes, the unique stromal cells in the brain microenvironment, facilitates breast cancer brain metastasis. If we define microenvironmental changes during brain metastasis, we can yield real and actionable targets on the brain, instead of on cancer cells, to provide more effective therapies for brain metastasis patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bone marrow (BM) mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) are rare non-hematopoietic perivascular stromal cells which regulate hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) function by secreting high levels of niche factors such as Vascular Cell Adhesion Molecule-1 (VCAM1). While the specific role of MSC-derived VCAM1 on HSC and MSC maintenance remains unknown, our supporting data indicates that MSCs are the BM’s main source of Vcam1 and suggests that VCAM1 is critical for the maintenance, survival, and function of MSCs. Here, we will use rigorous genetic models, and technically innovative experimental approaches to elucidate the mechanisms by which VCAM1 promotes MSC survival and regulates HSC and progenitor function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, a fetal overgrowth syndrome with a mortality rate of 21 percent, exhibits an increased prevalence in children conceived by in vitro fertilization, and about 70 percent of cases of Beckwith- Wiedemann syndrome are due to dysregulation of the long non-coding RNA Kcnq1ot1. My project aims to elucidate the mechanism of Kcnq1ot1, and further our understanding of how defects in long non-coding RNA function result in diseases like Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Successful completion of this project will result in a foundation of knowledge that could eventually lead to the optimization of in vitro fertilization and may reveal strategies to attenuate the epigenetic activity of Kcnq1ot1, therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes can lead to complications like diabetic foot ulcers, which are nonhealing and may lead to morbidity and death. How small metabolites are utilized in normal wounds and altered in diabetic wounds remains understudied. By investigating metabolite utilization spatiotemporally and by host cells, this study aims to understand how alterations in metabolic usage contribute to delayed wound healing in diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop machine learning models that predict a wide range of clinical, histological, and molecular outcomes directly from histopathology images. Importantly, we will connect biomedical research and clinical efforts through the identification of enriched regulatory pathways responsible for worsening cancer outcomes. Ultimately, such efforts would augment clinical practice by giving pathologists additional diagnostic tools and molecular pathway information not previously available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease where the follistatin (FST) pathway has emerged as a potential mechanism impacting T2D pathophysiology, but the context-specific T2D regulation remains unclear. I will investigate genetic regulators of gene expression and chromatin structure within mesenchymal stem cells in basal and stimulatory states to elucidate genetic regulators of the FST pathway. This study will contribute to a multimodal understanding of T2D with the goal of informing future treatments.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This CDA-1 project will examine the extent to which reactive aggression acts as a suicide risk factor among Veterans and test the acceptability and utility of a multimethod assessment of reactive aggression. Reactive aggression is a robust suicide risk factor among civilians, but is understudied in Veterans. Four factors limit the minimal existing research among Veterans: 1) conflation of reactive and proactive aggression; 2) use of samples underpowered to predict suicide behavior; 3) overreliance on self-report measures of aggression; and 4) inattention to Veteran cultural factors. Dr. Krauss addresses each of these limitations in the current proposal while examining the extent to which reactive aggression predicts suicide behaviors in a parent study specifically powered to predict suicide behaviors. Findings from this proposal could identify reactive aggression as a potent, modifiable risk factor for Veteran suicide, which would greatly enhance VA’s current suicide prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A complex community of microbes, known as the microbiota or microbiome, lives within our distal digestive tract and is intimately connected to human health. Diet has a major impact on the gut microbiota and different components of diet can positively or negatively impact human health via the microbiota. This project defines how specific molecular components of fermented foods impact the human gut microbiota, provide desired changes to the immune system, and prevent food allergy using a mouse model of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The pathology associated with Alzheimer’s disease (AD), β-amyloid plaques and tau neurofibrillary tangles, is frequently seen in older people with normal cognition. By measuring this pathology during life with PET scanning, it has become clear that these processes cause some individuals to show memory decline over time, while others do not. This project will investigate several possible factors that are associated with successful aging outcomes: that is, preservation of cognitive function despite the occurrence of AD pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Infections, including influenza, have been linked to pediatric hydrocephalus; however, pathological progression resulting in ventricle expansion and altered brain development has not been clearly defined. The proposed project is to examine the impact post- infectious hydrocephalus has on the lateral ventricular system stem cell niche. A particular emphasis will be placed on the critical functions of ependymogenesis, neurogenesis and the capacity for regenerative repair following infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cell migration is a critical step in the metastatic spread of cancerous cells from a primary tumor to distant organs in the body. To date, the vast majority of cell migration assays are carried out in medium with a viscosity close to that of water (0.77 cP), whereas the viscosity of the interstitial fluids and blood in the human body is much larger. We will herein employ state-of-the-art bioengineering and imaging tools, quantitative analysis and in vivo models, to understand how breast cancer cells sense and respond to physiological extracellular viscosities in an effort to identify novel therapeutic targets to reduce breast cancer metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients that require mechanical ventilation in the emergency department (ED) either die or have long term disability if they survive. ED clinicians commonly administer sedative and paralytic medications to facilitate endotracheal intubation (i.e. placement of a breathing tube), and to care for patients after mechanical ventilation has been initiated; however, our findings suggest that these practices increase the rate of awareness with paralysis, a dreaded complication whereby patients have memories of wakeful paralysis. By studying awareness with paralysis, post-traumatic stress disorder, and patient-centered experiences among survivors of acute respiratory failure, this project will have important implications for how mechanically ventilated ED patients are treated worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our work shows that the majority of patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), the leading indication for lung transplantation, have short telomeres. Our studies have also shown that patients with short telomeres have impaired T cell immunity leading to increased susceptibility to complications from Cytomegalovirus and other viral infections, but continue to be at similar risk for chronic rejection (chronic lung allograft dysfunction; CLAD). Our proposal studies how telomere genetics impact immune mechanisms that drive these outcomes and will leverage the largest lung transplant cohort (LTOG) to evaluate outcomes, leading to new insights that will significantly advance the field of lung transplantation. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project is relevant to public health because the Drosophila neural stem cell lineages we study are essentially the same type of lineage as human outer radial glial (oRG) progenitors. This pool of human progenitors is proposed to generate the massive cortical expansion in most primates, yet working with human progenitors has limitations. Our system provides a gene and mechanism discovery system which will allow tightly focused hypotheses for the role of human oRGs in generating cortical neural diversity in development or disease. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH's mission to reduce the burden to society arising from prevalent environmental and genetic brain disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Long-chain fatty acid oxidation disorders are identified at birth through newborn screening. They are currently treated using medium-chain fatty acids to bypass the enzymatic defects and provide energy, but this therapy is only partially effective in heart and not effective in muscle. The proposed research seeks to optimize the type of medium-chain lipid and the route of administration in order to better treat muscle and heart.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinicians caring for critically ill children routinely struggle to harmonize the tension between giving too much versus too little sedation-analgesia. This work will (1) identify patterns of sedation-analgesia associated with outcome; (2) identify genotypes associated with sedation-analgesia administration; (3) characterize PK parameters of common sedative-analgesic mediations; and (4) promote the development of the PI as an independent Learning Health System researcher. The aggregate results of this work will inform development of a predictive model for sedation-analgesia dose response for critically ill children that will be the focus of future, prospective investigations

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Africa, the birthplace of modern humans, is the single most informative continent for understanding the human genome and human disorders with worldwide impact. Since most genomic research has not involved African populations, generations of human genetic history are missing from our understanding of human genetics and complex disease. In this study, we will use novel whole genome sequencing strategies to characterize the genetic bases of schizophrenia in the Xhosa population of South Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: There is currently no effective treatment for motor neuron disorders like amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and spinal muscular atrophy, in part due to a lack of understanding of the molecular mechanisms that enable distinct motor neuron subtypes to acquire and maintain their unique functional features. This proposal aims to test the hypothesis that motor neuron subtype-specific functional features, such as expression of ion channels and neurotransmitter receptors, are induced during development and maintained throughout life through the activity of highly conserved proteins of the Collier/Olf/Ebf and Hox family of transcription factors. Completion of the proposed experiments may provide novel entry points into the etiology, diagnosis, or treatment of motor neuron disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The selective infiltration of immunosuppressive myeloid cells is a hallmark of malignant brain tumors, and represents a major hurdle to effective immunotherapy. Our preliminary data suggest that tumor-associated myeloid cells (TAMCs) utilize two different metabolic pathways to consume arginine which has the potential to be targeted to prevent immunosuppression. This proposal seeks to dissect the unique metabolic pathways of TAMCs and target them in a clinically relevant manner to promote immunotherapy for glioma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most youth who experience significant trauma-related symptoms do not receive indicated services and, when they do, the services received are not evidence-based. The current project aims to simultaneously test the effectiveness of Trauma-Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT) for students in schools and the impact of The Beliefs and Attitudes for Successful Implementation in Schools (BASIS) strategy on clinician use of TF-CBT. If effective, TF-CBT and BASIS represent robust and generalizable strategies for greatly enhancing the accessibility and quality of services for trauma-exposed youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute and chronic lung diseases such as the acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) result from injury to the alveolar epithelium with ineffectual regeneration. Unfortunately, effective therapies are limited, in large part because our understanding of disease pathogenesis is incomplete. By dissecting mechanisms underlying alveolar homeostasis and normal regeneration, and how these go awry in disease pathogenesis, the proposed work will fill fundamental gaps in our knowledge and overcome critical barriers to the development of novel therapies for ARDS and IPF.
