IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project has major public health relevance because diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) remain one of the most common complications of diabetes and are the leading cause of lower extremity amputations in the US. Current treatments are ineffective and given the recent surge in major lower extremity amputations in patients with diabetes despite the previous decades of decline, identification of novel treatment avenues is of critical importance. The main objectives of the Diabetic Foot Clinical Research Unit at the University of Michigan are to expand the work and activities initiated during the first DFC cycle by integrating the robust DFC infrastructure we built at Michigan with the highly skilled clinical and translational research team to: finalize the ongoing DFU biomarkers protocols, implement the DFC master protocol and its various substudies, continue our high recruitment performance across all biomarker studies, recruit, train and supervise satellite sub sites, develop new methods to stimulate participants engagement, collect all data sets from large and standardized clinical samples collections, phenotyping, genomic, molecular and microbiome analyses from DFUs samples, and wound image analyses, to patient reported outcomes and social determinants of health, analyze how DFU recommended standards of care are implemented into usual care to facilitate evolution of clinical practice, and participate in biomarker validation analyses and any new wound healing projects undertaken by the Consortium through active and effective participation in its self-governing committees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The role of RB1 loss in bladder cancer progression, differentiation and cancer cell plasticity remains unknown. A major obstacle in translational bladder cancer research is the lack of genetically engineered mouse models that recapitulate aggressive muscle invasive bladder cancer in humans, that makes it difficult to rigorously study in vivo responses to systemic treatment. The proposed research will utilize novel mouse models to elucidate the role of RB1 loss in tumor progression, differentiation, plasticity and resulting clinical therapeutic implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Scleroderma is a complex rheumatic disease with significant variability in clinical presentation, disease course, response to therapy and prognosis. This proposal will develop methods to identify patients at risk of progression who may benefit from earlier and more intensive disease monitoring and therapeutic strategies. This includes approaches to generate personalized risk estimates of major complications from multivariate longitudinal data, display predicted risk estimates in a clinical setting to test their impact on future medical decision making, and utilize phenotypic trajectories as a platform for biomarker discovery to further improve risk stratification in scleroderma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is an extreme immune response of the body to severe infection and can frequently be fatal. Even though sepsis often results in low blood counts, including anemia, blood transfusion is not usually beneficial to these patients. In this project, we use human blood samples and mouse models to study how vital oxygen-carrying red blood cells change unfavorably in sepsis, and we test the ability of available methods to increase the ability of transfused blood to improve survival and other outcomes in patients with sepsis and anemia.

PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain is a major health crisis for millions of Americans in part due to ineffective treatments with significant side effects. We have assembled a team of highly experienced researchers to solve this difficult problem and advance these new compounds toward clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating and fatal disorder with no cure and few effective treatment options. We will develop a gene therapy for ALS by engineering an RNA-targeting CRISPR-based technology to silence the production of mutant forms of superoxide dismutase 1, a protein responsible for ~20% of all inherited cases of ALS. Thus, by harnessing an innovative technology for transcriptional engineering that can overcome the limitations of traditional methods for gene silencing, we will develop a new, permanently effective therapy for SOD1-linked familial ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is one the leading causes of mortality and morbidity affecting humanity, and a recognized risk factor for late-life neurodegenerative disorders. The absence of validated biomarkers in the neurotrauma field is a barrier to drug development in this area, and there are currently no disease-modifying therapies that limit the burden of TBI. This proposal addresses this gap by aiming to validate serum neurofilament light (NF-L) a biomarker of TAI which can be useful in early-phase clinical trials of therapies aimed at improving axonal resilience and regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative 16p11.2 copy number variations (CNVs) are highly associated with autism and schizophrenia. In this collaborative study, we will utilize the complementary expertise of two laboratories to model these CNVs in 2- and 3-dimensional cultures of human cortical neurons. We will investigate the development and the metabolomics of excitatory and inhibitory networks as well the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying the effect of 16p11.2 deletion and duplication on neuronal development and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative Caring for an ever aging society represents an increasing social and economical burden and continuing efforts are required to improve health during the course of life. Getting old increases the chances of succumbing to devastating diseases including cancer, and dementias such as Alzheimer’s disease and Parkinson affecting millions of people in the US. These diseases are caused by an increase of damaged and non-functional proteins at old age. We have established an animal model to address the role of decreased pH in the organelles responsible for the degradation of proteins in the fruitfly Drosophila. We are thus in a position to find out how an increase in toxic proteins leads to neurodegeneration in a fly model of Parkinson with the ultimate goal to identify novel treatment options to improve life at old age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: PACIFIC INSTITUTE FOR RES AND EVALUATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will provide important information about local policies and programs that can reduce discrimination and alcohol inequities among sexual and gender minorities (SGMs) and SGM subgroups. Identifying local modifiable structural conditions that contribute to SGM health can better inform the development of effective programs and policies to reduce alcohol inequities for SGM populations because (1) local structural conditions may be more immediate and therefore more important for people's day-to-day experiences and (2) local policies might be easier to implement than national or state-wide policies. Also, by understanding how the three levels of stigma operate together to affect alcohol use and problems, results can inform stigma-reduction interventions in healthcare settings and SGM organizations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed work is to substantially enhance the function of electronic retinal implants for treating incurable blindness. We use electrical recordings and stimulation of the isolated macaque and human retina as an experimental lab prototype for this future device, and use it to develop ways to efficiently interface with the neural circuitry of the retina and provide it with high-fidelity artificial visual signals. This research will advance the design of the next generation of retinal implants, to support advanced visual functions such as object recognition and navigation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Statement Our objective is to develop tools that improve early diagnosis of systemic light-chain (AL) amyloidosis, a disease that causes heart and kidney failure and early death, in patients with smoldering multiple myeloma, a disease in which patients make immunoglobulin free light chains but are relatively asymptomatic. By studying patients with smoldering myeloma and analyzing their light chain levels, the genes in their myeloma cells and a certain heart-related protein we will be able to establish the likelihood that they have or will get AL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mental fatigue—a feeling of exhaustion often accompanied by the sense that every task requires great effort—is prevalent in many neurological and psychiatric diseases. In healthy subjects, it is a common symptom ensuing after extended wake or intense learning. However, the reasons why we become mentally tired remain unknown. Based on recent findings, we hypothesize that a key mechanism underlying mental fatigue after sleep deprivation or intense learning is the increasing occurrence of brief, local periods of silence of brain cells. These “OFF periods” normally occur throughout the brain during sleep, but they can occur locally in wake (“local sleep” in wake) when we stay up for too long or engage in intense tasks. This project is relevant to public health because it will provide a mechanistic explanation of mental fatigue and its negative consequences. If successful, the proposed experiments will identify 1) a specific circuit of inhibitory and excitatory cortical neurons responsible for mental fatigue after extended wake or intense learning; 2) a neural mechanism underlying mental fatigue—the active induction of periods of silence in cortical neurons during wake. This project will also result in a large dataset of electrophysiological recordings from multiple areas of the brain. This dataset can be used in future studies to test whether, due to inflammatory or neuromodulatory changes, the neural circuit responsible for mental fatigue after extended wake or intense learning is also involved in pathological fatigue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to characterize an emerging tumor suppressor ATF3 for its roles in regulating cells’ ability to repair DNA damage. Successful completion of the proposed research will culminate in a better understanding of how cells defend themselves from DNA damage and malignant transformation, and ultimately lead to the development of novel anti-cancer therapies. This study will also have a potential to identify biomarkers for predicting patient responses to radiation therapy and thus lead to improved treatment outcomes that would benefit millions of people suffering from cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Synthetic organic chemistry is a rate-determining factor in the production and discovery of small-molecule pharmaceuticals; thus, continued innovation in synthetic methodology is of vital importance for developing the next generation of medicines for improved human health. The aim of this proposed research is to synthesize and characterize novel late-transition-metal-oxo complexes and harness their reactivity for the selective catalytic oxidation of sterically unhindered methyl groups on complex molecules. The results of these studies are expected provide a valuable tool for synthetic chemists to prepare and derivatize complex bioactive molecules for drug discovery efforts and validate the utility of late-transition-metal-oxo complexes for the oxidation of strong C–H bonds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Overall-Narrative The health-disease continuum is a process through various states of health and disease (such as heart disease, diabetes, cancer, and Alzheimer’s) and can fluctuate throughout life. While chronic diseases can be treated, an understanding of genetic susceptibility and molecular mechanisms involved in disease onset has the potential to halt progression and return an individual to a healthy state. The proposed Molecular Center of Health and Disease, through a Phase I COBRE, seeks to apply innovative molecular technology and computational biology to enhance research, discovery, and innovation in understanding the health-disease continuum and lead to better interventions to improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Malformations of brain development lead to mental retardation, epilepsy, neurological deficiencies and life-long learning, cognitive and motor disabilities. The experiments proposed in this grant will greatly contribute to understanding how brain growth is regulated through the comprehensive analysis of the molecular mechanisms controlling neuronal differentiation during brain development. Completion of the experiments described in this application will lead to a better understanding of brain disorders such as microcephaly and will allow us to better diagnose, predict and possibly envision future avenues for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our overarching goals are to develop statistical methods for the analysis of imaging acquired on multiple scanners for the study of multiple sclerosis (MS). We will develop and validate statistical methods for identifying individual lesions and quantifying the central vein in MS lesions for improved MS diagnostics as well as techniques for automatically identifying lesion phenotypes in a novel coordinate system. Finally, we will develop methods that allow for the study of patterns of neuropathological change across an image to study diffuse changes in the normal-appearing white and gray matter of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The public health relevance of our study is two-fold: 1) Premature aging and lower healthy life expectancy disproportionately affect people in resource-limited environments; and 2) We assess the roles of a modifiable risk factor (nutritional supplementation) in early life, which could represent actionable changes to improve DNA- related mechanistic pathways closely linked with physiologic aging. Our expected findings could shed light on novel nutrition-sensitive biomarkers of physiologic aging that persistent reflect the early-life exposome into adulthood, leading to improved prevention of premature aging and related consequences over the life course.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Individuals with profound anemia, particularly sickle cell anemia (SCA), have a high risk of developing strokes and silent cerebral infarcts; this risk begins in early childhood, with more than 50% affected by 30 years of age. Better understanding stroke mechanisms in anemia should improve stroke risk identification, and lead to better treatments to prevent stroke. This study uses multiple hemodynamic and metabolic brain imaging techniques to understand differences in brain blood flow and oxygen use before versus after anemia treatments, as well as how brain blood flow and oxygen utilization differ in anemic individuals with versus without strokes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Stroke is the leading cause of adult disability in the United States and, outside of physical therapy, no treatments exist to improve recovery of stroke patients. The research proposed in this application seeks to substantially improve our understanding of the way brain circuits and networks repair themselves after stroke. Unmasking these basic mechanisms of stroke recovery could facilitate the development of novel treatments to enhance recovery, reduce disability, and improve the lives of stroke survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing difficulties with age may be due to the progressive loss of nerve connections in the inner ear, but this loss does not show up in current clinical tests. The proposed study will integrate research in humans and animals with human-like hearing to develop new diagnostic tests for this ‘hidden’ hearing loss. The completion of this study could lead to novel diagnostic tests that can be used to detect this loss of inner ear nerve connections in the clinic, all while setting up a research pipeline to develop future diagnostics and test therapies for various forms of hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Deaf and hard-of-hearing (DHH) scientists constitute a severely underrepresented group in the nation’s biomedical research workforce. The proposed RIT U-RISE Scientists-in-Training Program for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Undergraduates will implement an undergraduate research-intensive training program to prepare DHH baccalaureate students in this linguistic and cultural minority for admission into doctoral programs in biomedically related research disciplines. RIT U-RISE will reduce the underrepresentation of DHH scientists in the nation’s biomedical research workforce and, in turn, promote research to reduce the corresponding disparities in DHH people’s health and healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to determine whether the retroelement LINE1 activates the immune system in a way that contributes to autoimmunity in Sjögren’s Syndrome. This work could help explain how dysregulated immune surveillance of endogenous genetic material could promote autoimmunity in some people. Completion of this work may help direct study of new targeted therapies for Sjögren’s Syndrome and related rheumatic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative California State University, Dominguez Hills (CSUDH), a public 4-year, Hispanic- and Minority-serving institution, home to a diverse community of learners and educators, will offer a well-structured U-RISE program that will provide personalized guidance, organization, and support for its scholars by “meeting each student where they are” through individual student-centric approach. The proposed program leverages previous successes of various NIH-funded programs at CSUDH and draws upon relevant current academic interventions in the literature to enable a personalized, well-structured training plan. In alignment with the overall goal of the NIGMS U-RISE nationwide program, the proposed U-RISE program at CSUDH will empower a diverse pool of undergraduates to first complete their bachelor’s degree, then transition into—and, finally, complete—research- focused advanced degree programs in the biomedical sciences to become successful biomedical scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease remains a leading cause of disability and death in the USA, often necessitating surgical correction via the use of vascular grafts. We and others have designed and tested myriad tissue engineered vascular grafts based on experience gained incrementally in animal models, first in mice then in larger animals, but it has taken decades to reach FDA-approval of the first such grafts. We submit that there is a pressing need to accelerate this process and that our proposed novel computational-experimental approach has great promise to accomplish this longstanding unmet need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Bacterial keratitis is a significant sight-threatening infectious disease of the cornea. This project will investigate how extracellular matrix (ECM) components of the corneal basement membrane are assembled and how certain bacterial pathogens exploit ECM fibrils of the corneal basement membrane for their attachment and infection. These studies should uncover new mechanisms of how ECM interactions regulate corneal homeostasis and how pathogens take advantage of this physiological process to promote their pathogenesis. We anticipate these studies to reveal new targets for therapy against ocular surface diseases, including bacterial keratitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over the next five years, the U-RISE at University of New Mexico program will prepare 30 students from groups underrepresented in the biomedical sciences for PhD programs and careers in research. Our program will also advise undergraduate students about the possibilities for pursuing research careers, thereby enhancing the curriculum at our University for all STEM students. As ours is a minority-majority state with ~18% of the population living under the poverty line, our U-RISE Scholars come from populations associated with significant health disparities (diabetes, cancer, infant mortality, HIV/AIDS, and alcoholism) that afflict minorities and those in poverty, we will be training individuals who are highly motivated and skilled to carry out future research aimed at alleviating and curing these health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goals of this proposal are to (1) determine if slow and rhythmical breathing consciously performed during wakefulness through an 8-week yogic breathwork intervention will be sustained in sleep; (2) measure the effects of the intervention on subjects' long-term sleep patterns, and correlate the degree of sleep improvement with the changes in breathing patterns during sleep measured in Aim 1, and; (3) determine the influence of an 8-week yogic breathwork intervention on CSF flow dynamics and glymphatic function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure of old cells and tissue to young blood leads to their rejuvenation. Likewise, exposure of young cells and tissues to old blood leads to their accelerated aging. However, how a cell is able to reset its age in response to factors in the blood remains a mystery. The main focus of the studies of this proposal is to explore the mechanisms that regulate cellular age and that are required to reset the age or a cell, either to an older age or a younger age, in response to exposure to old or young blood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of the proposed study is to determine whether one type of immune cell called the T cell can adopt qualities similar to another type of immune cell called the natural killer cell. This modified T cell exhibits the ability to recognize certain cancer cells and cells infected with a common virus and could be useful as a cell product in the treatment of certain cancers and infection. Understanding how this modified T cell contributes to the immune response is important in the treatment of patients who may become sick from the virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) related changes likely occur decades before symptoms are observed underscoring the need for novel tools that can aid in the early identification. The olfactory system has multiple unique features that make it an ideal tool to understand the neurobiology of AD, including its direct access to key brain areas that support cognitive and memory function. The proposed study aims to better understand changes in the olfactory system in prodromal AD and its relation to cognitive function using advanced imaging methods, which could ultimately facilitate the development of measures for early detection and progression of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The manipulation of a subset of glutamate-octopamine dual transmitting neurons results in increased levels of high intensity aggression. The goal of our study is to understand how dual transmission is regulated and how the release of two transmitters from the same neuron leads to changes in aggressive behaviors. A better understanding of the mechanisms by which dual transmission is controlled may lead to novel strategies to treat elevated aggression that are associated with psychiatric disorders or neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Deep brain stimulation (DBS) has been FDA approved for managing several brain disorders, including Parkinson’s disease (PD), and has been increasingly used to treat patient over the past couple decades. However, the therapeutic mechanisms of DBS remain largely unknown. This study aims to systematically study the neural circuits involved in PD, and the therapeutic mechanisms of DBS using novel single cell voltage imaging techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Envelope (Env) glycoprotein of HIV-1, a key player in the biology of the virus, has a complex glycan shield with multiple functions. In this proposal, we will test the concept that the glycan shield is comprised of glycan-units with distinct functions and limited interchangeable positions. We will use a combination of research tools to provide novel insights into the how these clusters of glycans work together to maintain a functional Env glycoprotein and, thus, identify vulnerable regions of the glycan shield that can be targeted for intervention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atrial fibrillation (AF) is afflicting over 33 million people worldwide to date and its prevalence is expected to increase dramatically in the future. This proposal aims at studying new modalities for characterizing the AF in computer and sheep models to describe new mechanisms of patterns of the electrical activity during its onset and cessation. Accomplishment of the proposal aims will enhance our understanding of AF and possibly lead to improved risk stratification and guide therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The smallest airways in the human lung are called the respiratory airways and are a site of injury in many chronic lung diseases including Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (COPD). We have identified a new lung stem cell in this region that is altered in COPD, potentially affecting the lung's ability to heal and repair. Understanding the mechanisms that regulate this cell type will help identify new avenues for treatment in COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We predict that olfactory dysfunction testing using AROMA – a novel, essential oil-based, objective test of olfaction – and machine learning algorithms using this data will accurately classify Alzheimer’s disease stage (including asymptomatic individuals); be strongly associated with and predictive of conventional biomarkers of disease; and predict longitudinal functional trajectory. The ability to effectively screen for ADRD using a non- invasive and accessible test is critical to public health and our ability to identify people early when disease course is most likely to still be modifiable. Accurate prediction of future functional decline will also meaningfully inform comprehensive care planning and improved counseling of patients and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project combines the expertise of Johns Hopkins University and the University of Illinois at Urbana- Champaign to develop a safe and broadly protective combination vaccine against enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) and Shigella, two leading causes of children’s diarrhea and travelers’ diarrhea. Currently, there is no licensed vaccine for either ETEC or Shigella, but the novel epitope- and structure- based MEFA (multiepitope fusion antigen) vaccinology platform together with appropriate animal challenge models make feasible the development and evaluation of a safe and broadly protective multivalent combination vaccine for ETEC and Shigella. An effective ETEC-Shigella vaccine will have a major beneficial impact on children’s health, and this MEFA technology may be applied generally for safe and precision multivalent vaccine development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While prior research has highlighted biological, cognitive, and caregiving factors that increase risk for child attention problems, the impact of trajectories of these risk factors in relation to trajectories of inattention have yet to be studied. This study examines initial levels and change in DNA methylation, executive function, and caregiver psychological distress as predictors of inattention trajectories in a sample of 568 very preterm children. The proposed training and research activities will improve understanding of the strongest individual or combined risk factors for attention problems in this high-risk population, help us identify sensitive periods at which biological, cognitive, and caregiving factors are most predictive of functional outcomes, and provide critical information regarding the optimal focus and timing for future interventions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Histone modifications serve as key epigenetic marks with dynamic functions in many cellular processes. This proposal aims to characterize the role of histone H3 lysine 36 methylation, a mark of active transcription, in the specification and maintenance of colon cell lineages. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to identify objective, biological markers of psychosis risk by utilizing ‘big data’ to assess how deviations from pediatric neurodevelopmental growth charts predict which individuals are at greatest risk for developing psychosis. We will then assess how high-performance, low-field MRI can be used to measure these indices, a key step for future use of these measures in community settings. Results from this study will lead to earlier detection and intervention of those at greatest risk and make these assessments easily accessible to all, ultimately improving outcomes and potentially preventing the onset of psychosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Among SARS-CoV-2-infected individuals, we have seen the emergence of a subset of patients with persistent symptoms, including fatigue, shortness of breath, brain fog, sleep disorders, fevers, gastrointestinal symptoms, anxiety, and depression lasting in duration from several weeks to many months. These symptoms, collectively known as PASC, or “long-COVID”, occur in a sizable proportion of SARS-CoV-2 infected individuals and range from mild to incapacitating, with profound effects on quality of life. We propose applying new statistical approaches to characterize the risk factors for PASC and to determine how best to treat patients with PASC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research investigates novel mechanisms in axon regeneration, a critical process that can restore function after nerve injury. The research proposed here is expected to result in fundamental knowledge that suggests ways to promote functional recovery after nerve injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to environmental toxicants including pesticides causes dopamine (DA) neuron loss in the substantia nigra and raises risk for developing Parkinson’s disease (PD), with important sex differences where females lose fewer DA neurons than males. We have identified the vesicular glutamate transporter VGLUT2 in mammals and its Drosophila ortholog dVGLUT as modulators of sex differences in DA neuron resilience. Our proposed studies of dVGLUT/VGLUT2’s roles in sex differences in DA neuron resilience in the context of environmental toxicant exposures may provide new insights into PD and ultimately may lead to new, effective treatments to either slow or stop PD neurodegeneration in men and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reticular Dysgenesis is a severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome caused by loss of the mitochondrial enzyme Adenylate Kinase 2 (AK2). AK2 links energy and nucleotide metabolism, and lack of AK2 causes reductive stress and defects in purine synthesis in myeloid cells, the cell type most affected in RD. Understanding the mechanisms by which AK2 deficiency undermines the proliferation of myeloid cells will allow us to identify better treatments for mitochondrial and metabolic diseases and more precise strategies for improving immunosuppression and cancer therapy by selectively manipulating purine metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blockages of arteries in the legs are often treated with metal mesh tubes called stents to keep the arteries propped open. These stents often fail resulting in return of symptoms, repeat surgery, or amputation. We propose to develop and test an optimally-designed stent that bends and twists with the artery during walking, and we hypothesize that it will help arteries stay open longer by improving arterial healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal is based on the hypothesis that cancer cells avoid triggering inflammatory death by pyroptosis, by  down- regulating  or  mutating  GSDME,  which  suppresses  effective  anti- tumor  immunity.  A  corollary  is  that  inducing  pyroptosis  in  cancer  cells  will  enhance  immune  control  and  responsiveness  to  chemotherapy  drugs.  Therapeutic strategies that induce GSDME and/or make cancer cells susceptible to pyroptosis may be effective  at activating anti- tumor immunity, controlling tumor growth and improving responses to conventional or targeted  drugs, radiation or immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The shortage and poor quality of donor organs represent major limitations facing liver transplantation, the gold standard of care in patients with end-stage liver disease and those with tumors of hepatic origin. The goal of this project is to improve long-term liver transplant outcomes as well as “rejuvenating” suboptimal hepatic tissue, and promoting homeostasis via hepatocyte – macrophage cross-regulation. Our findings should facilitate innovative interventions to improve the quality and size of the current organ supply, an absolute imperative for the full realization of success for solid organ transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Wright Regional Center for Clinical and Translational Science (Wright Regional CCTS) is a collaboration of partner institutions that serves regions of Virginia and North Carolina. Partners include Virginia Commonwealth University, Virginia State University, Eastern Virginia Medical School, and Old Dominion University. Our overall goal is to develop methods that overcome roadblocks in clinical and translational science (CTS) to support equitable advancement of translational science across our rural and diverse region that can be deployed throughout the CTSA network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Neuromodulators are important for normal brain function, and defects in modulatory transmission are involved in many brain disorders. We will dissect how the neuromodulator dopamine is released from somata and dendrites from midbrain dopamine neurons in the vertebrate brain. Our results will likely uncover new secretory mechanisms and general principles for neuromodulation, and may reveal cellular pathways that are affected by drugs of abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is essential to address the complex social ecological factors that persistently hamper the delivery of necessary healthcare, particularly in light of pervasive documented health inequities. The REACH (Research Expanding Access to Child Health) Center will strengthen pediatric health care research infrastructure by establishing a thematic, multidisciplinary health research system, rooted in the principles and methods of pediatric healthcare delivery science, and bridging our biomedical research and health care systems to assure equitable access to high quality pediatric health care for all. The REACH Center will propel scientific knowledge, technical capabilities, and clinical practice forward to improve health and health equity for children and families across Delaware with broad implications nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Until the unfortunate COVID-19 development, Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) was the number one cause of death in humans due to a single infectious agent. The current tuberculosis vaccine BCG is very effective in young children, but there is a need for a generally more-effective and longer-lasting vaccine, potentially as a booster to BCG. This proposal examines a novel intranasal subunit BCG booster vaccine comprised of multiple Mtb antigens that interact with the respiratory mucosa and are adhered to nanoparticles and combined with an immune-stimulating matrix.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative: STAT3 mutations cause autosomal dominant hyper IgE syndrome (AD-HIES), a rare genetic disease. Recurrent pulmonary infection is the leading cause of mortality in AD-HIES, but the mechanism(s) mediating mutant STAT3-induced lung disease are unclear. This application proposes to identify the mechanisms by which STAT3 mutations cause defective mucociliary clearance in AD-HIES subjects, quantitate their mucus obstruction and ventilation defects, and provide options for new therapies for the pulmonary manifestations of AD-HIES.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research experiences, education, and mentorship skills training of researchers from low- and middle- income countries in this program will allow them to more independently address the most important issues of global HIV prevention, and with greater effectiveness by taking into account the local context and culture. ITAPS will help address critical shortages of trained LMIC mentors and fill gaps in analytic skills required for research. Mutually beneficial research collaborations between US investigators and ITAPS trainees will be promoted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying the infectivity of Mycobacterium tuberculosis expands our knowledge of biochemical pathways in pathogenic bacteria and is crucial to identify novel targets with the hope of combating the increase in drug-resistant strains. We are studying unique aspects of both gene regulation and DNA repair in M. tuberculosis. In separate studies, we are using ensemble biochemistry, single-molecule biophysics, and kinetic modeling to undercover the mechanisms of transcription initiation in Eukaryotes, including yeast and humans.

PHR: The purpose of this study is to test VALE+TU SALUD (Your Health is Worth More) in a cluster randomized trial in order to answer this question: Can an adapted Latino day laborer program increase adherence to mitigation practices that reduce the risk of COVID 19? PHR: Vascularization is critical to many normal (e.g., wound healing) and pathologic (e.g., tumor progression) conditions, as well as emerging therapeutic approaches to treat ischemic diseases. This proposal will determine how two key features of the microenvironment (the extracellular matrix and supporting stromal cells) regulate the quantity, functional quality, and stability of new capillary blood vessels. Results from the proposed studies will help bring cell/biomaterial-based strategies to vascularize tissues closer to a translational endpoint.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prolonged social isolation can produce deleterious effects on the brain and behavior, including the promotion of interpersonal aggression and violence against others. The proposed research is relevant to public health, as we aim to achieve a circuit-based, mechanistic understanding of how the brain exerts coordinated, prefrontal control of isolation-induced aggression. These findings will transform the field by expanding our understanding of how pathological forms of aggression are encoded by the brain, and will identify targets for the treatment of isolation- related mental health disorders, particularly those that result in violence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Drugs that reduce the activity of an enzyme called phosphodiesterase 5A (PDE5A) are used worldwide as safe and efficacious agents for erectile dysfunction in older men, in men with diabetes, and in men with prostate cancer following therapy. Our recent finding in mice that the drugs also increase bone mass, particularly in females, has prompted our current investigations into their efficacy and mechanism of action. These preclinical studies, comprising both genetic and pharmacological approaches, should provide the basis for future clinical trials for osteoporosis in elderly women and men.

PHR: NARRATIVE Pulmonary nontuberculous mycobacterial disease is increasing in incidence and disproportionately affects the elderly. However, the mechanisms underlying increased vulnerability and disease severity in the elderly are unknown. Therefore, in this proposal we will identify these mechanisms by investigating age related changes in immunity and microbial communities in the lung using a translational nonhuman primate model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This R50 Research Specialist (Clinical Scientist) proposal is to support (40% effort) Deborah Stephens, DO, to continue providing extensive support of NCI-sponsored clinical trials including: serving as a national principal investigator for the S1925 EVOLVE CLL trial; supporting SWOG Leukemia and Lymphoma Working Groups; and, providing leadership and mentorship in hematology clinical trials research at Huntsman Cancer Institute. Dr. Stephens’s work as a clinical investigator focuses on improving survival and care of patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia and relapsed/refractory B-cell lymphoma, the most common adult blood cancers which are mostly considered incurable. This Research Specialist award would improve the survival of and care for these patients and support Dr. Stephens continued development and management of a clinical trial portfolio with significant scope at HCI including National Cancer Institute (NCI)-sponsored investigator-initiated, and industry-sponsored clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The successes of antiretroviral therapy in improving and extending life for people with HIV are significantly diminished by suboptimal adherence and adherence psychosocial and structural barriers. Forty percent of Latino men who have sex with men with HIV do not achieve viral suppression, largely due to suboptimal adherence. The proposed study seeks to evaluate the efficacy of stepped care strategies in improving antiretroviral therapy adherence among Latino men who have sex with men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eukaryotic histone proteins are fundamental to all biological processes and were historically thought to be highly conserved. However, histones proteins can be subject to evolutionary turnover in the form of gene duplications and dramatic sequence divergence in multiple eukaryotic lineages suggesting adaptive advantages. This proposal uses yeast and flies to investigate the fitness advantages of unique eukaryotic histone repertoires for two crucial functions – genome regulation and DNA damage response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE.  Vibrio cholerae is a gram negative bacterium and facultative human pathogen that causes the acute diarrheal disease cholera. Cholera is an epidemic disease that is estimated to affect 3-5 million people each year. The research proposed in this project focuses on defining the mechanisms used by V. cholerae to cause human disease and survive in aquatic ecosystems. Defining these mechanisms will uncover novel targets for the development of new therapeutic approaches to treat cholera.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  This project investigates how fundamental metabolic processes (i.e., glycolysis and mitochondrial respiration) regulate the cellular events that drive the elongation and rotation of the embryonic digestive tract. The results will provide new insight into the etiology of intestinal malrotation, a common birth defect with significant morbidity. Moreover, as the morphogenetic mechanisms regulated by metabolism -- mesenchymal- to-epithelial transitions and interkinetic nuclear migration --underlie the proper formation of many tissues and organs throughout the embryo, the findings will also reveal how abnormal maternal or fetal metabolism could contribute to a wide variety of structural birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to determine the cell identity, electrophysiological properties, and functional connectivity of hippocampal long-range projecting GABAergic neurons, and examine whether this long-range inhibition coordinates and synchronizes activity between the hippocampus and subcortical regions in memory formation. Given that impairments of coordination and synchronization between the hippocampus and other brain areas have been implicated in a number of neurological and psychiatric disorders, such as Alzheimer’s disease and depression, the knowledge gained from this proposal will provide new insights into both normal functions of hippocampal-subcortical circuits and their potential involvement in diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: FEDERATION OF AMER SOC FOR EXPER BIOLOGY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diseases of the retina affect approximately three million Americans, about 1 million of whom are blind. In many of these conditions, including age-related macular degeneration (AMD), diabetic retinopathy and retinitis pigmentosa, blindness is caused by the loss of rod and cone photoreceptor cells. Therefore, the prospect of therapeutic treatments for a wide array of these conditions depends on scientific advances in our understanding of the biochemistry, physiology, cell biology, molecular biology and genetics of photoreceptor function. Of critical importance in accomplishing this goal is the open exchange of new research findings among the community of vision scientists and the cultivation of the next generation of researchers to study photoreceptor biology and pathobiology. The FASEB Science Research Conference on “The Biology and Chemistry of Vision” is the premier meeting in the field of photoreceptors and their supporting cells. This biennial conference attracts the leading investigators in the field and is well-attended by young investigators, postdoctoral fellows, and students. It represents unique opportunities to propel new developments in vision research, articulate pressing questions and foster new collaborations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social positions within workplaces have been shown to be associated with increased morbidity and shorter life expectancy, but the causality and mechanisms behind this association remain unclear. Our proposed study will use administrative health and earnings records from millions of workers in Utah to examine the causal pathways between workplace social status and minority health disparities in a broad and diverse US population. We will extend the literature to examine the mechanisms behind persistent health disparities that operate intergenerationally or through social networks with coworkers, quantify how these channels contribute to structural racial and ethnic health disparities, and estimate how public policies might mitigate these health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Time of flight positron emission tomography (TOF-PET) is a very effective nuclear medicine technique to diagnose cancer, cardiovascular diseases, and musculoskeletal disorders. Novel modalities of TOF-PET have emerged during the last years, such as long axial field of view (LA- FOV) TOF-PET or studies with very low dose uptake, but state-of-the-art detectors used in TOF- PET are hindering their progression due to the elevated production cost and intrinsic physical properties. In this project, we will evaluate the feasibility of using a new detector material, thallium chloride, as it offers a low production cost and very attractive physical properties that can allow for a practical adoption and spread of the most recent TOF-PET techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: U*RISE at UC Merced - Project Narrative The focus of our U*RISE proposal is to provide robust and enhanced research experiences with supplemental training in computational biology and/or systems biology including bioinformatics, multiple “-omics” approaches, and big data analytics. We propose to take a cohort, peer- mentoring approach that allows the scholars an opportunity to provide direct, hands-on peer- mentoring in conjunction with the faculty’s mentoring and supervision, and also integrate a highly innovative modular-learning approach to the training of scholars. Given UC Merced’s status as a Hispanic Serving Institution and the number of highly qualified undergraduates in Biology, Chemistry, and Math, recruiting and retaining these scholars will be easily achieved, and our history of successful training program implementation and achievements make UC Merced ideally situated to successfully implement the proposed U*RISE at UC Merced program.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Tennessee State University (TSU) Undergraduate Research Training Initiative for Student Enhancement (U-RISE) program would increase the pool of historically under-represented (UR) research scientists. PHR: Project Narrative The kidney is a complex organ whose essential roles include filtering waste from the blood, regulating blood pressure, and maintaining electrolyte balance. This project will develop a microscopy-based technique to study the organization of the genome of kidney cells and it will use the new technique to study aging in model mouse kidney tissue. The tools and findings of this project will enable researchers to study genome organization in kidney or other tissues and will illuminate the molecular details of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An impaired ability to exert control has been implicated in bulimia nervosa (BN), but this impairment may not represent a stable trait or be the most effective focus for treatment. This project aims to understand how predictions and value-based decisions about control may be abnormally influenced by eating in individuals with BN, thereby maintaining cycles of binge eating, purging, and restriction. Data from this project will inform a new model of BN symptoms and identify more precise, state-specific intervention targets for this costly and often chronic disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mild traumatic brain injury, or concussion, gives rise to cognitive deficits, chiefly inattention, that overlap the phenotype of comorbid attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) during adolescence. The proposed research capitalizes on this clinical window of opportunity to compare fMRI-based neural signatures of acquired vs primary inattention. This study will leverage innovative analytic approaches and already-collected data from the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) study, the largest ever fMRI study of 11,875 children, to advance scientific understanding of cognitive deficits following traumatic brain injury as compared to primary attention deficit in ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Diabetes distress—stress, fear, and guilt related to managing diabetes—is linked to poor glycemic control and disproportionately affects vulnerable populations. Screening for and intervening on high levels of diabetes distress is now a part of diabetes care guidelines, but no studies have tested diabetes distress screening and treatment interventions in a real-world primary care setting. This pragmatic study will compare a program to support community health center (CHC) healthcare teams deliver systematic diabetes distress screening and intervention (6 CHCs) to enhanced usual care (6 CHCs) and assess its impact on glycemic control (A1C) among adults with type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative mRNA-LNPs are the backbone of the highly successful COVID-19 vaccines. We propose to develop mRNA-LNPs that will deliver HIV-specific CARs to tissues and cells that are enriched for cells harboring the latent reservoir. Our underlying hypothesis is that by expressing HIV CARs in areas where HIV hides from CTLs, “kick and kill” strategies will be much more effective in reducing the reservoir.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulation of ERK activity through dephosphorylation by phosphatases is critical for female fertility; alterations to ERK activity results in female infertility. For decades the DUSP6/7 homolog LIP-1 in worms was thought to function as an ERK phosphatase in the female germline in worms; recent work shows that LIP-1 and its ortholog DUSP6/7 do not regulate ERK activity during oogenesis in worms and mice. The goal of this proposal is to identify the phosphatase that controls ERK, in vivo, during oogenesis and generate reagents to study its function in depth.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The program proposed here aims to strengthen the international research ethics training capacity in Kenya while also addressing the specific needs related to One Health research and emergency health research. As a collaboration between the University of Nairobi (UoN) and The Ohio State University (OSU), it will offer in-depth training and experiences in research ethics and integrity through establishing and running both a 1-year postgraduate diploma (PGD) and a 2-year MSc in One Health and Emergency Research Ethics (MOHERE) at UoN. It will also fund and mentor 6 future leaders in bioethics and research ethics to take the OSU MA in Bioethics so that together all these graduates will become leaders in a sustainable, rigorous and exciting culture of research ethics in Kenya.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This project will contribute to our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that cause accelerated aging, decreased health, and shorter lifespan in offspring from older mothers. This study is innovative and significant in its use of an emerging model system in aging research to examine the role of mitochondrial dysfunction in maternal age effects on offspring aging. Our work has the potential to identify a cause of interindividual variability in lifespan and to identify targets for therapies to improve health and increase lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBMs) is one of the most malignant tumors of the central nervous system (CNS) in humans and has an extremely poor prognosis. We are the first to report that the suppression of TRPM7 inhibits proliferation, migration, and invasion of malignant human gliomas, indicating that TRPM7 may represent a novel and promising target for the therapeutic intervention of malignant glioma. The proposed study will delineate the molecular mechanisms of TRPM7 in the development and progression of glioma tumorigenesis and stemness, as well as develop TRPM7 as a novel drug target for glioma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Pain typically is measured by patient self-report, but self-reported pain is difficult to interpret and may be impaired or not possible to obtain. We will use clinically well-characterized data to: (1) develop an automatic multimodal method for the detection of occurrence and intensity of pain in five of the most common and disabling acute and chronic LBP conditions; (2) use EMA to characterize early point psychosocial and behavioral signs that acute pain is likely to become chronic.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses a significant unmet medical need for curbing metabolic dysfunctions in obesity by investigating a novel mechanism underlying adipose tissue pathological remodeling. PHR: Project Narrative Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is a common and serious public health problem. No effective therapies are currently available, in part due to insufficient understanding of the factors that influence disease progression. We propose to use state-of-the-art genomic tools and genetic and disease models to investigate how a unique type of disease-associated macrophages are regulated and contribute to disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder continues to exert a significant toll on morbidity and mortality in the U.S., yet a pervasive gap remains in engaging the most vulnerable patients in continuous use of evidence-based treatment with medications for opioid use disorder. The proposed research aims to address a lack of knowledge regarding effective strategies for transitioning opioid use disorder patients from interventions that initiate medications in hospital settings to ongoing treatment in the community. This K01 will uncover evidence to better support integrated care services for opioid use disorder across health system touchpoints, while supporting a new investigator in advancing towards an independent research career dedicated to promoting equitable access to evidence-based addiction health services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of metabolic diseases, including obesity, has increased at an alarming rate over the past 50 years, and treatment currently commands enormous public health resources, especially in children and adolescents. Clinical and preclinical data indicate a causal role for disrupted circadian rhythms in the development of obesity, but how metabolic signals early in life impact the development of circadian rhythms in metabolism remains unclear. The goal of this proposal is to determine how diet and the gut microbiota— during circumscribed windows of early development— shape the expression and plasticity of circadian rhythms and metabolic outputs over the lifespan, and thereby dispose individuals to diet-induced obesity.

PHR: Project Narrative Although conventional dendritic cell type 2 (cDC2) plays a pivotal role in multiple diseases, the cDC2 specific mouse model is undeveloped. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NMR spectroscopy is a primary tool for metabolomics and the structural biology of proteins, membrane proteins and complexes they form, providing powerful means for understanding how structure, dynamics, and chemistry drive functional mechanisms. Here, we advance the sensitivity and spectral resolution of NMR technology in multiple ways that will lead to new tools for biomedical science that provide novel insights into metabolic flux, enzyme mechanisms, structure-function relationships for many drug targets, mechanisms of intrinsically disordered proteins, and cell wall structure. We interface to NIH-funded programs aimed at addressing nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, gene regulation, amino acid synthesis, bacterial biofilms, fungal infections, bacterial drug resistance, and drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This proposal will test the efficacy of thawed cryopreserved cultured thymus tissue implantation (cCTTI) versus implantation of freshly cultured thymus tissue (CTTI) to reconstitute the immune system of conditioned recipients, using a pig model. Results will advance the goal of developing immune tolerance to a heart transplanted from the thymus donor, which would revolutionize transplantation of the heart and other solid organs by preventing the chronic rejection and need for immunosuppression that currently limit allograft and patient survival following transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Kaposi's Sarcoma is the most common tumor of AIDS patients worldwide and is caused by the Kaposi's Sarcoma-associated herpesvirus. KSHV is present in the latent state in the KS tumor cells, cells of endothelial origin. Through the study of how cellular metabolic processes are required for KSHV latent infection of endothelial cells, we will identify novel therapeutic targets to inhibit latency and therefore, KS tumors. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Axon regeneration after peripheral nerve (PN) injury is often incomplete, thus deciphering the repair mechanisms is critical. This proposal investigates a previously unknown function of the core circadian regulator Bmal1 in gating neural regenerative responses and immune activation after PN injury. Our study will link Bmal1 circadian clock, epigenetic rhythms, and intriguing time-of-day differences of axon regenerative responses, thus establishing a new paradigm to enhance nerve repair by modulating circadian/ epigenetic pathways.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region faces a myriad of environmental and occupational health (EOH) challenges in a context of dynamic political changes and multiple concurrent humanitarian crises. The proposed collaborative U01 (led by the American University of Beirut, Lebanon) and U2R (led by Yale University in collaboration with the University of Iowa in the US) applications aim to establish a Global Environmental and Occupational Health Research and Training Hub for the MENA region (GEOHealth MENA) with the goal to build and strengthen EOH research capacity at academic/research institutions and relevant NGOs in the region. With the purpose of informing policy and practice guidelines, the U01 research project will evaluate pathways of pesticide exposure among Syrian refugee agricultural workers, investigate its association with neurobehavioral performance, and explore the role of social factors in this association, while providing a platform for short-term (workshops, courses) and long-term training (MPH, PhD) to health professionals from the MENA region supported by the U2R.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Kidney transplant is superior to dialysis for the treatment of end-stage kidney disease, but access to transplant remains limited in underserved communities. To get a transplant, patients must navigate a complicated healthcare system, but the current approach to supporting patients is not patient-centered, inadvertently favoring patients at ease in healthcare settings and with higher socioeconomic status. Feasible strategies to improve access to transplant in safety net hospital settings are critical to providing equitable access.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  A hallmark feature of heart failure is decreased exercise tolerance. Even in normal subjects, dynamic exercise presents one of the greatest challenges to cardiovascular control and this challenge is markedly exacerbated in heart failure resulting in often profound increases in sympathetic nerve activity which can elicit vasoconstriction of the inactive vascular beds such as the kidney and even the coronary circulation as well as the active skeletal muscle. The focus of this proposal is to determine the mechanisms mediating the extreme activation of the sympathetic nervous system during exercise in patients with heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative  This study aims to learn the causes of population differences in genetic risks of schizophrenia through studying genetic regulators of brain gene expression in donors of East Asian, African, and European ancestry, and create a novel algorithm to impute genetically-regulated brain gene expression based on genotype data of diverse genetic backgrounds. The study will improve our understanding of the biological mechanism of schizophrenia and discover novel risk genes either specific to populations or shared across populations, with significant implications for addressing human diversity, health disparities and for developing precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The status of the axillary lymph nodes is one of the strongest prognostic factors in patients with breast cancer, and the sentinel lymph node (SLN) biopsy has become the standard of care in the assessment of metastatic spread to the lymph nodes (LN). Current SLN biopsy procedures are limited by a lack of real-time intraoperative visualization tools to accurately distinguish between LN metastases and healthy LN. The overall objective is to determine whether our intraoperative imaging approach can accurately distinguish between LN metastases and healthy LN in mimicked intraoperative settings (animal surgery) with multiple validations and the double-blinded procedure.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Pregnancy requires adaptation by many maternal organs, including the heart, but precisely how the heart responds to the dynamic changes of pregnancy and the postpartum periods is poorly understood. Here, we present novel data suggesting that prolactin receptor (PRLR) signaling is critical for the normal response of the heart to the physiologic stress of pregnancy, and resolution of those adaptations in the postpartum. Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying adaptations driven by cardiac PRLR signaling will reveal novel insights into the biology of the heart during pregnancy and may predict novel targets to improve heart function during pregnancy in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We plan to determine why post-exertional malaise occurs, to which patients and at what level of severity. The changes in cardiopulmonary physiology reported to occur on the second of two sequential days of maximal exercise testing have been reported to be a physiological manifestation of PEM. This proposal seeks to use this two day exercise protocol to understand the physiology of PEM and how it is linked to its behavioral manifestations of reduced activity and markedly increased symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) cause substantial mortality and morbidity. Current treatments that block pathological inflammatory responses have improved clinical outcomes in some patients but they are not highly effective in modifying disease progression or preventing relapses. Common genetic polymorphisms associated with disease risk can be utilized to identify molecular pathways, genes and cell types driving disease pathogenesis. As such, we have recently identified an association of LSP1 expression in CD4+ T cells with the risk for inflammatory bowel disease, and our work here will examine the role of LSP1 in CD4+ T cells in IBD pathogenesis, provide direct mechanistic insights, identify functional genetic variants and will aid to develop novel therapeutic targets for inflammatory bowel disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Platelet transfusion is an essential therapy for the treatment and prevention of bleeding, yet a significant number of platelet transfusions fail to achieve the anticipated clinical effect. Oftentimes this is the result of antibody-mediated platelet clearance; however, we have recently found that CD8 T cells can cause accelerated loss of transfused platelets. Understanding the interactions between recipient CD8 T cells and transfused donor platelets may reveal new therapeutic strategies to inhibit platelet loss in patients requiring transfusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a malignant primary brain cancer which carries a dismal prognosis. STAT3 has been shown to be a very attractive therapeutic target for GBM; albeit, small molecule inhibitors of STAT3 signaling are ineffective, as they exhibit very poor blood brain barrier permeability. Our interdisciplinary team will develop and evaluate a novel and scalable bi-compartmental nanoparticle delivery system that allows controlled co-release of STAT3 siRNA and the chemotherapeutic agent, paclitaxel. This work may result in a new treatment modality for GBM, a tumor type, for which no effective treatments exist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal seeks support for the Society of Ear, Nose and Throat Advances in Children (SENTAC) annual scientific conference, to enhance diversity, equity, and inclusion. SENTAC facilitates the formation and dissemination of interdisciplinary knowledge about the care of infants and children with otolaryngology, hearing, speech, and swallowing disorders. The purpose of this grant is to support annual conferences for the next five years with a focus on enhancing diversity in membership and attendees, and support research presentations and educational sessions that focus on health inequities in the field of ear, nose, and throat disorders in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Children’s mental, emotional, and behavioral disorders, as well as childhood obesity, occur at alarmingly high levels and constitute major public health concerns. The Research Center for Child Well-Being focuses on prevention of both mental health and obesity-related problems in children ages 2-10, emphasizing the promotion of self-regulation and the fostering of nurturing environments for healthy child development. The Center seeks to add to the nation’s scientific workforce for the next generation of prevention research towards greater child well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomarkers that reliably inform the selection of therapy or prognosis for patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) are lacking. Emerging data suggest that analysis of the profiles of small (30-150 nm) extracellular vesicles (sEV), also known as exosomes, in body fluids is a promising approach to the detection of non-invasive biomarkers in cancer, including HNSCC. This project will simultaneously assess the utility of sEV produced by tumor cells (TEX) and sEV produced by non-malignant cells (NTEX) in HNSCC patients’ plasma as biomarkers of prognosis and/or response to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Wnt/beta-catenin pathway and adenosine monophosphate-activated kinase (AMPK) pathway play crucial roles in regulation of hepatic metabolism. The proposed studies will develop novel small molecules that possess dual activities of Wnt/beta-catenin inhibition and AMPK activation, delineate their molecular mechanism of action, and assess their efficacy and safety for treatment of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) which afflicts 12% of US population. The findings are expected to be of great impact as they lead to pharmacological agents for a highly unmet medical need with no approved drugs.

PHR: Infection with bacteria triggers specific responses from the human immune system that help clear the infection. We discovered a protein (NLRP11) that is key to this response in human macrophages. Our goals are to generate insights into how NLRP11 contributes to macrophage responses that facilitate control of infection with certain human bacterial pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Research narrative The goal of the proposed research is an understanding of how action selection for goal-directed behavior is implemented in the frontal cortex, basal ganglia, and superior colliculus network. Malfunctions of this multi- regional network lead to repetitive and maladaptive behavior that affect a wide range of normal functions such as learning, motor skills, as well as social psychological well-beings. An understanding of the neural circuits that implement action selection could begin to outline a roadmap that informs treatments of these disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals residing in prisons have among the highest rates of tuberculosis worldwide, and this risk remains elevated for years following release from prison. How to effectively and screen for and diagnose tuberculosis in resource-constrained settings remains unclear. This project aims to investigate novel strategies for tuberculosis case finding and monitoring of transmission in high tuberculosis-burden prisons in Brazil, with a goal of identifying scalable strategies to protect the health of incarcerated people and their communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because of the need for modeling tools to guide more effective, rapid responses to emerging outbreaks and future pandemics. We propose to develop models that place social and epidemiological determinants of infection on equal footing and that integrate data and models from the individual to the population level using highly-detailed information from longitudinal cohort and clinical data. These models will evaluate disparities in incidence and burden of emerging pathogens as well as vaccination coverage and effectiveness to promote equitable mitigation of future outbreaks at the population level. This research is relevant to the mission of the NIMHD in that it will inform future modeling efforts to guide vaccination and other public health approaches that will reduce disparities in outbreaks of emerging infections.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) The Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region faces a myriad of environmental and occupational health (EOH) challenges in a context of dynamic political changes and multiple concurrent humanitarian crises. The proposed collaborative U01 (led by the American University of Beirut, Lebanon) and U2R (led by Yale University in collaboration with the University of Iowa in the US) applications aim to establish a Global Environmental and Occupational Health Research and Training Hub for the MENA region (GEOHealth MENA) with the goal to build and strengthen EOH research capacity at academic/research institutions and relevant NGOs in the region. With the purpose of informing policy and practice guidelines, the U01 research project will evaluate pathways of pesticide exposure among Syrian refugee agricultural workers, investigate its association with neurobehavioral performance, and explore the role of social factors in this association, while providing a platform for short-term (workshops, courses) and long-term training (MPH, PhD) to health professionals from the MENA region supported by the U2R.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adolescent cannabis use is a significant public health concern because it predicts poor cognitive, educational, and occupational outcomes. Brain mechanisms of cognitive flexibility and reward motivation, two processes linked to functional impairment and addiction in adult substance use, have been neglected in studies of adolescent cannabis use. The proposed research and career development activities will provide the trainee with critical skills in (a) research assessment of adolescent cannabis use, (b) neuroimaging, and (c) computational modeling, facilitating her transition to an independent scientist whose work uses brain- mechanisms to identify factors explaining the transition from substance use to addiction in order to inform the design of targeted treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project narrative While most of the tumors in the head and neck region can be cured when discovered early, treatments are often ineffective when these tumors are discovered late. Since most head and neck cancers are found late, only when they become symptomatic, there is a need for non-invasive diagnostic tests to detect them early. We propose to develop a test able to discover the tumor from the oral rinse by checking for the presence of part of cells called myeloid derived suppressor cells that are present only in the tumor and that cancer needs to develop.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  By using the novel mouse models of human hereditary pancreatitis we recently developed, we will test our novel hypothesis that, in addition to gain-of-function features of PRSS1, the expression levels of trypsinogens and the location of active enzymes determine the spontaneous initiation and severity of hereditary pancreatitis. This study will provide novel insights into the spontaneous initiation of hereditary pancreatitis and the pathogenesis of hemorrhagic pancreatitis and pave the ways for developing novel effective preventive and therapeutic interventions.
