IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Prostate cancer (PCa) remains an incurable disease once progression to the metastatic castration-resistant (mCRPC) state occurs; killing >30,000 U.S. men/yr. Herein, we put forward an innovative strategy to selectively exploit selective vulnerabilities in neuroendocrine prostate cancer (NEPC), a highly aggressive variant of mCRPC, using an orally-bioavailable and highly specific LSD1 inhibitor, bomedemstat, in clinical development for unrelated indications. Furthermore, genome-scale analyses integrated with pharmacogenomics pipelines provide a rich mechanistic understanding of the genetic and epigenetic molecular features underlying the mCRPC subtype specificity to LSD1 inhibition, which will guide patient selection in future biomarker-driven clinical trials.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: SMART Preemie Project Narrative Sudden and Unexpected Infant Death (SUID) occurs 2-3-fold higher among preterm infants, compared to healthy, term infants, despite prolonged hospitalization and multiple touch points with medical providers. Our R01 “Study of Attitudes and Factors Effecting PREterm infant care Practices” (SAFE PREP) found alarming rates of modifiable, unsafe sleep practices, including non-supine sleep among 51% and bedsharing among 24% of US preterm infants recruited from 30 NICUs across the US. In this renewal application, “SMART Preemie,” we proposed a hybrid type 1 implementation effectiveness, cluster randomized trial. We will study the (1) impact of safe sleep education interventions occurring in the a) hospital and b) post-discharge time periods versus an attention-matched control (shared reading) on adherence to safe sleep practices and (2) key implementation outcomes (feasibility, acceptability, fidelity, and sustainability) to inform future scale-up.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Lupus nephritis is a significant burden to patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, but currently the prognostic utility of the kidney biopsy is lacking. Therefore, novel approaches are required to obtain continuous, quantitative data to improve accuracy, reproducibility, and prognostic utility. In this project we will apply detailed quantitative morphologic scoring, supervised computer-aided deep learning image analysis algorithms with morphometric analysis, and unsupervised machine learning approaches to establish improved methods of kidney biopsy interpretation in lupus nephritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insects are vectors for many pathogens that contribute to the deaths of more than a million people each year. Mosquitoes and other biting insects use a variety of gustatory cues to identify their human targets, but the molecular mechanisms underlying insect taste receptors are poorly understood. Here, we propose to elucidate the structure and function of insect taste receptors, thus providing a critical foundation for developing new strategies to limit the human and financial damage caused by insect pests.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Undernutrition is the most common cause of tuberculosis (TB) disease worldwide, but despite curative antibiotics people with undernutrition commonly suffer failure of TB treatment. We found that conventional dosing of anti-TB antibiotics led to suboptimal serum concentrations that contributed to treatment failure. However, we also found that the suboptimal serum concentrations can be approximated by measuring the amount of drug that is excreted in the urine. We propose to study the efficacy and safety of dose personalization of a common anti-TB antibiotic based on urine excretion in adults and children with TB from a region burdened by undernutrition. We will also study the reasons why undernourished people may have suboptimal drug concentrations, including the presence of gut pathogens or gastrointestinal malabsorption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common hematologic malignancy in the United States. Approximately 40% of adult DLBCL patients relapse or are refractory to current frontline therapy, thus there is an urgent need for new effective therapies. Using chemical biology combined with a high-throughput 930 cancer cell line screen, we identified 4’-ethynyl-deoxycytidine as a unique pre-clinical therapeutic for DLBCL which we plan to further investigate and develop herein.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The effects of consuming non-nutritive sweeteners (NNS) during pregnancy and lactation on infant obesity and cardiometabolic disease risk are not well understood. In this project, pregnant women who frequently consume NNS will be randomly assigned to an NNS-restriction intervention (NNS restriction during pregnancy and lactation or during lactation only) or a control group (no NNS restriction) to determine whether NNS consumption during pregnancy and/or lactation affects infant body composition, maternal blood sugar during pregnancy, and the infants’ gut microbiome and metabolome. The results of this study have the potential to shape recommendations around NNS consumption during pregnancy and lactation, thereby potentially improving maternal and infant metabolic health and reducing the global burden of obesity and cardiometabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Essential voice tremor (EVT) affects over 40% of individuals with essential tremor (ET), one of the most common movement disorders characterized primarily by upper limb tremor. Although thalamic deep brain stimulation (DBS) has become the go to treatment for severe and drug-refractory ET, we are still at the early stages of understanding its capacity to treat EVT. Here, we propose to identify thalamic targets that optimize EVT suppression in ET patients undergoing DBS treatment for upper limb tremor and determine if EVT suppression is a marker for axial tremor suppression and reduced fall risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Relevance) Chlamydia trachomatis is a medically relevant pathogen that depends on host for its nutritional requirements, thus placing the pathogen in a metabolic situation that demands balanced utilization of nutrient resources. Here, we investigate how the unusual means of regulating the trp operon accomplishes this balancing act to ensure that a specific substrate is available to the other metabolic pathways that requires it. Investigations will revolve around the intergenic region of the trp operon, which was previously characterized to mediate regulation by the transcriptional repressor YtgR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Mutations in equilibrative nucleoside transporter 3 (encoded by SLC29A3 gene) cause an expanding spectrum of human genetic disorders (e.g., H syndrome, PHID syndrome, and SHML/RDD syndrome) with anemia as a characteristic sign. In the present proposal we seek to determine the molecular disease pathogenesis and treatment options for anemia and related pathologies observed in SLC29A3-mutated disorders. The proposed research is relevant to public health because we anticipate that this project will uncover treatment options for several SLC29A3 mutated human disorders and improve the understanding of occurrence of anemias in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because social anxiety that persists into mid-adolescence predicts lifelong negative mental, social, and economic outcomes, there is a critical need to identify the behavioral and neural mechanisms by which youth remit vs. persist in symptoms. The goal of this longitudinal project is to characterize the brain-based mechanisms by which biased memory for negative social experiences contribute to adolescent social anxiety persistence and remittance. Given gold standard treatment rarely results in remission, these results will pave the way to develop much-needed novel interventions, tailored to a key period of development, that prevent devastating lifelong consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This study will be the first of its kind to explore the impact of continuous theta burst stimulation (cTBS) to the intraparietal sulcus (IPS) on arousal symptoms among patients with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). We will demonstrate that IPS cTBS results in significant reduction in arousal (measured by startle response) compared to sham cTBS, that IPS cTBS interacts with extinction training to further improve arousal, and that there is a dose/response effect of cTBS on arousal. We will also demonstrate that IPS cTBS significantly improves retention of extinction learning, the experimental analogue of exposure therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Genetic variants in a single gene, APOL1, contribute to the very high rate of kidney disease in African Americans and others of recent African ancestry, and also confer resistance to Sleeping Sickness in Africa. We want to understand precisely how these genetic variants lead to this major disparity in kidney disease at a biological level. Understanding how these differences in the APOL1 gene cause kidney disease will have direct implications for improving all aspects of care for the growing number people with this serious public health problem and ultimately removing a major racial health disparity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The adult enteric nervous system contains neuronal progenitors that can be leveraged for regenerative cell therapy to treat neurointestinal diseases, but the pathways that mediate the neurogenic response in the postnatal intestine are unknown. Based on our preliminary data, we hypothesize that inflammatory mediators released by intestinal macrophages act on specific populations of enteric glial cells to activate their differentiation to a neuronal lineage. In this proposal, we will determine the role of activated macrophages and their inflammatory cytokines in glial-derived neurogenesis, examine the role of Sox2 and Sox10 transcription factors in this process, and characterize the phenotypic diversity of the glial-derived neurons that are generated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the mechanisms by which microbiota impact mucosal immune function in a highly prevalent disease such as chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) will lead to: (1) more judicious use of antibiotics, (2) clarity of microbial targets for sinus health and disease, (3) better understanding of therapeutic interventions as they relate to the microbiome, and (4) elucidation of how airway surface microbiota are regulated. Incorporation of these findings into clinical management paradigms will result in well-defined CRS endotypes, improve prognostic abilities for existing interventions, and direct development of novel therapeutics. The proposed research is relevant to NIH's mission for fundamental knowledge that enhances health, reduces illness and disability, and enhances quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Frailty is a syndrome increasingly common in older adults that makes it difficult to recover from a stressful event, such as an infection or fall, and increases the need for more help at home or long-term institutionalization. We believe that statins, one of the most common medications to lower cholesterol and prevent heart disease and strokes, may have a role in lowering frailty by lowering inflammation. In this study we will test whether statins can lower the risk of frailty, measured according to several physical function parameters such as walk speed and grip strength, common blood tests, and other health variables.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: A breakthrough to achieve regeneration of perfect skin has become a major aim in wound healing especially for large burns. The goal of this proposal is to understand the mechanisms of skin regeneration through repopulation of skin allografts in small animal models and to demonstrate the efficacy and feasibility of our novel stem cell mobilizing therapy in repopulation of skin allografts in a preclinical large animal (swine) model of full thickness burns. The translational outcome of this proposal will be a simple, safe and clinically pertinent protocol using FDA approved drugs to induce skin regeneration and to improve the treatment of victims of severe burns.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Brain injury caused by blast waves from IEDs (improvised explosive devices) and other explosions is a signature injury of Veterans serving in Iraq and Afghanistan over the past 20 years. This form of brain injury can result in mental health problems such as PTSD-like symptoms and impairments in brain function (memory loss and/or difficulty making appropriate decisions). These consequences of blast wave injury to the brain seem to result from low-grade chronic inflammation and progressive injury to brain cells. The research described in this application will test whether inhibitors of inflammation can prevent behavioral changes resulting from blast exposure in a well-established a rat model of the anxiety-like traits and brain dysfunction typical of brain injury caused by exposure to blast waves. The treatment being tested can be taken by mouth, is present in nutritional supplements, and is thus thought to be safe. Thus, if successful, this research could be rapidly translated to Veterans to attempt to reduce neuropsychiatric complication of blast exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Endurance exercise is a highly effective intervention for ensuring healthy metabolism and maintaining healthy function during aging, but is unavailable to patients with illnesses or injuries that restrict their movement. Here, we follow up on previous discoveries from the fruit fly model system showing that stimulation of specific regions of the brain can coordinate benefits of exercise in sedentary animals. Here, we propose to follow up by identifying required factors to respond to these stimuli in the exercising brain and muscle, and by extending these results into humans for the first time using virtual reality stimulation to produce some benefits of exercise in sedentary humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Retroviruses have long been recognized as important pathogens of humans and animals, and research on these agents has uncovered important discoveries in cell biology and mechanisms in human disease. The 33rd International Workshop on Retroviral Pathogenesis will continue a long tradition of intimate, engaged scientific interaction on all aspects of retroviral pathogenesis with strong emphasis on animal retroviruses as models of human disease. The conference will convene national and international scientific leaders in the field, together with junior investigators, postdoctoral and student trainees, for scientific presentation and engaged discussion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Streptococcus pneumoniae (Spn) kills millions yearly mainly due to pneumococcal pneumonia. We demonstrated that hydrogen peroxide produced by Spn strains oxidizes heme-carrying proteins, releasing and degrading heme, a molecule having a central role in the biological processes of all living organisms including humans. We will investigate the molecular and cellular mechanisms leading to the oxidation of hemoglobin by Spn and the consequences of such oxidative reactions in the pathophysiology of pneumococcal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: Motoric cognitive risk syndrome (MCR), defined as having both slow walking speed and complaints of declining cognitive function, is common in older adults, and is associated with a very high risk of the future development of dementia. Research by us and others indicates that a form of non-invasive brain stimulation called transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) may be used to improve aspects of brain function that support the control of both walking and mental function. In this project, we will use home-based delivery of individually-tailored tDCS and a combination of in-lab and home-based assessments to conduct a multi-site, randomized controlled clinical trial of tDCS in older men and women with MCR, in the hope of demonstrating that six months of stimulation enhances cognition and lowers the risk of the future development of dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to the global epidemic of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), the potential market impact for the NASH drug is estimated to be about $20 billion to $35 billion, as populations with fatty diets increasingly fall victim to a condition with no approved treatments. This project aims to demonstrate how our human stem cell-based in vitro steatohepatitis organoid model system mirrors patient's liver phenotype, which can be molecularly and mechanistically used for precise evaluation of heritable and non-heritable factors. Results from these studies will lead to novel drug discovery and diagnostic platforms against NASH, guided by organoid-based genotype- phenotype association, and, in the long term, transform the hepatology medicine through precision hepatology for the broad spectrum of inflammatory and fibrotic disorders in the liver.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative The different conditions making up inherited retinal degenerations may lead to distress, depression, and all forms of vison related disabilities, and therefore, represent a group of diseases that can be used to understand how best to intervene with care comprised of low vision rehabilitation and distress alleviating psychotherapy. By studying the patient experience of functional vision deficits and vision-related anxieties, we can provide low vision rehabilitation which will be enhanced with psychotherapy addressing the psychosocial needs of the patient. This project is relevant to the National Eye Institute’s goal to support applied clinical research concerning individual quality of life—with a particular focus on the patient perspective and encompassing blindness rehabilitation and brain plasticity, assistive devices and independent living, while also addressing depression in patients coping with vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ribonucleic acids (RNAs) are essential molecules responsible for transmitting genetic information, catalyzing reactions, and regulating gene expression, and, consequently, have been linked to bacterial pathogenesis, cardiovascular conditions, neurological disorders, mitochondrial diseases, and cancers. This work will take on questions about the structure, function, and dynamics of mitochondrial transfer RNA (tRNA), the proteins that act on these tRNAs, and associated disease-causing mutations using a combination of biochemistry (e.g., kinetic and binding assays, mass spectrometry) and structural biology (e.g., Cryo- EM, x-ray crystallography). Our studies will reveal how mitochondrial transfer RNAs are recognized and processed and help rationalize how patient-derived mitochondrial tRNA mutations alter tRNA stability and processing, which will allow us to seed the discovery of possible new therapeutic targets to treat mitochondrial diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This project will advance our theoretical understanding of human semantic memory while providing a set of diagnostic and clinical tools for detecting age-related cognitive impairment in a longitudinal cohort of older African American adults at high risk for dementia. One of our major goals is to disseminate tools for detecting subtle changes in naturalistic language samples that portend the onset of Alzheimer's Disease or an associated disorder. In addition to characterizing language and language change, we will disseminate a database of pupillary functioning spanning tasks, light reflexes, and rest.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) remains the leading cause of inheritable kidney disease, and the fourth leading cause of end stage renal disease. Outside of chronic dialysis or kidney transplant, prophylactic and intervention treatment targets and options remain limited. These studies will directly address the novel role of renal nerves in PKD progression, and potentially offer a new therapeutic mechanism to target for future PKD treatment.

PHR: NARRATIVE Protein synthesis is a key process in cellular function. In this proposal we seek to broaden our understanding of the mechanisms of protein synthesis and use that understanding to develop therapeutic approaches to overcome these harmful mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding cognitive trajectories associated with cancer and cancer treatment is particularly important among older adults who may be more susceptible to cancer-related cognitive impairment as cancer and cancer treatment potentially accelerate already ongoing aging processes. The overall objective of this proposal is to determine risk and biological mechanisms linking cancer, cancer treatment and cognitive functioning. This work may identify susceptibility factors for cognitive trajectories in older adults diagnosed with cancer which may be leveraged to risk-stratify individuals for cognitive decline and develop modifiable targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Opioids are commonly prescribed for a variety of pain states but are prone to tampering and diversion. Here we propose to develop subcutaneously injectable opioid depots that would provide on-demand adjustable analgesia suitable for the treatment of acute pain, and that would be highly tamper- and diversion-proof. The device would be controlled by a wearable or handheld light source.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) impose a significant healthcare burden and reduce quality of life yet risk factors are poorly defined. We propose to lead new efforts in understanding whether BK channels, negative regulators of bladder contraction, are a target of PCB induced voiding dysfunction and whether these channels represent a convergent target for gene x environment interactions. We propose to test to test the hypothesis that developmental exposure to PCBs increases bladder contractility leading to overactive voiding symptoms in part by altering BK channel regulatory subunits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Each time a cell divides it must produce an accurate copy of its genome. This process, termed DNA replication, is essential and defects in DNA replication can lead to mutations, chromosomal rearrangements and cancer. This project will use new technology to understand the molecular mechanisms that control how the genome is replicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a disorder of gut-brain interaction that affects up to 20% of school children worldwide. Children and adults with IBS may improve their symptoms when restricting fermentable carbohydrates from their diet – but this restriction is challenging, does not work in all individuals, and may have unintended health consequences. This proposal will begin to investigate a non-dietary restriction therapy by evaluating psyllium (a soluble fiber) given with meals for fermentable carbohydrate (fructan) induced childhood IBS symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Our recent discovery suggests the SOX2-mediated in vivo reprogramming strategy generated a great number of neurons for neural repair after injury, with reduced astroglial scar. The preliminary experiment clearly showed that reprogramming modulates the inhibitory glia scar to a permissive environment for a robust CST axonal regeneration following spinal cord injury. We will therefore investigate the alteration of the glial scar and pyramidal neurons underwent the reprogramming process, in order to manipulate this process through an optimize the reprogramming strategy to treat SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Even before the onset of the COVID pandemic, adolescent depression has been increasing, and health disparities and disparities in access to treatment have continued to widen. Yoga-based interventions, shown to be effective in treating depression in adults, may be promising in adolescents as well, thus providing an alternative to the already burdened mental health care system. We propose a multisite pilot trial in preparation for an adequately-powered multisite non-inferiority trial of yoga-based intervention vs. group cognitive- behavioral therapy for adolescents with mild to moderate depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Selective bacterial destruction of tumor tissues may offer improved outcomes compared to current chemotherapies for patients with colorectal liver metastasis (CRLM). Image-guided delivery of cyborg C. Novyi- NT functionalized with nanoparticles directly into the tumor blood supply via selectively placed catheters should permit bacteriolytic treatment of CRLM and the treatment efficacy will be further enhanced by blocking blood flow to the metastases after administration of the cyborg bacterial spores. Image guided delivery and follow-up imaging will provide confirmation of cyborg bacteria spore delivery to the metastases and tracking of tumor colonization for early predictions and optimization of patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCPyV) positive Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) is an ideal setting for identifying foreign viral epitopes in diverse HLA alleles that can be leveraged to develop targeted immunotherapies, including cancer vaccines. In this context, we propose to predict and physically identify, processed, presented, and conserved promiscuous HLA epitopes originating from MCPyV. We will validate the T cell immunogenicity of these viral epitopes and develop a nanodisc based off-the-shelf MCC cancer vaccine candidate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity has strong inflammatory underpinnings, which are associated with the development of type 2 diabetes (T2D), non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), however, the mechanisms by which obesity provokes aberrant inflammation have yet to be clearly defined. In this study, we aim to demonstrate that in obesity and hyperinsulinemia, RNA silencing machinery plays a critical role in generating and responding to pro-inflammatory small extracellular vesicles (sEVs) and therefore controls systemic inflammation and glucose metabolism. Our systematic approaches will reveal novel mechanisms of RNA silencing machinery in EV-mediated immunometabolic regulation in obesity and hyperinsulinemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The cardiac conduction system is specialized in the generation and propagation of electrical impulses from the atria to the ventricles to produce a highly coordinated muscle contraction. Cardiac conduction disorders (CCDs) are common arrhythmic disorders that impact the contraction of atria or ventricles. Understanding the molecular and cellular mechanisms leading to CCD may provide a foundation for new therapeutic strategies and the proposed work will elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which the mutation in lamin A/C promotes CCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mitotic spindle, the football-shaped cellular machine that segregates the replicated chromosomes into the two daughter cells, is formed by microscopic cellular structures called centrosomes, which are comprised of a highly interconnected network of ~150 proteins. Centrosome duplication occurs precisely once every cell cycle to ensure that dividing cells have exactly two centrosomes, and thus two poles of the football-shaped spindle. The goal of this project is to understand how centrosome assembly reactions and the capacity for spindle pole organization are confined to the centrosome, thereby preventing the formation of aberrant multipolar spindles that have the potential to generate cells with inaccurate chromosome numbers and promote tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have shown that the plasma contact system, which regulates both blood clotting and inflammation, is dysfunctional in human patients and mouse models of Alzheimer's disease (AD), a fatal neurodegenerative disorder. We will use various pharmacological and biochemical techniques to define the contribution of this system in AD pathogenesis. We will also examine the potential of inhibiting the contact system as a therapeutic target for AD and explore the mechanism-of-action of lecanemab, a new and promising FDA-approved therapy for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Currently, no FDA-approved disease-modifying osteoarthritis (OA) drugs are currently available to stop, slow, or reverse the progression of obesity-associated OA. In this study, two hallmarks of obesity, increased mechanical loading and alterations in adipose tissue metabolism, will be modeled in the microphysiological joint chip (miniJoint) as the physiologic stressors of OA. Through the complementary studies in the miniJoint and animal models, the mechanistic basis of obese adipose tissue-mediated pathological changes of joint elements in humans will be elucidated and help develop novel treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project will expand and improve the IPUMS Multigenerational Longitudinal Panel (MLP), the world’s largest longitudinal population data system. This massive data collection incorporates hundreds of millions of linked observations drawn from American censuses, surveys, vital records, and administrative data, creating a transformative shared resource for longitudinal analysis of aging and health. The the new data will advance fundamental knowledge about the causes and consequences of changes in health and well-being of the older population and will support research on the effects of public policies, social institutions, and environmental conditions on the health, well-being, and functioning of people, both over the life course and in their later years.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of smell and other neurological symptoms are prevalent in COVID-19 disease and can be long-lasting, significantly impairing quality of life; however, the underlying cellular mechanisms are poorly defined. We will use a new, genetically manipulatable mouse model that is susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection to delineate the mechanisms that underly acute and long-term loss of smell and identify the routes by which the virus can invade the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a rapidly progressive state of pulmonary failure associated with high morbidity and mortality, and severe cases require prolonged mechanical and ventilator support with limited therapeutic options. In the current proposal, we aim to advance a novel in vivo lung perfusion (IVLP) method as a surgical therapy to treat severe ARDS, including ARDS caused by SARS-CoV-2 infection. This strategy involves the controlled isolated perfusion of injured lungs with Steen solution for the delivery of targeted therapeutics to the injured lung inside the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nuclear envelope surrounds the cell’s DNA and is vital to cell function. This research aims to elucidate important steps in correct assembly and maintenance of the nuclear envelope. This work will generate new insight into human diseases associated with mutations in nuclear envelope proteins, as well as shed light on disease states, such as cancer, where rupture of the nuclear envelope can lead to DNA damage.

PHR: Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disease in which the immune system attacks and destroys the insulin- producing beta cells in the pancreas. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Open vascular reconstructions, such as bypass grafting and endarterectomy, remain the gold standard of surgical treatments for occlusive cardiovascular diseases. This project aims to understand the biology behind the epigenetics of neointimal hyperplasia, and to develop a potential effective means to treat neointimal hyperplasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The current standard of care for evaluation and surveillance of regional and metastatic disease in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma is 18F-FDG PET/CT scan, which is highly sensitive but not specific. Due to its nonspecific targeting of any tissue with high metabolism, FDG PET/CT produces a significant number of indeterminate findings and is of limited use for detecting tumors located in areas of high metabolic activity. To address this, we propose that imaging using a tumor-specific PET radiopharmaceutical can improve diagnostic specificity in head and neck cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma, a leading cause of blindness, is caused by the loss of retinal ganglion cells (RGC), which can continue despite clinical treatment to reduce intraocular pressure (IOP). We identified novel neuroprotective drugs that prevent RGC loss even when IOP is elevated, and developed a long-lasting, gel-forming eye drop technology for efficacious drug delivery to the posterior segment. We expect our system to be synergistic with current IOP- lowering glaucoma therapies, resulting in an improved treatment for glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  We propose image guided transcatheter intra-arterial (IA) delivery of Z-domain mediated aPD-L1 conjugated ferumoxytol (aPD-L1-Z-Fer) permitting combinational local immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) immunotherapy and irreversible electroporation (IRE) of hepatocellular carcinoma. Selective transcatheter IA delivery of our aPD-L1-Z-Fer in a combination with immunogenic IRE treatment will permit efficient local delivery of immunostimulatory ICB molecules, allow an increase in the dosage and improve their safety profile. This salient combination of local ICB immunotherapy and immunogenic IRE offers the potential to significantly improve longitudinal treatment outcomes in liver cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes results from the autoimmune destruction of the islet beta cell mediated in part by beta-cell dysfunction prior to autoimmune attack. Polyamine and hypusine production are important for the translation of a subset of RNAs involved in the unfolded protein response, ER stress, and cytokine response in the beta cell. Using novel mouse models and human samples, we will interrogate the polyamine/hypusine pathway specifically in the beta cell during the pathogenesis of type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Variety of genetic mutations can cause pediatric disease where white matter in the brain is destroyed or not properly formed. However, despite clinical genome sequencing many of these children with devastating brain disease remain undiagnosed. This project aims to resolve all cases of undiagnosed white matter disease using new sequencing technology combined with disease-specific model systems to provide novel insights into molecular targets for disease diagnosis and advance therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project narrative Eukaryotic protein kinases regulate important cellular processes through their ability to phosphorylate themselves and substrate proteins and alteration of the mechanisms that control kinase activation leads to pathological conditions including cancer. Here we will investigate a novel mechanism of kinase activation through hydroxylation of proline residues by proline hydroxylase enzymes. We will determine the functional impact of the signaling pathways converging on proline hydroxylases, the cancer phenotypes elicited in the mouse brain by dysregulation of this novel pathway of kinase activation and the consequences on the global proteome and phosphoproteome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Summary Pathological increases in adipose tissue, including white adipocytes studied here, are major risk factors for Type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular diseases, whereas brown adipose tissue has potential anti-obesity properties. White adipose tissue has an inherent plasticity to turn on the brown adipocyte gene program to increase energy expenditure. Therefore, understanding and manipulating the biological programs governing these two distinct adipose cell phenotypes may have therapeutic potential to combat obesity, insulin resistance, and heart disease.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This proposal is relevant to public health because it will introduce novel, nonperturbative, nondestructive, elasticity-based metrics and finite element modeling to the evaluation and management of keratoconus progression, a disease that is significantly more common than previously thought, and for laser vision correction for myopia, which is reaching epidemic proportions in most developed countries, including the US. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative  Neurons and glia form highly specific attachments during brain development. Disruption of neuron- glia attachments is associated with neurodevelopmental disorders, including autism and schizophrenia, as well as long-term neurological risk, including failure to recover from stroke or traumatic brain injury. This project uses a precisely defined neuron-glia attachment in the model organism C. elegans to identify the genes that enable a single neuron to select the correct glial partner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Renin released from juxtaglomerular cells, the first-step and rate-limiting enzyme of the circulating renin- angiotensin-aldosterone system, plays an essential role in the regulation of extracellular fluid volume and blood pressure. The most important among the control mechanisms of renin release is a pressure-sensing mechanism, denominated as the intrarenal baroreceptor, however, the nature of the intrarenal baroreceptor and in particular, the central questions about this pressure-sensing mechanism: what the exact mechano-sensor is in juxtaglomerular cells and how it controls renin synthesis and secretion, remain elusive. This project aims to determine whether syndecan-1 is a key mechano-sensor of the intrarenal baroreceptor mechanism in juxtaglomerular cells that controls renin synthesis and secretion, regulates the circulating renin-angiotensin- aldosterone system, and thus contributes to the maintenance of fluid and electrolyte homeostasis and blood pressure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This project renewal will leverage the power of serial biomarkers measures to investigate the interrelationships of novel microbiome-generated AAA metabolites with initiation, extent, and clinical onset of subclinical CVD, clinical CHD, and total mortality. Primary aims include: (1) to investigate the independent relationships of serial measures of plasma aromatic amino acid (AAA)-derived microbial metabolites with longitudinal onset and progression of subclinical CVD; (2) to investigate the independent relationships of serial measures of plasma AAA-derived microbial metabolites with incident CVD events; (3) to investigate the independent relationships of serial measures of plasma AAA-derived microbial metabolites with total mortality. Secondary Aims include focuses to investigate (a) the independent dietary, lifestyle, and demographic predictors of plasma AAA- derived microbial metabolites and change in these metabolites over time in two diverse community-based populations; and (b) potential effect modification of metabolite-outcome associations by age, sex, race/ethnicity, socioeconomic status, background diet, lipid-lowering medication use, renal function, and prevalent CVD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In 2010, more than 1 million infants born preterm (at less than 37 weeks of gestation) died worldwide, making it the second leading cause of death in children under the age of 5 years. The overarching goals of this study are to develop blood tests for both the early detection and ongoing prediction of pregnancy complications that result in preterm birth (PTB). The proposed study will improve our understanding of the biology of preterm birth and lead to the development of new diagnostic/screening tools to help us identify women at high risk of preterm birth for whom an intervention may be tested and for whom intervention is most critically needed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Valvular heart disease affects over 2.5% of the US population. While transcatheter valve interventions can substantially decrease patient risk in comparison to open surgery, existing catheters do not provide the capability to easily cut or remove diseased valve tissue as is done during open surgery. The goal of this project is to increase patient eligibility and to enhance the accessibility of transcatheter valve repair by developing easy-to-use catheter technology for cutting diseased valve tissue during valve replacement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Across the state of Maryland, communities of color and low wealth populations are differentially burdened by environmental hazards and the cumulative impacts of chemical and non-chemical stressors and structural factors including pathogenic infrastructure that produce environmental health disparities (i.e., environmental injustice). To better identify and characterize environmental justice (EJ) communities, we plan to update Maryland Environmental Justice Screen (MD EJSCREEN), an environmental justice screening and mapping (EJSM) tool by the integration of air quality data and use of mixed methods approach- stakeholder feedback through focus groups and interviews and advanced statistical and geostatistical methods. This project is relevant to public health because it may: (1) help track disparities in air pollution exposure; (2) improve our capacity to track cumulative impacts of chemical and non-chemical stressors; (3) better visualize and track exposure-disease associations including health disparities at the neighborhood level; and (4) assist with microtargeting high risk areas that need mitigation strategies and investments to eliminate environmental injustice and improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance to public health: Differences in genome sequence underlie susceptibility to virtually every human disease, and predicting the effects of specific sequence differences is a crucial step in improving diagnosis, prevention, and treatment. Such predictions are currently challenging for differences that lead to changes in proteins, and all but impossible for differences that may instead alter the abundance of proteins. The proposed research will enable development of more accurate predictive models of the effects on health of all types of sequence sequence differences with currently unclear significance, leading to better diagnostic precision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) affects up to 12% of the United States population and lacks any effective therapies. We and others have recently generated compelling evidence that low doses of the commercially available generic drug digoxin can reduce steatosis, inflammation, and fibrosis in several murine models of NASH, and can reduce inflammation in healthy human subjects. The proposed research to ascertain that digoxin improves human NASH will be transformative in providing care for this patient population and of significant relevance to public health; it will also be pertinent to NIH’s mission of fostering innovative research strategies and their applications as a basis for ultimately improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a complex, heritable brain disorder without known effective treatment. The proposed methods and tools will have considerable potential for discovery of genetic biomarkers to help monitor the disease progression and provide insights of downstream molecular mechanism toward the development of Alzheimer’s disease. These results can help with candidate screening in clinical trials and provide stratified risk groups to facilitate the development of therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will improve the automatic analysis of longitudinal, multi-time point PET/CT images of lymphoma by developing contextually-aware and multimodal vision-language deep learning algorithms. Quantitative PET metrics are highly predictive of outcome for lymphoma and could be used to improve the efficacy of PET-adapted therapy, but quantification of whole-body PET/CT images is time consuming and automated analysis of interim- therapy images is technically challenging. This project will address these challenges by designing and validating deep learning PET analysis algorithms that can simultaneously consider baseline and interim PET scans, thus mimicking the processes used by physicians, and also by designing semi-supervised multimodal algorithms that can use the information in radiology narrative reports for enhanced image analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The service life of dental composite restorations is estimated to be about 10 years, with replacement mainly due to recurrent caries caused by bacterial biofilms forming at the margins and within interfacial gaps. The proposed project will design and develop new divalent metal ions releasing dental materials to promote the oral microbiome diversity and extend the longevity of dental restorative materials, thus contributing to the NIH's aim of advancing human health through fundamental research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  As the most numerous non-neuronal cell types in the mammalian brain, astrocytes are proposed to regulate neuronal function via intracellular Ca2+-dependent signaling, which becomes deranged in numerous neurological and psychiatric disorders. The goal of this project is to elucidate the contribution of astrocyte Ca2+ signaling to the prefrontal neural circuit function and avoidance behavior. The proposed research is highly relevant to a broad range of mental disorders and may guide the development of innovative treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE End stage liver disease accounts for nearly 80,000 deaths a year in the United States, and we have less than 6,000 donor livers of adequate quality for transplantation. Increasing numbers of donor livers are discarded due to fatty liver disease because of the danger of post-transplant failure, and this clinical trial will use normothermic perfusion to assess and improve the quality of fatty livers to allow them to be safely transplanted. We will also develop new techniques to accurately assess the safety and transplantability of donor livers, as well as identify potentially therapeutic targets for intervention during normothermic machine perfusion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal will develop novel methods using expansion microscopy to characterize the three- dimensional structure of the genome. These methods will reveal the spatial organization of different regulatory interactions in the genome with near nucleosome resolution, with the goal of understanding how different parts of the genome interact to regulate gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: CENTRE FOR ADDICTION AND MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A core symptom of body dysmorphic disorder (BDD) is perceptual distortions for appearance, which contributes to poor insight and delusionality, limits engagement in treatment, and puts individuals at risk for relapse. Results from this revised study, adding a body processing experiment to the existing face processing experiments, will provide a more comprehensive understanding of factors accounting for a broad range of appearance concerns in BDD. This will lay the groundwork for next-step translational perceptual retraining approaches to address face and body perceptual distortions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE In day-to-day life, we often flexibly select actions based on what we anticipate the outcomes will be. Stressors and adversities lead to failures in flexible goal seeking, causing organisms to defer to familiar, routinized behaviors that can contribute to compulsions, smoking, over-eating, and other health concerns. Our goal is to understand the learning and memory processes controlling action flexibility, and how they are disrupted by prolonged social isolation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Visual cortical prostheses represent a promising treatment for patients with acquired blindness, but so far have these devices have used relatively simple strategies to deliver electrical stimulation to the visual cortex. This project will test whether use of stochastic variability in electrical stimulation pulse timing and amplitude, and use of electrical stimulation pulses precisely timed relative to ongoing alpha rhythms, can lead to better activation of visual pathways, and enhanced production of visual percepts. If effective these electrical stimulation strategies will lead to development of visual cortical prostheses that are safer and more effective, and could improve the performance of other brain computer interfaces.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative-Relevance to Public Health We propose to develop a tumor cell and vasculature-targeted, cold-responsive nanotechnology-potentiated cryoimmunotherapy for treating both primary and metastatic cancer. This novel cancer therapy strategy may be invaluable for combating cancer metastasis and recurrence, which are the main causes of mortality in breast and many other types of cancer, to minimize the mortality and morbidity of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application uses data from a large group of well-characterized subjects from the COPDGene Study, which includes 5 and 10 year follow-ups and extensive available genomics datasets. We will use the state-of-the-art Phage ImmunoPrecipitation Sequencing (PhIP-seq) technology to efficiently and comprehensively profile 3,000 blood samples for autoantibodies and antibodies from prior viral infections. We will determine whether infections with certain viruses and/or the development of specific autoantibodies are associated with more rapid progression of COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study directly addresses one of the key challenges in the field of geroscience: What are the conserved mechanisms of longevity across evolutionarily divergent organisms? This proposal will address this question by analyzing the function of conserved essential genes in regulation of longevity. As a result we will reveal new aging genes and unknown components of conserved aging pathways with mechanistic framework that can be tested directly in mammalian systems and might ultimately lead to the development of new therapies to increase human healthspan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT One in nine women is expected to develop breast cancer during her lifetime, and 1 in 27 will die of it. In our recent study, we have demonstrated success in treating BRCA1-mutant cancer cells with E3 ligase deficiency using a new therapeutic approach but currently there is no testing available to identify patients who have a loss of E3 ligase function BRCA1 variant. In this study, we propose to develop new biomarkers that will allow us to identify BRCA1 deficiency by examining the expression profile of the ubiquitination protein substrates of BRCA1 so that it can allow us to stratify patients that can be most benefit from our proposed treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative White adipose tissue has a central role in maintaining whole-body metabolic health, thus it is critical to understand how adipocyte develops and how it remodels in response to high caloric diet. We propose that TET3 is a critical epigenetic regulator in homeostatic control of adipocyte development under chow-fed conditions and diet-induced adipose expansion. We address this question by using integrated physiological, genomic, and epigenomic profiling, and targeted epigenetic editing approaches on a newly-developed APC-specific Tet3 KO mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mothers with substance use disorders face unprecedented stress in their roles as parents working to care for their children while maintaining healthy recovery. Mothering from the Inside Out (MIO) is the first attachment- based parenting intervention designed specifically for mothers in recovery from substance use disorders that has been shown to have bigenerational benefit in multiple randomized controlled trials. This project will: (a) test the effectiveness of MIO among women in outpatient addiction treatment under ‘real-world’ conditions, (b) further elucidate the MIO mechanism of change associated with improvements in caregiver behavior and maternal mental health outcomes, and (c) assess key implementation constructs to support optimal uptake and treatment in future dissemination studies; closing an important science-to-service gap for an underserved population in an effort to support maternal and child health simultaneously.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Intrinsic and extrinsic nerves modulate movements of the GI tract, however the underlying patterning of GI motility depends upon intrinsic myogenic behaviors. The propulsive contractions of the colon (colonic migrating motor complexes or CMMC) are thought to be due to neurogenic motor patterns programmed within the myenteric plexus and direct innervation of smooth muscle cells. Recent work on this project has introduced important new information about how colonic motor activity is initiated and propagated. We are investigating mechanisms and functions of interstitial cells of Cajal (ICC) of which there are four classes in colonic muscles. These cells generate spontaneous, stochastic Ca2+ release events that activate Cl- channels (encoded by Ano1) in the plasma membrane, causing transmembrane inward currents. Neural inputs regulate Ca2+ signaling in ICC, thus modulating the myogenic drive on colonic motility. Loss or disabling of the basic functions of ICC (e.g. blocking Ca2+ signaling or ANO1 channels) causes defects in colonic motor activity, including decreased smooth muscle excitability, inhibition of phasic contractions, and disruption in major motility patterns, such as CMMCs. Because neural signals are transduced by ICC, damage to ICC makes it difficult or impossible to restore colonic motility by enhanced neural output. In the next funding period mechanisms responsible for Ca2+ transients in colonic ICC-MY and regulation of these events by enteric motor neurons will be characterized. Integration of activity between smooth muscle cells and ICC will be studied, and mechanisms responsible for initiation and propagation of propulsive contractions will be clarified. Animal models of ICC loss will also be characterized to develop new tools for testing therapeutics for motility disorders associated with ICC loss (e.g. slow transit constipation).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Aortic aneurysm is a life-threatening disease characterized by the dilation of the vessel wall due to loss of vascular integrity and dysfunction of resident cells. The studies of this proposal will investigate the causal relationship between modifications of aortic vascular cell’s extracellular environment and changes in cell genome organization and gene expression through processes called epigenetic mechanisms. The proposed studies will greatly enhance our understanding of the mechanisms regulating vascular cell behavior in aneurysm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Growing evidence shows that noise exposure and hearing loss induce profound changes in the central auditory system from brainstem to cortex and that dysfunction of ion channels, termed channelopathies, has been linked to many neurological disorders, including deafness and tinnitus. This project aims to study calcium permeable ion channels and their synaptic function, and how hearing loss affects these ion channels and synaptic properties. The research proposed here will establish a new view of the role of presynaptic calcium permeable channels in synaptic function and their role after injury, providing the basic groundwork for future strategies for the treatment of channelopathies and hearing disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Candida albicans is frequently found in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract where its presence is highly relevant to public health as it directs local and systemic immune responses, as well as has the potential to translocate out of this niche to cause life-threatening systemic infections. The research outlined here will provide detailed mechanistic information into how C. albicans is able to grow in the GI tract including competition with the repertoire of bacterial species found in this niche.

PHR: Project Narrative. Improper gene expression causes many diseases, including developmental defects and cancer. The goal of this project is to understand the fundamental processes by which genes are expressed and regulated. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  Removing membranes from the surface of the retina is among the most common vitreoretinal surgeries performed in the US. This delicate procedure can have a high incidence of intraoperative complications, that could benefit from the use of robotic assistance. Current limitations and challenges of robotic approaches include cumbersome setup, limited access to important portions of the retina, and lack of force feedback to the surgeon. To consistently enable human utilization of robotics in epiretinal membrane peeling, we propose to develop a novel system that will fuse tool-tissue force information with intraoperative guidance via a high-dexterity robotic assistant surgical platform with cooperative and teleoperated control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Periodontitis is a chronic disease affecting millions of people globally and has complex underlying cellular and molecular drivers. Here, we aim to leverage a systems biology functional approach to dissect the cellular states driving periodontitis and the added burden of type 2 diabetes. We will characterize clinical samples by single-cell expression profiling, perform advanced computational analyses, and test regulators of cell state and signaling that may offer future novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission and public health because it aims to determine the cellular, molecular and electrophysiological mechanisms of mechanical regulation of the sinoatrial node, the primary natural pacemaker of the heart. Our work will define how specialized cardiac cell membrane mechanosensitive domains and associated signaling molecules contribute to both physiological regulation of the sinoatrial node and its remodeling and dysfunction during chronically elevated mechanical overload in hypertension. The potential impact of this research is high because the mechanistic insights gained from it can serve as a foundation for developing innovative therapeutic strategies aimed at preventing sinus node dysfunction in hypertensive individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S.-wide burden on emergency medical services (EMS) systems associated with environmental exposures remains unknown. In this study, we will utilize a national database of 911 calls, the National Emergency Medical Services Information System (NEMSIS), to test the hypothesis that short-term air pollution and temperature exposures are associated with EMS transports. We will also measure the impact of exposure misclassification on the risk estimates by leveraging recent advancements in exposure assessment tools (low- cost sensors and mobility data) and unique information in EMS data on event locations and times.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rapidly evolving antibiotic resistance requires a matching effort to develop novel and effective antimicrobial agents. Particularly, infections caused by emerging carbapenem-resistant Enterobacterales and carbapenem- resistant Acinetobacter baumannii, which are difficult to treat, have been recognized as an urgent threat. The goal of the proposed project is to study preexisting cefiderocol resistance and heteroresistance without prior cefiderocol exposure and the evolution of cefiderocol resistance after cefiderocol exposure in vitro and in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Veno-arterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA ECMO) may enable survival of patients with severe acute cardiogenic shock (CS), which kills 80,000 Americans each year, but may also cause harm to the failing heart. A clinical management change of unloading/decompressing the heart during VA ECMO for CS may improve survival for these patients. Understanding the physiologic effects of unloading on the heart is an important step towards conducting clinical trials of unloading during VA ECMO for CS and improving patient outcomes during ECMO and CS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT  The broad, long-term objective of our research is to improve the health of the ~1.5 billion people in the world with chronic liver disease that can progress to liver failure, liver cancer, and liver-related death. We seek to develop and validate non-invasive methods of assessing the activity of chronic liver disease. These methods will reduce the need for biopsy, permit earlier diagnosis, and facilitate more effective treatment, thereby pre- venting the serious long-term complications of chronic liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will develop a paired imaging/tissue biomarker of sensitivity to PARP inhibitors (PARPi) that can be used for patient selection, visualization of drug-target engagement, and potentially long-term dose modulation. In breast cancer, where PARPi are currently used largely in the setting of metastatic disease, the ability to predict response would also provide a critically needed tool to stratify patients for clinical trials testing neoadjuvant PARPi therapy/therapy combinations. If successful, this research could lead to a new way to functionally characterize PARP-1 expressing cancer, guide targeted therapy, and assess therapeutic response and resistance.

PHR: Project Narrative Our scientific premise is that maladaptive changes in DNA modifications and chromatin accessibility accumulate in the retinal pigmented epithelium (RPE) with aging leading to RPE dysfunction and contributing to age-related macular degeneration (AMD) pathogenesis. Whether RPE epigenetic aging is exacerbated by poor diet and can be slowed by ketogenic diet will also be tested. These studies will provide fundamental knowledge to the field and new biological/functional insights into RPE aging as well as identify RPE-specific epigenomic targets for manipulation to maintain RPE function with aging and prevent AMD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will experimentally evaluate the ability of ultra-processed foods to activate reward, attention, and memory regions that influence eating behavior compared to minimally-processed foods, investigate the relative role of the higher caloric content versus the flavor enhancers of ultra-processed foods to engage these regions using a 2 x 2 experimental design, and test whether ultra-processed foods are more effective in promoting the incentive salience of food cues than minimally-processed foods, which is important because elevated reward region response to food cues predicts future weight gain. It will also test whether individuals who show the greatest activation in reward, attention, and memory regions in response to ultra- processed foods and stronger food reward cue learning are at risk for greater ad lib intake of ultra-processed foods and future body fat gain. This study should advance knowledge regarding the mechanisms through which ultra-processed foods contribute to overeating and guide the design of more effective obesity prevention programs and treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We posit that a barrier to the treatment of T2D diabetes relates to broad difficulties with emotional regulation (ER) that are not diagnosis specific but lead to Diabetes Distress (DD) and difficulty in coping with medical regimens, and other aspects of diabetes self-care, when confronted with the psychosocial stressors associated with having diabetes. Recent work suggests an important relationship between emotional regulation, elevated DD scores and elevated A1c levels – characteristics that may impact up to 25% of all those with T2D; preliminary data using emotion-focused interventions suggest that elevated DD and A1c levels can be reduced in PWD with T2D. In this project we propose to adapt our emotion-focused behavioral intervention (EFBI) from a one-to-one intervention (I-EFBI) to a group intervention (G-EFBI) and to conduct a pilot RCT study to determine if G-EFBI is a feasible, acceptable and, possibly, efficacious intervention compared to an “Attentional Control” intervention in PWD with T2D and elevated DD and A1c levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic mutations in the sodium channel gene SCN8A cause a severe, early-onset seizure disorder along with significant motor impairment. We have generated a unique new mouse model that is the first to exhibit the motor impairment characteristic of SCN8A epilepsy. This proposal seeks to investigate the pathophysiologic mechanisms underlying motor dysfunction to provide new information that will help guide development of treatments for this debilitating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About 51.8% (129 million) of American adults had at least one chronic condition, which is attributed to the total direct and indirect cost of $3.7 trillion and demands imperatively patients to self-manage their health across their lifespans. However, most existing self-management interventions and apps do not enable users with chronic health conditions, such as multiple sclerosis (MS), to actively utilize resources, solve problems, develop self- efficacy, and empower decision-making. We will develop and validate MyMSMentor for people with MS, which will be generalizable to other chronic conditions and devices, to maximize their lifelong capacity of self- management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Many patients with serious COVID infection continue to have lung problems long after the acute infection has resolved. This may be due to persistence of SARS-CoV-2 products in the lung stimulating unwanted lung inflammation and immune responses. Our study will examine in detail the lung immune and inflammatory environment in patients with post COVID chronic lung disease with the goals of (1) linking lung disease to specific types of immune and inflammatory responses, (2) determining whether this is due to persistent viral products in the lung, and (3) assessing protective versus potentially harmful immune responses in the pathogenesis of post- COVID lung disease. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Approximately 78% of Veterans are overweight or obese, which costs millions of dollars in medical and non- medical costs. While treatment of obesity is consistent with the priorities of the VA through personalized, proactive Veteran-driven care, patient compliance has proven inefficient in maintaining long-term weight loss. The central mechanisms regulating macronutrient intake are poorly defined. Our published and preliminary data support the hypothesis that FGF21 acts on the central nervous system to suppress simple sugar intake and regulate sweet taste preference. The proposed research is directly relevant to VA healthcare because of the high disease burden and enormous health care cost that obesity and diabetes is causing in veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Obesity is a major public health problem that underlies many medical conditions, including diabetes, vascular disease, and brain dysfunction, which result from several pathophysiological mechanisms. The proposed project involves a retrospective analysis of an existing bariatric surgery cohort to examine long-term (>36 months) cognitive and brain outcomes following bariatric surgery in severely obese adults. A prospective study will also be conducted to understand the role of the vagus in cognitive and brain outcomes through two manipulations in the context of bariatric surgery (vagotomy and transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Advanced prostate cancer has increasingly developed a lethal neuroendocrine phenotype as a consequence of widespread use of highly potent antiandrogens in castration-resistant prostate cancer. This is a significant clinical challenge raising an urgent need to develop new effective molecularly targeted therapies to improve patient survival. The proposed studies aim to define the mechanistic basis and functional role of tryptophan hydroxylase 1 and its downstream effectors in neuroendocrine prostate cancer. Our studies will provide new fundamental molecular insights into neuroendocrine prostate cancer pathogenesis and progression, laying the foundations for developing a repurposing targeted strategy capable of rapid clinical translation to treat neuroendocrine prostate cancer, which currently remains incurable.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: There is a high prevalence of pain disorders among US veterans when compared to the general population, with 50% of older veterans reporting chronic pain. The etiology of pain disorders in this population is complex, but recent evidence suggests that alcohol drinking may worsen pain symptoms and predispose to pain disorders in later life. These studies will test our overarching hypothesis that chronic alcohol use alters activity in serotonin circuits that modulate central pain circuits. This investigation is directly relevant to veterans because it will identify new potential targets for the treatment of pain disorders exacerbated by chronic alcohol use, which is increasingly common among military personnel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human brain contains billions of neurons organized into neural circuits by synaptic connections, forming the basis for perception, thought, and behavior. This project examines molecular mechanisms that build electrical synapses, a critical, understudied connection type used during development and in mature circuits. Defects in electrical synapse formation are tied to autism, epilepsy, myopia, and other neurogenetic disorders, thus a mechanistic understanding of their formation will provide a foundation to treat complex neural disorders.

PHR: This grant proposal aims to develop, validate, and optimize a noninvasive MRI method for quantifying and mapping pathological changes in liver microstructure (notably, cell sizes and densities) in vivo. The proposal will focus on demonstrating the clinical role of qTDS in assessing hepatic inflammation in patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and the ultimate goal of generating a non-invasive diagnostic metric for NASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Antisocial behaviors are common and severe in behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD), yet our understanding of why these behaviors occur remains incomplete. This project will test the hypothesis that aggressive and rule-breaking antisocial behaviors are distinct behaviorally, with different associated patterns of brain damage and different changes to socioemotional neuropsychological functions. Study results will improve clinical understanding for antisocial behaviors in bvFTD patients and guide future efforts to identify, prevent, and treat these problematic behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Perinatal hypoxic-ischemic (HI) brain injury causes long-term neurological disability, morbidity, and death in infants. Using neonatal mouse models, we will uncover the mechanisms of redox imbalance in the brain that leads to oxidative stress after the oxygen deprivation/reperfusion associated with HI injury. Our line of research will pursue two recently identified metabolic pathways that may help to prevent, rather than just mitigate the damage, and to protect the infant’s brain from HI injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Combination therapies cure some cases of aggressive lymphoma, but attempts to make improved drug combinations are rarely successful in clinical trials. This project will develop computational models of multiple drugs acting on populations of cancer cells, within populations of patients, to simulate clinical trials. We will use these models to understand why some combination therapies have succeeded and others have failed in past trials, and to assist the design of forthcoming trials of new combination therapies to give them the greatest likelihood of curing more patients with lymphoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The use of complex, multi-component interventions has become an increasingly important strategy for cardiovascular disease prevention, screening and treatment, but in the face of the complexity of these interventions it is difficult to specify before a trial launches the optimal intervention package and its optimal intervention component “doses”, as existing non-adaptive and adaptive methods require. Previously, we established “Learn-As-you-GO” or LAGO designs for logistic regression for a single binary outcome, where the intervention package is increasingly refined within each successive stage, optimizing for cost-effectiveness and the attainment of pre-planned study goals. In this project, we will develop the mathematical theory and open- source software for adaptive LAGO designs for the range of outcome data typically encountered and across a number of design options not covered by our initial 2021 Annals of Statistics paper, focusing on cost- effectiveness, reaching a pre-planned study goal at pre-specified statistical power even when pre-trial expectations are not met, and comparisons of LAGO to existing non-adaptive designs, motivated by the EXTRA-CVD (U01HL142099) and PULESA-Uganda (UG3HL154501) studies, the latter of which is an ongoing NHLBI-supported project for which the contact PI serves as study statistician that is funded to apply LAGO at two pre-planned stages after baseline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hispanic adults face disparities in obesity, type 2 diabetes, and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease relative to non- Hispanic white adults, driven in part by higher consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs). Requiring sugar warnings on SSB containers could reduce excessive SSB purchases and consumption, but studies have not examined how such warnings influence SSB purchases especially in Hispanic populations. The proposed research will evaluate the effectiveness of sugar warnings on SSBs at reducing SSB purchases among Hispanic adults in the US and in Mexico.
