IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dystrophin associated heart dysfunction is a leading cause of death in patients with Duchenne and Becker Muscular dystrophy (DMD/BMD) and carriers of DMD and BMD (MDC); however, the evolution of heart dysfunction is not well-understood. The central objectives of this proposal are to elucidate this evolution of heart dysfunction in patients with DMD/BMD/MDC, identify measures from cardiac MRI images that can predict death or significant heart disease, and create a risk toolkit accessible to clinicians around the world. This study will create a large clinical and cardiac MRI registry of dystrophin associated heart dysfunction and will utilize advanced image analysis techniques, including deep learning neural networks, to comprehensively evaluate every patient; this proposal has the potential to improve the quality of life in patients with dystrophin associated heart dysfunction by allowing for earlier and more intensive therapy in patients with severe disease and by identifying surrogate outcome measures for use in therapeutic trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In response to drug use, brain transcription factors regulate gene expression changes within the cells that comprise brain reward regions, which is thought to drive the damaging behavioral changes that define drug addiction. Here, we propose research utilizing synthetic biology approaches to reprogram the function of key brain transcription factors to resolve their exact contribution in drug-specific transcription and behaviors. This research and the application of these synthetic transcription factors has the potential to be used as preclinical tools to uncover novel targets for pharmacotherapies to combat the pathogenesis of specific drug addictions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular diseases (CVD) are one of the leading causes of death and disability worldwide, resulting in a heavy economic burden. Novel population-specific risk factors for CVD have recently been identified from genome-wide association studies (GWAS) in individuals from non-European ancestries; here, using multi- ancestry GWAS, we develop and apply a suite of computational and experimental innovations to increase identification of causal variants, relevant cell types and target genes. In particular, we introduce scalable methods to unite high-throughput genetic perturbations and precise insertion of human genetic variants with single-cell sequencing, which can pinpoint causal variants for CVD and the genes they regulate locally and globally across the genome.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Multisensory attention skills—selective attention to unitary audiovisual events (e.g. face and voice of a person speaking), and maintaining and efficiently shifting attention in the context of distracting events—are key building blocks for later development. Using our two new individual difference measures, this research will build an exciting new body of knowledge about the typical development of multisensory attention skills from infancy (3 months) through pre-adolescence (11 years) and reveal the pathways through which they support language and socio-emotional functioning, and in turn, executive functions, and academic achievement. We will do so at a level of detail that is necessary for identifying risk for atypical development in disorders such as autism, and for guiding applications and interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diagnosis of lupus nephritis (LN) using conventional histopathology is challenging and fraught with pitfalls. We propose combining histopathology with information from two independent optical imaging modalities that provide additional biochemical and macromolecular context to LN diagnosis. We develop a multi-modal histology platform to collect co-registered images and combine data using a deep learning architecture to improve the accuracy of LN diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will lead to new knowledge about the causes of imbalance and falls in older adults and to innovative approaches to study sensory contributions to imbalance and central sensory integration. These advancements will provide a foundation for mitigating falls in older adults, including through the use of newly developed therapeutics. The project is relevant to NIH’s mission because falls in older adults are responsible for substantial disability and are the leading cause of trauma- related death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will utilize high resolution adaptive optics scanning light ophthalmoscopy (AOSLO) to investigate the structure, function, and treatment of photoreceptors in human patients with blinding inherited retinal degenerations (IRDs). This study will: 1) Determine the AOSLO cellular phenotypes of cone and retinal pigment epithelial mosaics in IRDs; 2) Correlate cone function with AOSLO structural phenotypes in IRDs; and 3) Investigate the AOSLO structural and functional response to gene therapy. The information gained in this study will aid future studies of IRD, and will pave the way for AOSLO imaging technology to advance gene, cell, and molecular therapies for blinding conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is a disease identified by increased pressure within the eye and progressive death of neurons in the back of the eye that eventually leads to blindness. Current treatment options for disease only include reducing elevated pressure, but patients are sometimes resistant to established treatments. We will use human neurons and a regenerative therapy to rescue visual neurons from dying which will provide progress towards clinical trials in glaucoma patients with a focus on precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical researchers collect brain images from multiple modalities to enhance diagnosis and treatment of neurode  generative disorders (NDs), yet their impact is constrained due to a lack statistical methods that model information both within and across images. This proposal develops a new Bayesian framework to address the theoretical and computational challenges of jointly modeling structural and network brain images, exploiting their linkage to ad  vance the study of ND. The goal is to provide imaging statisticians and practitioners with a set of inferential tools that harness the potential of existing multimodal imaging data to improve the study of cognitive theory, disease progression, and biomarker development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE People who experience repeated bouts of circadian misalignment, such as shift workers, are at higher risk of developing cardiovascular disease and Type 2 diabetes compared to daytime workers; however, there have been few attempts to develop strategies to improve health in shift workers. Highly controlled inpatient studies suggest that a circadian-based eating strategy in which energy intake is restricted to the daytime period during circadian misalignment improves markers of cardiometabolic health. The goal of this project is to translate this strategy of timed eating to a population of free-living shift workers to identify a non-pharmacological strategy that could mitigate cardiometabolic disease risk in this population, which represents more than 25% of the US workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Targeting dsRNA pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) in tumors represents a promising strategy to treat patients with melanoma and other tumor types. In this proposal we address gaps in knowledge that limit the translation of dsRNA PRR-targeting strategies, determining the effects of dsRNA sensing on T cells, evaluating the efficacy of targeting single versus multiple sensing pathways and identifying the tumors most likely to respond to therapy. If successful, this work will help define the rules that govern tumor and immune responses to dsRNA and advance novel therapeutic strategies that target RIG-I and ADAR1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The AML1-ETO fusion protein causes acute leukemia in children and adults, and we have been studying the fundamental mechanisms that underlie its leukemia promoting ability. By combining biochemical approaches with biological and genomic data from human cell lines and mouse models, we have uncovered a range of oncogenic functions promoted by AML1-ETO. We are focused on targeting the co-factors required for AML1-ETO oncogenic functions in order to develop effective targeted approaches to this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The synaptic organizers, neurexins and their partners, play a central role in severe neuropsychiatric disorders including autism spectrum disorder and schizophrenia. These proteins constitute a suite of molecules that regulate synapse development, either by forming trans-synaptic bridges or by dynamically regulating these bridges. Elucidating the mechanisms of these molecules will reveal how they guide synapse development, shape neural circuits and regulate circuit plasticity, as also will lay the foundation to investigate highly innovative, mechanism-based therapies that target specific synapses and select circuits to ameliorate CNS disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuroprognostication of unresponsive survivors following cardiac arrest, crucial to providing closure to families and to guide allocation of scarce critical care resources, is challenging. Prior models of prognostication arose from studies plagued by the self-fulfilling prophecy bias introduced by the withdrawal of life support due to perceived poor neurological prognosis, and more accurate models of prognostication are needed, with greater understanding of the usefulness and limitations of commonly utilized tools in the present day. We propose a joint study between the US and Brazil, where the practice of withdrawal of life support is virtually nonexistent, and will capitalize on the expertise of experienced investigators and collaborators utilizing the unbiased population in Brazil.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite extensive clinical testing, mesenchymal stem/stromal cell (MSC)-based therapies continue to yield suboptimal patient outcomes due to knowledge gaps in quality attributes that confer therapeutic efficacy, which explains why most clinical studies produce MSCs using similar donor selection and manufacturing processes to treat medically unrelated diseases. To address this problem, we developed a CLinical Indications Prediction (CLIP) scale that predicts inter-donor differences in MSC potency for a range of clinically relevant activities. Building on this discovery, in this proposal we propose to use the CLIP scale to interrogate how donor selection and academic and industry-based manufacturing platforms impact MSC product potency and use this information to produce products of defined potency that are tailored for specific disease indications to enhance their efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: We propose that convergent effects of endogenous brain neuromodulatory chemicals may be essential to limiting inter-individual variability of neural systems and shaping consistent neural activity. We develop a mathematical framework for neural output variability and use the crustacean stomatogastric system, one of the best-understood neural circuits for studying neuromodulation, to experimentally explore this hypothesis. Our work will provide insight into general principles of how the nervous system produces reliable activity in face of significant inter-individual variability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairments in psychotic disorders are among the strongest predictors of poor functional outcomes in patients. We have identified and replicated a novel brain circuit linked to multiple cognitive deficits in psychosis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The increase in longevity of the population has stalled in recent years, while socioeconomic inequalities in health and prosperity persist into older ages both in the UK and the USA. The multidisciplinary English Longitudinal Study of Ageing collects longitudinal data from a large population sample to help us understand the determinants and consequences of these issues for quality of life, cognitive impairment including Alzheimer’s Disease, and healthy aging. Repeated measures of health and disability, economic circumstances, social participation, cognitive and physical function, wellbeing, biology and genetics are relevant both to public policy and scientific investigations, and comparisons with the Health and Retirement Study provide insight into the drivers of these processes in the USA and England.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies will (1) determine the evolution of genetic pathways altered as manganese (Mn) exposure extends from acute to chronic, and whether any such effects are persistent after cessation of chronic Mn overload, (2) evaluate the concurrent and persistent functional consequences of acute versus chronic Mn exposures and the influence of neural cell type, neurotransmitter-type, and genetic sex on the magnitude versus types of genetic pathways and functional outcomes altered, and (3) explore the mechanistic basis of chronic/persistent Mn neurotoxicity phenotypes via metabolic analysis, with pharmacological and genetic manipulation of signaling and metabolic pathways in C. elegans and hiPSC neural model systems. Our highly interactive experimental design brings innovative and complementary expertise to assess shared genetic networks of Mn-induced chronic neurotoxicity with translation from C. elegans to humans. We test the hypothesis that chronic Mn neurotoxicity is caused by a response to the impact of acute elevated Mn on neuronal cell signaling systems for which Mn normally acts as an essential co-factor.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative: Neonatal hypoxic ischemic (HI) injury causes significant mortality and morbidity, and the only effective treatment is hypothermia. We will develop in vivo magnetic resonance imaging techniques, together with other imaging modalities, to assess tissue injury and survival after HI using a well-established mouse model of neonatal HI injury. The proposed techniques can potentially shed light on the mechanisms of HI injury and therapeutic hypothermia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in the US, and while annual screening with low-dose CT (LDCT) is recommended for high-risk individuals, the high false-positive rates remain a major challenge. We propose to use existing blood samples collected during the National Lung Screening Trial (NLST) to evaluate whether newly identified DNA methylation markers can be used in a clinical setting to improve the selection of high-risk candidates for screening with LDCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH CTR AT TYLER
PHR: Project Narrative Vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) phenotypic modulation, a phenotypic switch from a differentiated contractile phenotype to a proliferative phenotype, contributes to vascular remodeling and the development of diverse vascular diseases such as atherosclerosis, hypertension, and restenosis following angioplasty. We have uncovered a novel role of Runt-related transcription factor 3 (RUNX3) in VSMC phenotypic modulation and proliferation, implicating it in the development of vascular injury-related cardiovascular diseases. The proposed studies will shed new lights on the pathogenesis of neointima formation and vascular remodeling, which may ultimately lead to the identification of novel targets for the therapeutic treatment of cardiovascular diseases related to vascular remodeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis is a bacterial infectious disease that causes more global death than any other bacterial infection. This proposal investigates how tuberculosis-causing bacteria use phosphoarginine protein modifications to survive stress conditions. Our findings will reveal new information on the biology of these important bacterial pathogens, and will support efforts to develop new antibiotics to combat drug-resistant tuberculosis infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To eradicate the Hepatitis C epidemic, a dramatic shift in diagnostics methodology is needed. The current paradigm, which relies on lab-based tests, requires multiple visits with a patient because of the latency between sample collection and result. We aim to develop a system that is rapid, equipment-free, and easy-to- use, enabling a patient to receive a Hepatitis C viral test result within a single visit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulation of both sleep and metabolism presents an enormous health burden throughout the world. This proposal will investigate how genes and neurons modulate sleep in response to changes in metabolism. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes is a major public health problem and exercise has an essential role in the management and prevention of this disease. The goal of this research is to find out how exercise training causes fundamental changes to adipose tissue that signal the body to improve overall metabolism, including lowering blood sugar and lipid levels and enhancing function of other tissues such as liver, muscle and kidney. These studies will lead to a better fundamental understanding of the beneficial effects of exercise on health and may help to identify therapies for diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE It is projected that by 2030, one in every five Americans will be of retirement age, and this demographic shift is expected to result in more people suffering from dementia. A key feature of the brain is its need for a constant supply of glucose and oxygen to meet the high energy costs of mental activity. This program aims to develop clinically practical, noninvasive imaging methods based on combined positron emission tomography and mag- netic resonance imaging to assess brain energy in order to better understand how this critical component of brain health is impacted by aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing a new treatment strategy, an extracellular vesicle (exosome)-based novel intraocular drug delivery system providing active targeting of ocular neovascularization, capacity to deliver multiple drugs, and sustained efficacy to treat neovascular age- related macular degeneration (NVAMD), a leading cause of blindness in people older than 60 and a major increase in healthcare cost. Development of these strategies has great potential to upgrade the therapeutic efficacy, and to reduce the treatment burden by shifting the paradigm in ocular drug delivery from current passive targeting directed monotherapy to active targeting-directed multi-drug delivery with sustained efficacy for the treatment of NVAMD as well as other posterior eye diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Frailty is a common clinical condition in older adults that is characterized by increased vulnerability to disability and mortality, and is a major burden for the healthcare system in the United States. Aging is the main risk factor for frailty; however, families of centenarians delay aging and are protected from frailty. Identifying genes and biological markers that protect from the effects of aging is an important step in the development of effective therapies that protect from and delay frailty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is a risk factor for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), a cancer that has a dismal 5-year survival rate largely related to limitations with prevention and treatment. Our project plans to elucidate mechanisms that contribute to the molecular changes that occur in the adipose tissue of obese individuals that can drive the development and progression of PDAC. Understanding how adipose-derived factors contribute to tumorigenesis will lead to novel targets to improve PDAC prevention and treatment and provide a model for future work in other obesity-associated cancers.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Acute kidney injury is common, affecting 22% of Veterans admitted to VA intensive care units. As such, acute kidney injury is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the Veteran population, and Veterans who survive are at risk of developing chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease. One in seven people in the United States has chronic kidney disease. Patients with end-stage renal disease require dialysis or kidney transplantation for survival. Kidney regeneration is poor following acute kidney injury and there are no treatments available at this time to directly encourage regeneration. New treatments that target regeneration of the kidney are needed. The human kidney is comprised of a limited set of nephrons that are present at birth. These nephrons are lost over time and can never be regained, so renal injuries can be lifelong. We seek to explore the use of reprogrammed progenitor cells and their extracellular vesicles for kidney regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Gut microbiota play a vital role in metabolism, endocrine, and immune system. Extracellular vesicles (EVs), small bilipid layer containers, mediate intercellular communication and hold great potential in drug delivery and therapy. We will investigate the novel role of gut microbiota-derived EVs in the progression of diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN), the most prevalent chronic complications of diabetes patients, and examine whether commensal beneficial microbiota-derived EVs can be employed as a potential therapeutic target against DPN and the underlying molecular mechanisms. Our work will provide new insights into the pathogenesis of DPN and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic agents for patients with DPN.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Frailty, a multi-component phenotype of having a decreased capacity to recover from a health-related stressor, impacts three out of ten Veterans over 65 and independently associates with increased mortality risk. Chronic kidney disease (CKD) confers a nearly 80% higher odds of frailty. No interventions improve frailty or frailty risk in CKD, and no interventions are currently able to be targeted to those who would most benefit. Physical activity is the component of the frailty phenotype that predicts mortality and dialysis initiation in CKD, and recent evidence suggests that biomarkers of senescence are reduced after exercise. This proposal will 1) identify novel psychosocial factors associated with physical activity frequency among older Veterans with CKD; 2) develop and pilot test an intervention targeted to these mechanisms to increase physical activity; and 3) explore whether biomarkers of senescence can predict intervention treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project aims to illuminate the molecular mechanism of the human sodium-dicarboxylate transporter NaDC3 by structurally characterizing its complete reaction cycle. Structures of the protein with substrates and inhibitors bound will establish the structural basis of the transporter’s substrate specificity and the mechanisms of inhibition. Such knowledge will in turn help us to understand the signaling pathways that control cell fate and aid us in the design of therapeutics in treating Canavan disease and other disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a disease characterized by T cell mediated beta cell destruction. The mechanisms behind long-term functional persistence of autoimmune T cells under conditions of chronic inflammation and continuous immune activation, which should curtail immune responses, are not well understood. We will determine the role of resident and recruited CD4 T cells in maintaining tissue autoimmunity, and mechanisms behind the persistence of high and low affinity autoimmune T cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic studies of immune-related disorders have discovered a number of genetic variants associated with the risk of these diseases, yet, to translate these data into knowledge of the underlying genes and identify potential therapeutic targets is challenging. To fill this gap, we propose to study the effects of genetic variants, in human immune cells, on RNA modification, an important mechanism that controls RNAs and may affect the risk of diseases. We expect our study to uncover variants and genes that play important roles in immune disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because the efficacious treatment of children with speech sound disorders is paramount to their academic and social success. School-based speech-language pathologists are well-poised to adapt clinical decisions related to the speech sound therapy environment to ensure positive therapy outcomes. Thus, this exploratory pre-implementation research aligns with NIDCD’s goal to advance the science of communication to improve lives by determining what works for whom to optimize school-based therapy outcomes, related to phonological knowledge, for elementary-aged children with speech sound disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Our research indicates that dystrophic neurites that surround amyloid plaques in Alzheimer's disease (AD) are caused by Aβ-induced membrane damage leading to calcium leakage, kinase activation, and tau hyperphosphorylation, suggesting a mechanism that links Aβ and tau pathologies. Moreover, dystrophic neurites may be crucibles of AD tau seeding and spreading that ultimately results in synaptic loss, neuron death, and cognitive impairment in AD. We discovered that the membrane repair protein annexin A6 reduces dystrophic neurite formation and pathologic tau phosphorylation, so in this R01 we will explore whether annexin A6 can ameliorate dystrophic neurites, tau hyperphosphorylation, and the seeding and spreading of AD tau in mouse models of amyloid pathology, which could provide therapeutic proof-of-concept supporting annexin A6 for the prevention or treatment of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Although empirical evidence supports a strong relationship between human eating behaviors, food intake, and obesity, research outside the lab and development of interventions to improve eating behaviors have been hindered by lack of accurate automated technology to track free-living eating behaviors. This project will develop and test a discreet wearable device assembly to track a key combination of eating behaviors, starting with laboratory validations and progressing to free-living situations with a variety of foods and beverages in adults across a broad range of BMI, age, genders, and race/ethnicity, with oversampling from LatinX communities, who experience higher prevalence of obesity and associated co-morbidities. The long term goal is to enable researchers to better understand how real-world eating behaviors influence body weight regulation and health, how eating behaviors can effectively be modified, and how people can be provided with tools to improve their everyday eating behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The notochord is the main embryonic axial structure necessary for development and patterning of the body plan, and in humans impaired notochord formation can result in birth defects, vertebral malformations and bone- derived malignant tumors called chordomas. The transcription factor Brachyury is known to be indispensable for notochord development and to be an etiological agent of chordoma; however, it is still unclear how this transcription factor coordinates the temporal expression of all its numerous target genes, which in turn control different stages of notochord formation, and how Brachyury-downstream transcription factors allow Brachyury to control late-onset genes required for morphogenesis and differentiation of the notochord. The research proposed here will fill these gaps in knowledge by studying how temporal information is encoded in notochord cis-regulatory regions directly controlled by Brachyury, by reconstructing the gene batteries that are regulated by Brachyury-downstream transcription factors, and by elucidating how transcriptional repressors refine notochord gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Non-alcoholic fatty liver diseases (NAFLD), which affect more than 10-40% of adults worldwide with 60% in diabetic patients and 90% in obese people, can progress to liver fibrosis and further advance to cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. DNA methylation/demethylation, likely regulated by the TET1 enzyme, is highly associated with NAFLD development and progression. Determining the role of TET1 in preclinical NAFLD models will yield results toward establishing TET1 as a potential target for treating NAFLD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE When vision loss becomes irreversible, some solutions seek to assist patients to substitute vision with their remaining sensory modalities by converting live visual information into patterns of sound or touch. In this project, we aim to further develop such technologies and identify the neurobehavioral effects of sensory substitution training in brains deprived of visual input via advanced neuroimaging and performance assessments. Results of this study can help determine how to leverage these new patterns of alternative senses via the plastic brains in the blind to improve their independence of living and to facilitate connections with others for better health outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative Dysfunctional repair of the alveolar epithelium following recurrent/chronic injury has been hypothesized as central to the pathogenesis of pulmonary fibrosis, but mechanisms driving dysfunctional repair are not well understood. Our preliminary data indicate that repeated injury to a regenerating alveolar epithelium is associated with persistent activation of hypoxia-inducible factor (Hif) signaling and suggest persistent Hif activation in regenerating alveolar epithelial cells (AECs) prevents their terminal differentiation and restoration of normal function. In these studies, we will utilize transgenic mouse models, state-of-the art single-cell genomics, and ex-vivo organoid models to investigate the mechanisms through which Hif- signaling regulates AEC regeneration and examine whether inhibiting Hif activation can prevent or reverse experimental lung fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kinases have been implicated in almost all cellular processes and are attractive targets in the development of cancer therapeutics, with most drugs depending on kinase inhibition to achieve their therapeutic effect. This grant aims to expand on our previous efforts towards a novel mode of action for protein modulation – Targeted Protein Degradation – which induces complete elimination of the target protein from the cancer cell and thereby not only targets kinase catalytic activity but also important scaffolding functions. To accomplish this, we will develop novel small molecule degrader scaffolds and compound libraries in addition to elevating our compound characterization efforts to increase coverage of the degradable kinome and our understanding of degrading and non-degrading complexes, and we will further introduce the development of non-degrading glue molecules as new drugs for the modulation of (pseudo)kinase activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria remains a major health problem in the world with over 230 million cases and 627,000 deaths each year. Antimalarial drugs are the mainstay for controlling malaria and the mitochondrion of the malaria parasite is a validated target for existing drugs as well as those in development. This project aims to derive a deeper understanding of mitochondrial functions in malaria parasites to identify additional vulnerable targets for novel antimalarial compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Stroke is the leading cause of adult disability in the US with the greatest burden on communities of color. It is increasingly clear that disparities in Social Determinants of Health (SDOH), produced by structural racism and discrimination, are major drivers of stroke outcomes disparities. Demonstrating improved stroke outcomes with our equity-trained SDOH Homecare Intervention Focus Team (SHIFT), in addition to showing the impact of SHIFT on a more equity-centered provider practice model, may result in a paradigm shift in the approach to treating underserved minority stroke populations and close the gap in health disparities in this and other medical conditions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project will investigate a topic of significance in advancing research on everyday spoken language communication in children and adults: the ability to navigate across-talker variability in human speech sounds. Although the past 40 years of research have shown that the human comprehension capacity flexibly adapts to characteristics of the input, we do not yet know what perceptual, cognitive, and neural mechanisms underlie this adaptivity. Through contrasting three major proposals and testing their predictions in large-scale perceptual experiments, our project will be the first to identify what mechanism(s) support our adaptive speech perception – knowledge critical to understanding when/why healthy perception can break down.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The combination of unsurpassed genetic tractability, the stereotyped organization of the tissue, and the fundamental conservation of developmental mechanisms, makes the Drosophila retina an ideal model system in which to elucidate the mechanisms that establish and maintain pattern and form during tissue morphogenesis. The discoveries resulting from our investigations will improve understanding of both normal developmental mechanisms and of how disease-associated cellular defects in a complex organ can disrupt tissue-level patterns and organ morphology.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Approximately 60% of US Veterans with spinal cord injuries (SCI) experience clinically significant spasticity, which can disrupt rehabilitation and negatively impact quality-of-life, e.g., mobility, personal hygiene, intimate relationships. Previously, we have found that intraperitoneal (IP) injection of the FDA approved compound Romidepsin (a PAK1 inhibitor) suppresses the H-reflex in mice SCIs. In this project we will determine whether intrathecal (IT) route administration of Romidepsin reduces H-reflex hyperexcitability following SCI, as well as dendritic spine dysgenesis. [To compare safety, efficacy, and side effects of IT delivery of Romidepsin to that of IV delivery of Romidepsin (standard clinical delivery method for T-cell lymphoma in humans).] Results from this project will allow us to determine the safety and efficacy of IT administration for translational studies of Romidepsin for treatment of spasticity following SCI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: WHITE RIVER JUNCTION VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: While the VA has made considerable progress in predicting and preventing suicide for patients at the highest risk—including those who previously attempted suicide, were recently released from inpatient mental health treatment, or use opioids—no comparable achievements have been made for patients in lower-risk tiers. Indeed, even though they constitute the vast majority of VA suicide deaths, very little is known about VA patients who die by suicide but are not identified as being at high-risk by existing programs. The proposed study is highly relevant to Veterans’ health because it will advance epidemiological understanding and targeted prediction and prevention resources for these non-high-risk suicide decedents. This work would be highly scalable and could have a large positive impact on Veterans’ health by preventing suicide in patients whose risk otherwise would go undetected. The proposed research is highly relevant to the VA’s top clinical priority, aiding development of accurate and effective suicide prevention services that reach deeper into the risk pool.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research holds significant relevance to public health because the vitamin K cycle supports blood coagulation and calcium homeostasis in vascular systems and bones, and through ferroptosis regulation, involves in cardiovascular diseases and suppresses cancers. This cycle is the target of the most commonly prescribed oral anticoagulants that are used to treat and prevent deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, stroke, and myocardial infarction. Understanding the structural and cellular mechanisms of this cycle will lead to new therapeutic strategies for treating and preventing thromboembolic disorders, bone disorders, cardiovascular diseases and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Posttraumatic osteoarthritis is a common occurrence after joint injury such as anterior cruciate ligament rupture. Early events after joint injury response (apoptosis and inflammatory) have a synergistic crosstalk that can tip the healing response to injury into a vicious cycle of perpetuating joint damage. In this proposal we will use a novel multimodal imaging approach that allows to measure apoptosis and inflammation simultaneously on the same animal to test a novel combinatorial treatment targeting apoptosis and inflammation to reinstate joint homeostasis af ter injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative How excitatory and inhibitory circuits mediate neural computation in the cerebral cortex is central to understanding vision, and brain function more generally. Disruptions of the precise balance between excitation and inhibition in the cerebral cortex can lead to a variety of neurological disorders. Thus, understanding how excitatory and inhibitory circuits drive sensory perception should help reveal the underlying causes of certain neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS), sometimes in conjunction with Speech-Language Therapy, has been demonstrated to improve language function in subjects with chronic aphasia. We will use electrical field modeling to optimize TMS stimulation intensity in a double-blind study of continuous Theta Burst Stimulation combined with modified Constraint Induced Language Therapy as compared to sham stimulation and modified Constraint Induced Language Therapy in subjects with subacute aphasia. Additional aims are to identify anatomic, behavioral and genetic predictors of response to treatment and to identify the mechanisms underlying the beneficial effect of using network neuroscience imaging techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intracerebral hemorrhage is complex, has long-term significant cognitive and functional impairment, and has no proven treatment, resulting in a disproportionate disability rate and lifetime cost among stroke survivors. By employing novel cognitive outcomes methodology and neuroimaging analysis to study long-term outcomes in ICH with enhanced retention, we may accelerate understanding of the causes of cognitive impairment after ICH. In the REpeated ASSEssment of SurvivorS in IntraCerebral Hemorrhage study (REASSESS ICH), we will determine whether reduction of ICH volume with minimally invasive surgery is a critical target to reducing the risk of progressive cognitive decline, targets for residual hematoma volume and whether cerebral small vessel disease and inflammatory pathways in particular predict patients with cognitive impairment independent of gene risk scores for dementia and surgical status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The unique mental abilities of humans are rooted in the immensely expanded and folded neocortex, which reflects the expansion of neural progenitor/stem cells. Abnormal size or folding of the human neocortex can cause intellectual disability and other neurological disorders. By defining the mechanisms regulating neural progenitor/stem cell expansion, the proposed research will help us to understand the mechanisms underlying such disorders that are caused by genetic and other factors, including controlled substances and certain viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using current approaches, determining the best treatments for patients with type B aortic dissection (TBAD) remains a clinical challenge. Our initial work suggests that measuring aorta blood flow with 4D flow MRI may better identify high-risk TBAD patients, and, in this proposal, we will develop more efficient imaging and data-analysis techniques to further test how 4D flow improves TBAD risk- assessment. Our overarching goal is to better understand the role of blood flow assessment in TBAD and make these techniques more broadly available in standard clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal will examine a previously uncharacterized variability in biospecimen collection that impacts measurement of biomarkers in preclinical and clinical research. We recently reported that exposing biospecimens to ambient air, even for a short duration, impacts levels of key signaling molecules associated with stemness and therapeutic response compared to biospecimens that are maintained at physiologic oxygen levels of 3-5% levels (closely mimicking the in vivo oxygen tension). This study will investigate the impact of oxygen exposure on the detection and quantification of clinically relevant biomarkers such as pEGFR, pPDGFRb, and pAKT in primary breast tumor tissues and biospecimens collected from malignant ascites and pleural effusions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The Chaperone-Assisted Structure Determination (CSAD) pipeline provides novel classes of antibody-based reagents to further objectives in structural biology and membrane protein research. Membrane proteins are the principle drug targets in the pharmaceutical industry because they modulate myriad critical biological functions. The reagents produced are considerably more powerful than traditional antibodies because they can be targeted to specific sites on proteins and protein complexes and can be endowed with biological function. The CASD collaborates and services a large cohort of scientists whose interests span across multiple areas of high biomedical importance. These collaborations and the reagents that are produced are likely to lead to development of antibody-like leads that have significant therapeutic value.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disease progression associated with diagnostic delays reduces curability of endemic Burkitt Lymphoma. Earlier recognition of eBL may be facilitated by detection of EBV in blood and/or saliva, but poor specificity reduces the utility of EBV DNA as an early diagnostic marker. We propose to study a variety of specimen preparation techniques that enrich for tumor-derived EBV DNA to improve sensitivity and specificity of cell-free EBV DNA detection as an early diagnostic marker for eBL. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative: The major risk factor associated with chronic low back and neck pain is the degenerative status of the intervertebral disc (IVD) and dystrophic mineralization significantly contributes to this pathology. Extracellular pyrophosphate, citrate and phosphocitrate are endogenous low molecular weight compounds that potently inhibit mineralization. Herein, we propose to decipher how the extracellular homeostasis of these small molecules is regulated and to explore if these endogenous compounds can be exploited therapeutically to prevent mineralization of the IVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE KRAS-driven non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) remains one of the most aggressive and lethal solid tumors. Therapeutic options and outcomes for NSCLC have remained virtually unchanged over the past thirty years. Using novel CRISPR/Cas9-based genome-engineering technologies we have established a unique and rapid research program to functionally characterize lung cancer mutations and identify genotype-specific metabolic vulnerabilities that can lead to novel therapeutic approaches in KRAS-driven lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because brain injuries, such as occur in stroke, leave many people with chronic motor disabilities, requiring long-term medical and institutional care. This project seeks to develop a greater understanding of the plasticity process that occurs after brain injury, specifically in the compensatory functional connections that form in uninjured regions of the brain. Information gained from this project will inform the development of new therapies, such as rehabilitative approaches designed to maximize functional recovery after brain injury.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Veterans with long-COVID experience debilitating symptoms that wax and wane over time. This results in poorer health, impaired occupational function, and reduced quality of life. Providers face increasing demands for treatment of long-COVID, yet treatment options are limited with no guidelines for optimal management of this group. Successful management of long-COVID should include a multi-modal health program that incorporates physical medicine and rehabilitation as well as mental health components. Combined aquatic exercise and cognitive training programs improve cognition, cardiorespiratory function, and mental health in older Veterans with cognitive impairment. Given this increased demand for effective treatments and the success of combined programs in healthy Veterans, it is critical to evaluate if the beneficial effects of these combined treatments extend to those suffering with long-COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE Survivors of childhood cancer experience accelerated aging with high burden of chronic health conditions (CHC) and premature mortality, hence it is critical to conduct proposed clinical aging research in this vulnerable population to improve survivorship care and quality of life for these individuals. In the current proposal, we will leverage preexisting epigenetic profiling data, and also generate additional epigenetic profiling data from stored biospecimens collected during the longitudinal follow-up of our well-established cohort of childhood cancer survivors, as well as from samples collected during two ongoing health promoting behavioral intervention trials. We will investigate how social determinants of health and health behaviors will affect the change of epigenetic age acceleration (EAA) among survivors of childhood cancer, and how the change in EAA will subsequently influence long-term health outcomes, and explore the effect of health promoting behavioral interventions on EAA and if the change pattern of EAA portends the improvement of targeted health outcomes.

PHR: Mutations in proteins that process ribonucleic acids (RNA) are highly prevalent in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS), a chronic blood disorder that causes anemia, bleeding and risk of transforming to leukemia. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL)-producing Enterobacterales (ESBL-PE) represent a serious public health threat because they are resistant to many beta-lactam antibiotics and have spread rapidly worldwide. Predicting antibiotic resistance using whole genome sequencing-based methods may enable early identification of effective treatment options for multidrug-resistant bacteria, but accurate prediction models for antibiotics that could be used to treat ESBL-PE are currently lacking. Taking advantage of nanopore whole genome sequencing technology to comprehensively characterize bacterial genomes, this study seeks to delineate the role that mobile genetic elements (MGEs) harboring ESBL genes play in determining antibiotic resistance and whether accounting for MGEs in genomic prediction models improves detection of antibiotic resistance in ESBL-PE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Concerns about adverse health effects of shipping emissions have been rising globally. The overall objective of the proposed study is to evaluate the impact of a policy/regulatory intervention to reduce shipping emissions on air quality and public health (i.e., total and cause-specific mortality and hospital admissions) using innovative Bayesian spatial multivariate receptor modeling, a causal inference method based on the concept of counterfactual outcomes and a strong study design that addresses issues of bias resulting from spatial misalignment and unmeasured confounding due to non-marine sources. We will also evaluate potential differences in the impact of the intervention among groups based on race/ethnicity, neighborhood disadvantage, sex, and age.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Weight loss surgery can effectively reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes, leading causes of illness and death in the US, but it is invasive and produces variable results. This project seeks to identify the biomarkers and pathways responsible for better cardiometabolic health after weight loss surgery. The findings may be used to develop nonsurgical methods to improve cardiometabolic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narratives Centrosome and cilia dysfunction is prevalent in a wide range of diseases collectively called ciliopathy, including e.g. Bardet-Biedl syndrome, Joubert syndrome, Meckel-Gruber syndrome, polycystic kidney disease, and primary ciliary dyskinesia. However, how these cellular organelles form error-free from protein components scattered in the cell and what their physiological roles in most tissues remain elusive. A thorough understanding of the molecular pathways vertebrate cells employ to form and maintain the centrosome-cilium complex will allow for the development of therapeutic manipulations for some of these diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The ADD SEX FUN project will identify and assess the strength of individual, dyadic romantic relationship, cultural, and socio-structural factors that predict or prevent a highly prevalent psychophysiological disease category among Black women: female sexual dysfunction. It will help researchers differentiate between the factors that are more likely to affect Black women’s v. White women’s sexual functioning and represent the extent to which the strength of correlated partner factors differs among Black and White women. It will also establish which messages about sexual functioning align most with distinct demographic and attitudinal profiles of Black women’s romantic partners, providing an evidence base upon which to develop or adapt dyadic sexual functioning interventions for Black women and their partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: Benzene is a ubiquitous environmental pollutant and a known hematopoietic toxin but little is known about the effect of benzene exposure on cardiovascular disease. The proposed study will examine the effect of benzene exposure on atherosclerosis, the underlying cause of most cardiovascular disease and stroke, and delineate the associated molecular mechanisms.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Elderly women are disproportionally affected by atrial fibrillation (AF) and AF related dementia. We will examine the role of aging and genetic sex, XX (female) vs. XY (male), in the development of cardiac inflammation/fibrosis, AF and dementia. We will also test fibrosis inhibition as a sex-specific AF and dementia preventative therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: We have generated a vast amount of transcriptomic, metabolomic and proteomic data from a nine-day time course aimed at temporally defining the changing signaling and metabolic landscape contributing to the initiation and progression of molecular events promoting the epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) in breast, lung and other cancers. These data have revealed several new links to EMT and metastasis, and we are currently focused on defining; (i) how ERK2 regulates chromatin remodeling and contributes to the initial phases of EMT via regulation of the HIRA complex and H3.3, (ii) how ERK2 signaling controls genetic and metabolic reprogramming to promote EMT-like features and metastatic progression via the SP1/EGR1-dependent down- regulation of genes suppressing metastatic behaviors and (iii) how ERK2 regulates extensive changes in membrane trafficking and lysosome biology for nutrient acquisition and survival and how differential expression of plasma membrane and lysosome membrane transporters during EMT, are regulated and contribute to cancer progression and invasion. These goals place us in the unique position to uncover and understand at a biochemical and molecular level new regulatory processes, new biomarkers and new potential targets for drug discovery, that are needed for personalized therapeutic intervention in many diseases, such as aggressive, metastatic cancers, a major unmet clinical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project proposes to test the hypothesis that skin necrosis over implants results from compression induced vascular necrosis leading to reduced skin elastic properties (skin damage), and eventually skin necrosis and implant exposure. Vascular ischemia and skin damage will be studied in an in vivo model, with photoacoustic tomography (PA), Doppler Ultrasound (US) and ultrasound elasticity (UE) respectively applied to measure vascular ischemia and skin damage in vivo. These measures will be correlated with implant shape and computationally predicted skin damage from nonlinear Finite Element continuum damage models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The epithelial cells that line the intestinal tract build finger-like protrusions referred to as ‘microvilli’, which extend into the gut lumen and play essential roles in nutrient absorption and protection against infection. Despite occupying a critical physiological interface in the gut, there is little information on how microvilli are built and organized. The proposed studies seek to elucidate molecular pathways that control the assembly and organization of these protrusions during intestinal epithelial differentiation, and thus generate insight on the basis of human diseases characterized by loss of microvilli, which include enteric infections and inherited pathologies such as microvillus inclusion disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cyclopropane, aza-cyclopropane (aziridine), and isocyano (isonitrile) moieties are unique functional groups used as pharmacophores in drugs (including FDA approved drugs for the treatment of hypertension, opioid addition, HIV, and cancers) and metal chelating agents, and it will therefore be valuable to develop effective strategies to access these novel functional groups. The recently discovered cyclopropanation, aziridination, and isonitrile formation catalyzed by iron(II)- and 2-oxoglutarate-dependent (Fe/2OG) enzymes represent attractive strategies to install these important pharmacophores. In this project, a combined bioinformatics and retro-biosynthetic analysis will be applied to efficiently identify Fe/2OG enzymes with these targeted activities in genomic sequence data; the identified Fe/2OG enzymes will subjected to mechanistic investigations, and the acquired mechanistic insights will be used to innovate chemo-enzymatic methods to prepare cyclopropane, aziridine, and isonitrile, the three novel functional groups widely used in synthetic chemistry and drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Improved point-of-care tests for tuberculosis (TB) are needed to enable more timely and accurate diagnosis. In light of its portability, relatively low cost, and good diagnostic accuracy for pulmonary disease, lung ultrasound is a potentially promising new tool for point-of-care TB diagnosis. We will carry out a study to evaluate the potential of lung ultrasound for pulmonary tuberculosis.

PHR: Narrative Chronic pain after traumatic stress exposure is more common in women, and mechanisms of chronic pain development in men and women appear to differ. We propose a series of genomic, molecular, and behavioral studies evaluating how microRNA, master regulators of the mammalian transcriptome, influence chronic pain development after traumatic stress exposure in men and women. These experiments will provide important new insights into sex-specific mechanisms of CMSP development and will identify novel therapeutic strategies for both sexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The dopamine system has been widely studied to elucidate the reinforcing properties of substance abuse, but far less is known on how this system regulates how cues, for example, drug-associated words or environments, act to trigger drug self-administration. Our research investigates how these cues become associated with outcomes and meaning, which appears to require dopamine-dependent changes in specific synaptic connections between auditory inputs to neurons that control decision making. This project explores how these learning-dependent changes occur in the brain, and the results are expected to contribute to understanding the brain mechanisms driving substance abuse, as well as symptoms of disorders including hallucinations in psychosis, attention deficit, post-traumatic stress disorder and deficits in language learning in neurodevelopmental disorders including autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study aims to discover the causes for sleep-wake disturbances that afflict patients with Alzheimer's Disease and Progressive Supranuclear Palsy. We will determine if the pattern of disturbed sleep in these two disorders is predicted by neuropathological and molecular changes in key areas that regulate sleep and wake in both human brain bank specimens and a subsample of patients who complete sleep measures and undergo autopsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The insulin-like growth factor (IGF) system has a central role in a number of human diseases including growth disorders, thyroid eye disease, chronic kidney diseases and various cancers. We recently showed for the first time that viruses have insulin/IGF-1 like peptides that are natural inhibitors of the IGF-1 receptor (IGF1R). The proposed experiments on these viral IGF1R inhibitors will enhance our understanding of IGF1R inhibition and provide valuable insights for the development of peptide therapeutics to treat IGF-1 related diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative This project will be the largest multimodal longitudinal study in children and adolescents attempting to identify robust neural and mental health correlates and consequences specific to three Screen Media Activity (SMA) types: active (i.e., videogaming), passive (i.e., watching TV and videos) and mixed (i.e., texting and using social media). Its innovation lies in the multi-modal and longitudinal characterization of the children and the use of twin- studies and sophisticated analytic methods to identify probable causal mechanisms involving SMA types. The rationale for the proposed research is that, once the neurobiological mechanisms mediating the relationship among SMA, mental health and brain development are understood, and modifiable factors identified, targeted prevention approaches and policy initiatives can be developed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Structural basis for pathway-selective signaling by the µ-opioid receptor. The goal of this proposal is to determine the structural basis for the versatile signaling behavior of the µ-opioid receptor. The µ-opioid receptor is the most effective therapeutic target for the treatment of acute and chronic pain; however, the use of opioid drugs acting at this receptor is a leading cause of death by overdose in North America and Europe. This proposal will provide structural insights that will facilitate the development of safer and more effective drugs for opioid receptors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE  This study will be highly significant in establishing a therapeutic modality to prevent the maternal and infant vascular dysfunction that is caused by improper SAR early in pregnancy. Non-invasive UMGD delivery of VEGF selectively to the maternal aspect of the placenta represents an innovative approach to reverse the decline in SAR and link it to vascular function in the mother and offspring. Reversing the defect in SAR by VEGF gene delivery will be foundational in developing a similar therapeutic modality to prevent the devastating complications of vascular dysfunction in the human mother and newborn elicited by impaired SAR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Our proposal relies on a multidisciplinary effort between researchers with complementary expertise to investigate the pathogenic potential for tubulin post-translational modifications (PTMs) in the onset of chemotherapy induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) and the mechanisms of CIPN-related drug dependent induction of tubulin and microtubule injury. In the short-term, our studies will examine a novel unifying theory of pathogenesis based on alteration of tubulin PTMs and determine the role for delta-2 tubulin in the onset of neuropathic damage induced by CIPN-promoting drugs by interfering with mitochondrial and TRP channel function. In the long-term, this work has the potential to reveal tubulin perturbation as the driver of axonal dysfunction caused by chemotherapeutics and to identify novel targets that may be modulated in drug therapies aimed at rescuing other chemotherapy- related adverse sequelae such as nephrotoxicity or ototoxicity as well as idiopathic or inherited forms of peripheral neuropathy in addition to CIPN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE At the heart of cleaning and disinfection (C&D) conducted by nurses is a “risk-risk tradeoff”: increased C&D leading to increased work-related asthma risks and simultaneous decreased occupational infection risks. Translation of risk-risk tradeoff methods to respiratory health research and understanding barriers to C&D policy change will enable and identify feasible policy change strategies that protect nurses at their acceptable risk levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proteostasis, or protein homeostasis, is the balance between the accumulation of damaged proteins and protein degradation capabilities. This project examines the role of proteostasis in Plasmodium falciparum artemisinin resistance and focuses on the proteasome, ubiquitination, and the unfolded protein response in Southeast Asian and African parasites. Targeting proteostasis in P. falciparum parasites represents a new paradigm to treat artemisinin-resistant malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Public health relevance: This project will generate and apply statistical tools for analyzing large-scale genomic studies. The tools will help scientists tackle a diverse range of problems, including understanding the effects of genetic variation on fundamental biological processes, identifying collections of related genes that may help inform or explain new experimental results, and discovering relationships and clustering among samples (e.g., cells, genes or people), for example to identify cell or disease sub-types. Solving these problems has the potential to help understand the biology of disease, eventually leading to new therapies or treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal is relevant to public health as it addresses how microglia, a cell implicated in Alzheimer's disease (AD) by human genome-wide association studies, are involved in disease pathogenesis. Although microglia surround amyloid-β plaques, one of the main pathologies of AD, there is still little known about what their response to plaques does to the brain – whether it is beneficial or detrimental. Upon completion, this project will not only identify the distinct role of these cells during disease, but also provide an innovative tool to study and target plaque-associated microglia, as well as insight into novel therapeutic strategies for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Our preliminary results demonstrate that targeting MDA-9 using the pharmacological inhibitor PDZ1i sensitizes metastatic breast tumor cells to conventional therapeutics. This proposal intends to characterize the mechanism by which PDZ1i, administered in a nanoformulation (PDZ1i-Nano), controls TNBC progression (growth and cellular dissemination) and sensitizes breast cancer cells to the toxic effects of chemotherapies and determine if these responses are enhanced further in terms of preventing metastasis when PDZ1i is used in combination with standard of care chemotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are no effective therapies for Ataxia Telangiectasia (A-T)—a catastrophic and lethal neurologic disease in children. We propose to utilize a recently generated animal model of A-T that for the first time displays the progressive loss of motor coordination (i.e., ataxia) and cerebellar atrophy that is a hallmark of the disease. Employing this new model, we will use cutting edge methods to examine the relationship between deleterious changes in the cerebellum and the progressive development of a severe form of ataxia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD) is an atherosclerotic disease that is associated with increased levels of arterial calcification above and below the knee, which decreases blood flow and perfusion to the calves and feet, and increases risk of non-healing wounds, limb loss, and death. Our research team developed a novel PET/CT imaging paradigm that provides absolute measures of skeletal muscle perfusion within specific muscle groups and vascular territories of the lower extremities that correspond with adverse remodeling of skeletal muscle and PAD symptom severity. The overarching goal of the outlined projects is to pre-clincially test and clinically translate this functional imaging approach to comprehensively quantify regional abnormalities in lower extremity skeletal muscle perfusion in the setting of PAD, which could ultimately assist the vascular medicine community by improving non-invasive monitoring of PAD patients, evaluating the efficacy of targeted revascularization procedures, and predicting rates of major adverse limb events after therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Chemotherapy for cancer can often result in damage to the heart muscle and heart failure. Stimulating a process known as autophagy can protect the heart from this but can, in some cases, also protect the cancer from the chemotherapy. We have developed a technique to image autophagy and will use this to determine whether there are ways to stimulate autophagy that protect the heart and preserve the cancer-killing chemotherapy efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project narrative: The endocannabinoid system, including type 1 cannabinoid receptors (CB1 receptors), is critical for proper learning and adaptation in neuronal circuits and is dysregulated in a number of psychiatric, neurodegenerative, and motor disorders such as depression, Alzheimer’s disease, and spinocerebellar ataxia. This work will determine cellular mechanisms that regulate presynaptic CB1 receptor activity during learning and demonstrate that activity-dependent changes in CB1 receptors regulates proper synaptic plasticity and learning in the cerebellar circuit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identical-by-descent segments inferred from genome-wide data provide information on population history and genetic relatedness that are not sufficiently used in current genetic association approaches. We propose to leverage identical-by-descent segments in the genetic association mapping for Alzheimer’s Disease and related brain imaging endophenotypes, develop efficient statistical methods and implement novel computational algorithms that can be applied to large samples. Our tools and findings will facilitate genetic research and provide novel insights into the genetic architecture of Alzheimer’s Disease.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Heart failure and atrial fibrillation are major public health problems that results from risk factors, including diabetes, obesity, and hypertension. These risk factors cause dysfunction of the left atrium, a chamber of the heart, prior to developing heart failure or atrial fibrillation. This study seeks to identify metabolites and proteins in the blood among individuals with these risk factors that lead to left atrial dysfunction, with the ultimate goal of finding new avenues for prevention and treatment of heart failure and atrial fibrillation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pediatric toxoplasmosis is a parasitic disease in immuno-compromised patients with no dose flexible medications available for children at this time. To address the unmet medical need, this proposal seeks to mechanistically develop and characterize an age-appropriate 3D-printed dose-flexible pediatric delivery system of three drugs individually and/or in combination for effective treatment of pediatric toxoplasmosis. It is expected that the quality, stability, palatability (human), pharmacokinetic, and pharmacodynamic (safety and efficacy) profiles of dose-flexible pediatric delivery systems will meet FDA and USP requirements for eventual deployment in hospitals for pediatric use.

PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this project is to improve the reproducibility of quantitative MRI and, consequently, the objectivity of radiological readings. The project will also improve the comparability of different scans, which is much needed in the age of large multi-center studies, artificial intelligence, and precision medicine. Further, we will enhance MRI’s sensitivity and specificity to pathologies, in particular to the different pathologies in multiple sclerosis, which will improve therapeutic planning.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses how maternal obesity and exercise impacts neuronal development. It is expected to identify critical signaling mechanisms by which neurotropic factors, such as BDNF are interdependent on other neurotrophic factors to regulate synaptic development; disruption of which has been associated with Intellectual Disability, Major Depressive Disorder, Schizophrenia, Autism Spectrum Disorder, Rett Syndrome and Alzheimer Disease as well as other neurodevelopmental disorders. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to elucidating how obesity and maternal behavior impacts development and developing targeted approaches for the prevention and treatment of obesity and mental health disorders, such as Autism spectrum disorder, depression, anxiety and cognitive function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma is the 3rd deadliest cancer in the US with only 3% of patients surviving beyond 5 years after the cancer has spread. Less than 25% of patients are eligible for surgery, and the effects of chemotherapy and immunotherapy are limited by various barriers in the tumor immediate environment. This project harnesses a light-activated priming treatment to restore the effects of chemotherapy, improve the immune system’s ability to eliminate the tumor, and prolong survival rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE If detected early, hypertension (HTN) is treatable; yet, HTN screening rates are low and inequitable in Sub- Saharan Africa (SSA) leaving many people with undiagnosed HTN, especially in urban areas. Thus, it is a high priority to determine the acceptability, effectiveness, and sustainability of strategies to increase rates of BP screening and connections to care in SSA. The overarching goals of this project are to: (1) Adapt evidence- based implementation strategies – called community vital signs (CVS) strategies – to support BP screening and connections to care; (2) Implement the CVS strategies and assess acceptability, test their effectiveness in improving rates of BP screening and connections to care, and understand facilitators and barriers to their sustainability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Although identified over 100 years ago, Treponema pallidum, the spiral-shaped bacterium that causes syphilis and related diseases, could not be grown in vitro, i.e. in a test tube, until 2018 when our laboratory achieved continuous in vitro multiplication of T. pallidum. The T. pallidum in vitro culture system is complex, including tissue culture cells, a specialized medium, and incubation under low concentrations of oxygen (1.5%), but appears to serve as an excellent replacement for the traditional method of growing T. pallidum in rabbits. In this project, we plan to optimize and simplify the culture system so that it can be used readily for research purposes, and we will also introduce mutations into the genes of T. pallidum to gain a better understanding of how the proteins they produce help this organism causes debilitating infections that can last for decades.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abandoned uranium mines, primarily located on tribal land in the southwest United States, are not remediated and continue to degrade heavy metals into the surrounding environment, contaminating the sedimentary dust and ground water with significant concentrations of uranium. Epidemiological data suggests a direct link between inhalation and ingestion of uranium mine dusts with higher incidences of intestinal inflammation and diseases. This proposal aims to define and characterize the mechanisms underlying uranium-induced intestinal dysfunction and long-term consequences in the intestinal epithelia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative A frequent complaint in older adults is difficulty with speech comprehension, especially in the presence of background noise. Using a high-powered individual difference approach, this project will use neural and behavioral measures to determine successful and unsuccessful adaptation mechanisms. This work aims to discover learnable cognitive strategies for improving speech recognition, and generate biomarkers for successful and harmful adaptations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While clinical development of HDAC inhibitors for oncology has been largely unsuccessful, we recently discovered a synthetic lethal relationship between HDAC1 and HDAC2 that should offer a greater window for therapeutic development. Based on our preliminary data that members of the HDAC1/2-containing NuRD chromatin remodeler complex are required for the survival of cancers impacted by HDAC1/2 synthetic lethality, we propose to (i) determine the mechanistic basis underlying NuRD vulnerabilities in these cancers and (ii) develop small-molecule modulators of NuRD function that target cancer-specific NuRD vulnerabilities.
