IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood obesity is a pervasive public health threat, inequities in social determinants of health create a context of stress that exacerbates childhood obesity, and novel outdoor preschool models offer innovative opportunities for: 1) obesity prevention, and 2) biological resilience to obesogenic social determinants of health. The gut microbiome plays an influential role in the intersection of stress and childhood obesity and is directly influenced by environmental factors such as outdoor time. Thus, we propose a prospective longitudinal natural experiment to examine the effect of a novel outdoor preschool model on gut microbiome characteristics, physiological stress, and the association with obesity in early childhood.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it uses a randomized clinical trial to experimentally test for perinatal biological embedding of a supportive perinatal intervention in the context of adversity. The results will contribute toward the development of non-invasive, proximal DNA methylation indicators of perinatal interventions’ effects on offspring. Thus, the proposed research aligns with the part of NICHD’s mission that seeks to ensure that all children have the chance to fulfill their potential to live healthy and productive lives free from disease or disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Long-range projections of neuronal types underlie the structure of neuronal circuits and constrain computations, but these relationship between projections and neuronal types remain largely unclear. We will unravel the relationship between gene expression and projections in the mouse corticothalamic circuit by combining state-of-the-art high-throughput in situ sequencing-based neuroanatomical techniques and robust meta-analysis. We will build a comprehensive spatiotemporal map of the corticothalamic projections in the context of neuronal gene expression and link our data with rich external reference single-cell RNAseq data to extract gene-projection relationship with unprecedented details.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project, a new class of biological reporters will be developed and deployed to identify key bottlenecks in the translation of CAR chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy, an emerging therapeutic approach to cancer treatment. This work will reveal new avenues to improve the overall general performance and durability of CAR T cells, by enabling researchers to easily view the history of calcium signaling in these cells. The imaging probes leverage state-of-the-art bioluminescent and fluorescent proteins, which naturally emit and transform light, to build probes that non-invasively record biochemical activities in living cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While the Affordable Care Act (ACA) improved commercial insurance access for vulnerable patients – i.e., financially fragile individuals, those living in socioeconomically disadvantaged neighborhoods, or of minority race – little is known about the clinical and financial experiences of vulnerable commercially insured cancer patients in the post-ACA era. In this study, we will leverage a unique data asset that combines cancer registry, commercial insurance enrollment and claims, credit reports, and bankruptcy records to characterize out of pocket cost exposure and its relationship to disparities in care and adverse clinical and financial outcomes among commercially insured cancer patients following implementation of the ACA reforms, with particular emphasis on medically and financially vulnerable patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on understanding disease course and treatment outcomes in Hispanic patients with inflammatory bowel diseases, an understudied population with high disease burden. By simultaneously examining biological and multi-dimensional social and structural determinants of health in Hispanic patients with IBD and their contribution to adverse disease and treatment outcomes, we will directly inform management of these health disparity population. The proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to enhancing health, reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE We previously reported that the viability of some breast cancers depends on histone deacetylase 6 (HDAC6). In this grant proposal, our ultimate goal is to define the clinical space for HDAC6 inhibitors in breast cancers (aim 1) and understand the molecular mechanism that mediates the anticancer activity of HDAC6i/s to use this information to improve HDAC6-based breast cancer regimens. We will pursue these objectives by Investigating the mechanisms of resistance to HDAC6i/s (aim 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This mobile health (mHealth) pilot study will develop an intervention to maintain reductions in evening sedentary screen time (eSST) over 12 months using a novel habit formation strategy among a nationally-recruited sample of adults at-risk for type 2 diabetes. Our intervention combines theory- and evidence-based approaches for addressing individual barriers to habit formation, which is a critical component of behavior change maintenance. This (ORBIT Model) Phase II pilot study will provide new insights into the relationships between maintained reductions in eSST and metabolic health, an mHealth solution for reducing eSST that can be scaled through the use of several commercially available screen time monitoring tools, and the necessary information to scale-up the StandUPTV application into a Phase III, fully powered randomized clinical trial to test the impact of reducing eSST on diabetes and cardiovascular disease risk in a national sample.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) pulmonary disease is an increasingly common orphan disease that causes progressive disability in older adults. Diagnosis is challenging and often delayed, and there is a tremendous unmet therapeutic need. We seek to define immunologic and transcriptomic signatures of MAC pulmonary disease that could ultimately be used to improve diagnosis, clinical management, and design of clinical trials of new and repurposed therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastasis is the main cause of cancer mortality, yet the development of treatments directly inhibiting metastasis is still an unmet clinical need. This project aims to identify chemotherapeutic drugs using engineered biomimetic tumor invasion models and to evaluate therapeutic feasibility of inhibiting the target genes involved in breast cancer dissemination to suppress cancer invasion. This study has implications for the preclinical screening of anti-cancer drugs, for characterizing subtypes of breast cancers, and will increase our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of breast cancer invasiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our ability to detect and discriminate quiet sounds depends on a mechanical amplification process that is mediated by the cochlea’s sensory cells. The goal of this project is to determine whether these cells can amplify responses to high-frequency sounds by rapidly changing length and generating force, or if alternative mechanisms are involved, such as slow or sustained changes in cell length that modulate how the surrounding structures vibrate. The knowledge gained will clarify how healthy ears work and what is missing in impaired ears, and will inform future efforts to rehabilitate and restore hearing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Stress is one of the most commonly reported precipitants of tobacco craving and relapse. Tobacco withdrawal is associated with escalation of negative affect symptoms; our research has found multiple stress-related physiological and hormonal alterations during withdrawal that predict relapse. Modifying these stress-related biobehavioral changes may prove useful in reducing effects of stress, especially during withdrawal. By establishing how acute doses of cannabidiol modify responses to stress and by examining moderating effects of cannabidiol on stress response during nicotine withdrawal, this study will provide novel results that could set the stage for subsequent studies to examine how cannabidiol how CBD impacts both stress response and tobacco addiction. Addressing stress-related increases in craving, withdrawal, and relapse would aid tobacco cessation efforts and reduce relapse rates contributing to reducing tobacco’s devastating health effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Vascular calcification (VC) occurring in chronic kidney disease is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. Calciprotein particles (CPPs) and extracellular vesicles play a major role in driving VC. This study aims to investigate the use of a new peptide to block the CPP mediated VC in chronic renal disease and end stage renal disease (dialysis). Also, this work will test a new potential therapeutic, reveal new drug targets and provide a new understanding of the regulation of the role of calciprotein particles in vascular calcification.

PHR: NARRATIVE Metabolic labeling with heavy water followed by LC-MS is used to study the turnover of individual proteins in vivo. Protein turnover is a fundamental biological process that is dysregulated in many diseases. This work will result in novel computational tools that increase proteome coverage and statistical power of protein turnover estimations and will help to reduce the dose, sampling frequency, and duration of labeling.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are >200,000 patients living with severe motor disability as a result of tetraplegia or severe tetrapereisis resulting from multiple neurological disorders. Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs) can reduce the extent of disability by allowing direct neural control of assistive devices. Our proposal aims to test whether a BCI using electrocorticography can allow such patients to control a complex robotic arm to perform a range of clinically relevant dexterous tasks.

Novel biophysical assays will be pioneered to investigate how tactile sensing induces the formation of biofilms and other forms of communities. PHR: Liver transplantation is the only curative option for patients with liver cirrhosis and there are no regenerative therapies available, although they are urgently needed. We identified a novel growth factor that induces proliferation of hepatocytes suggesting it improves liver regeneration. As this there are known and FDA-approved compounds to enhance or inhibit this pathway, we propose to assess if these compounds can be used to improve liver regeneration, which could eventually improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The tumor microenvironment of pancreatic adenocarcinomas endows these tumors with profound resistance to chemotherapies, which severely hinders clinical management of this disease. We have found that nutrient availability in pancreatic tumors is a key microenvironmental factor that leads to this therapy resistance. In this proposal, we will determine the molecular mechanisms by which tumor nutrition imparts therapy resistance upon pancreatic cancer cells, and if manipulating tumor nutrition and its impact on pancreatic cancer cells can sensitize pancreatic tumors to chemotherapies, which may lead to new therapeutic approaches in this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Delirium is an acute and dynamic disturbance of attention and awareness that afflicts >20% of hospitalized older adults and costs up to $152 billion each year, yet has no FDA approved therapies. This project will use new monitoring tools to determine the temporal characteristics, sleep and circadian causes, and long-term cognitive impact of the acute course of delirium in older adults. Such tools will establish a firm physiologic foundation, objective biomarkers, and critical targets to identify, understand, and ameliorate delirium’s significant and distressing effects, including its associations with long-term cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will develop a new approach to monitor and predict treatment response in patients with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma using hyperpolarized 13C pyruvate MR molecular imaging. The data from this first study will inform future investigations incorporating metabolic imaging biomarkers for defining clinically relevant thresholds, enable timely therapy switch in non-responders, and guide high-stake decisions about the benefit of a highly morbid surgery, with the overarching goal of better guiding treatment decisions to improve survival of patients with this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Oxidative stress is an established risk factor for alcohol-related organ injury. In this project, we will examine the influence of superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), an antioxidant enzyme, on the activities of two proteins (AMP-activated protein kinase and catalase), which are known to alter liver and fat tissue injury. Further, we will evaluate the effectiveness of a novel SOD1 nanoparticle, in reducing alcohol-induced organ injury.

PHR: One of the major challenges of gene therapy is the lack of technologies to deliver healthy-gene copies to target tissues/cells. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 1$55$7,9( Published estimates indicate that 1 in 44 children are diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) (https://www.cdc.gov/), and while many genetic causes of ASD and related neurodevelopmental disorders have now been identified, our understanding of how disruption of genes drives nervous system dysfunction in these disorders remains limited. This project will study how mutation of genes associated with ASD and related disorders impacts a specialized DNA methylation pathway in the brain, leading to alterations in neuronal gene expression and disrupted circuit function. This work will define fundamental biology that is essential to the normal function of the nervous system and explore how it may be disrupted in disease, laying the groundwork for future therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a prevalent and impairing mental health condition, and symptoms of diminished positive affect (e.g., difficulty experiencing positive emotions, diminished interest) are consistently associated with poorer quality of life and worse clinical outcomes. Cognitive processing therapy (CPT) is an evidence-based trauma-focused psychotherapy with abundant evidence of clinical efficacy, but the neurobiological mechanisms by which trauma-focused psychotherapies, such as CPT, promote improvements in symptoms of diminished positive affect are not at all understood. The long-term public health goal of this project is to identify how CPT promotes changes in the function and information processing of neural circuitry involved in positive affect using reward processing paradigms and brain imaging, which will serve to inform our understanding of existing efficacious trauma-focused treatments and provide new opportunities for improving PTSD treatment outcomes through targeting the neural mechanisms underlying this poorly understood symptom cluster.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 20% of all children have tics at some time in their life, making tic disorders like Tourette syndrome a subject of substantial public health interest. Our colleagues enrolled over 300 children, beginning at ages 3-5, without selecting for presence or absence of tics, and have followed them up for 15 years at study visits that included video recordings of the child in addition to diagnostic interviews, a wealth of psychological data, and for later visits structural and functional MRI of the brain. This unique data set allows us to identify clinical features prior to the onset of tics in children who show tics on video at later visits, and to identify clinical or brain imaging predictors of tic outcome at visits when children first manifest tics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: While new medication classes promise to transform diabetes care and reduce diabetes complications, there remains limited evidence of their effects in Veterans with type 2 diabetes. This is largely because Veterans are not well-represented in randomized clinical trials, and Veterans often differ from clinical trial participants across many clinical and demographic characteristics, exacerbating the challenge of generalizing trial results to Veterans. Recent advances in biostatistical methods offer tools for bridging this evidence gap between clinical trials and real-world patient populations. We propose to apply these methods, called transportability methods, to several recent clinical trials in type 2 diabetes to generate valid VA-specific evidence of the efficacy of contemporary diabetes treatments in Veterans. We will then use this real-world evidence in Veterans to project short-term impacts - the potential number of diabetes complications prevented, budget impact for the VA, and cost-effectiveness of different treatment strategies - that may inform VA diabetes treatment guidelines.

STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Special Emphasis Panel[ZRD1 ENDA-L (01)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Ultrasound is among the world’s most widely used biomedical imaging technologies, but plays a relatively small role in molecular and cellular imaging due to a lack of contrast agents connected to specific aspects of cellular function such as gene expression and intracellular signaling. To address this limitation, we are developing acoustic biomolecules – proteins that can be imaged with ultrasound and serve as targeted nanoscale contrast agents and genetically encoded acoustic reporter genes. In this project, we will advance the engineering of these unique proteins and related ultrasound methods and apply them to imaging tumors and tumor-infiltrating immune cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) analysis is an important methodology and cornerstone of medical imaging because it is the main tool for evaluating diagnostic performance of radiologists, medical devices, and new technologies in binary medical decision-making tasks (e.g., diagnosis of a patient as having a cancer vs. not). This proposal, which we call weighted ROC (WROC) analysis, innovates on basic ROC theory and practical applications alike by introducing a new case-weight factor, which will add flexibility to ROC analysis, improve clinical performance inference from laboratory studies, produce new ways to design better studies, and spawn new future research. WROC analysis will help make ROC analysis more general, broadly applicable, practical, accurate, precise, efficient, and user-friendly, and will enable it to make greater impact on evaluation and optimization of medical technologies and medical decision-making.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE High levels of circulating androgens can negatively affect neuroendocrine reproductive hormone levels in females, yet the mechanisms and target cells by which androgens achieve these effects remain unknown. Indeed, hyperandrogenemia from exogenous androgens is a fundamental aspect of reproductive disruptions seen in transgender men (genetic females) and other clinical conditions, but little is known about how such disruptions are incurred. This proposal will utilize cutting edge molecular, genetic, and physiological techniques coupled with experiments in both genetic mouse models and human transgender subjects to delineate the specific cell targets and physiological mechanisms by which androgens can impact normal female reproductive hormone secretion and will improve understanding of androgen inhibition of neuroendocrine reproductive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Accurate diagnosis is crucial for successful medical intervention in infectious diseases, but can be challenging due to shared symptoms among different infections and the rising prevalence of drug resistance. There remains a need to rapidly identify causative pathogens and choose appropriate treatments quickly given that prognosis can depend on the turnaround time between sample collection and diagnosis. In this competing renewal, we aim to build upon technology developed in our previous R01 to enable rapid, sensitive, and information-rich diagnosis of infectious diseases from clinical samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ciliated cells provide essential host defense through the clearance of inhaled contaminants out of the lungs by the directional movement of cilia. Abnormal cilia and ciliated cell loss precipitate and exacerbate chronic inflammatory airway diseases like cystic fibrosis, asthma and COPD. Here we study a Wnt cell signaling mechanism that ensures the generation of the correct number of functional ciliated cells with the aim of identifying novel therapeutic approaches to target ciliary dysfunction in chronic airway disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging evidence implicates previously unknown glomerular endothelial lipid dysfunction as an important pathological process in the development of Alport syndrome. In this proposal we will investigate the role of lipid metabolism in the development of glomerular endothelial dysfunction and will use extracellular vesicles as a tool to re-establish functional homeostasis. Better understanding of the role of glomerular endothelium in the development of Alport pathology will facilitate the discovery of strategies to more effectively target the kidney for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Migraine affects more than one in ten people in the US, yet we still do not understand basic features of this disease, like how a migraine attack starts. This proposal will study the origins of the migraine attack by focusing on the initiation of spreading depolarization (SD), the physiological correlate of the migraine aura, which in turn is the first measurable event in in a migraine attack. We will use a combination of imaging, electrophysiology, and genetic manipulation to examine the cerebral cortex at cellular resolution during the initiation of SD, hopefully generating novel insight into how an attack of migraine begins, and thus critical information on how to stop it.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Anand, Kanwaljeet Singh Preschool children exposed to adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) and/or early life adversity (ELA) are likely to have worse physical and mental health across their lifespan, whereas positive childhood experiences (PCEs) can build resilience and prevent these outcomes. We plan to assess the interactions of ACEs, PCEs, parenting, and poverty on the social psychology of childhood and develop objective measures for stress dysregulation using hair cortisol as a chronic stress biomarker. These studies will address fundamental gaps in our current knowledge and establish a scientific framework to investigate the long-term effects of early childhood adversity, physical or emotional trauma, child maltreatment, or other adverse experiences in early childhood, as well as the preventive and protective effects of loving, nurturing, and consistent caregiving to children during their early childhood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arthritic pain often persists after the resolution of inflammation, yielding a chronic state in which the sensory neuron displays increases in at least four sodium channels and a decrease in at least one potassium channel, yielding a polyneuropathy. To advance our thinking that management of this early inflammation and late polyneuropathy pain state is optimized by addressing changes in not only one channel but several, we will use spinal delivery of the CRISPR-dCas9 platform to epigenetically regulate these channels, a strategy with clear implication for safely managing the chronic pain in the arthritic patient.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Myeloid malignancies are common among veterans, in whom there were over 2000 cases of myelodysplastic syndrome alone between 1996-2005. This incidence is only increasing as the median age of all veterans is ~65 years, and Vietnam veterans, the largest cohort of VA patients, reach their 70s, when myeloid malignancies peak in incidence. Myeloid malignancies find their origin in acquired mutations in hematopoietic stem cells. This project will first dissect the clonal and phenotypic identities of mutated stem and progenitor cells within the common myeloid malignancies of myelodysplastic syndrome and acute myeloid leukemia at single cell resolution. It will then determine how intracellular signals differ across clones to characterize the nongenetic causes of clonal dominance. Using cutting edge single cell techniques with computational analysis, we will link various multiomic datasets to establish a new framework for clonal discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and related motor neuron diseases affect more than 30,000 people in the United States, and 90% of ALS patients die within 5 years of diagnosis. It is well known that there is a strong genetic component to these degenerative diseases, yet many of the genetic causes remain poorly defined. The proposed studies will investigate the genetic functions of a gene ZNF106 newly understood to be involved in human ALS-like neurodegeneration to determine how ZNF106 mutations cause motor neuron degeneration.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related eye disorders affect more than half of the elderly population, compromising their ability to perform daily activities. In this proposal, we will determine conserved genes that influence eye degeneration through their effects on diet, aging, and circadian clocks in the eye. These studies will provide insights into therapeutic targets to slow age-related decline in visual function and their detrimental effects on peripheral tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Even though most heart attack patients have underlying heart disease, not all patients with heart disease have a heart attack. This observation suggests that some of the biological mechanisms that establish and promote heart disease are different from those that cause a heart attack. By integrating various experimental approaches, this project will discover and validate novel genes that specifically increase risk of heart attack in heart disease patients but not heart disease itself.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The repair of programmed DNA breaks by homologous recombination is essential for meiosis, the cellular process that produces sperm and eggs. This proposal addresses a critical gap in our understanding of meiotic recombination in mammals, the role of the breast cancer associated protein, BRCA2, which loads the central recombination enzyme RAD51 onto the ends of DNA breaks. Defects in BRCA2-mediated recombination are associated with infertility, pregnancy loss, congenital disease and ovarian insufficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative We will develop a high-resolution adaptive optics fluorescence lifetime imaging ophthalmoscope (AOFLIO) and use this instrument to characterize the fluorescence lifetime of fluorophores within individual cells or specific layers in the retina and its supporting retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) in the living human eye. Our study will provide precise localization of retinal and RPE metabolic function at the cellular level in normal human eyes with normal aging and age-related macular degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Infants born more than 3 months prematurely are at high risk for lung disease that often persists through childhood, manifests as wheezing or abnormalities in lung or heart function, and may represent subtypes of disease that cannot be discerned in the early neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) course. Genetics may play a role in contributing to these subtypes, but studies have been inconclusive because of the imprecise definition of lung disease in the NICU and insufficient numbers of participants. We are assembling almost 2000 former premature infants who were enrolled in studies in the NICU, who have genetic data available, and who are now enrolled in studies at school-age to: 1) use gene pathways to define these subtypes of lung disease; 2) predict longer-term cardiorespiratory outcomes early in the NICU course; and 3) understand the genetic mechanisms that determine these outcomes so that we might treat or prevent these lung diseases early on.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Chronic pain, that is, pain that persists or recurs for 3 months or more, affects 20 % of adults in the United States and contributes to an annual economic cost of greater than $600 billion and is more prevalent among Veterans compared to non-Veterans with significantly higher rates of chronic pain in women veterans. Using noninvasive techniques to change the function of brain areas that are involved in chronic pain is one approach to developing treatments for chronic pain conditions. A small area of the brain called the insula is activated in chronic pain conditions. This study tests a new noninvasive technique called low intensity focused ultrasound (LIFU) as a way to inhibit the insula and determine whether this causes individuals with chronic pain to have a reduced response to painful stimuli and whether activity in the insula is decreased after LIFU. Results from this study could provide important information on how brain function changes with chronic pain disorders and may lead to improved treatments for chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Viral persistence due to low antiretroviral (ARV) penetration in secondary lymphoid tissues (SLTs) and poor adherence to daily ARV regimen remain major barriers to achieving a functional cure for HIV. We want to develop “stealth” long-acting lipid polymeric nanoparticles (GM3-PLA-NPs) that can potentially increase ARV entry and retention in SLTs by forming cellular drug depots in CD169+ macrophages. Our proposed studies will investigate the stealth and biodistribution mechanisms of GM3-PLA-NPs to elucidate new strategies for targeted delivery of safe long-acting drugs in the SLTs and hence aid in the development of nanotherapeutics for prevention and treatment of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE    Although immunotherapy has had remarkable successes in the treatment of cancer, it only benefits a minority of  cancer patients, and we do not know how to rationally combine immunotherapy with other treatments. Advances  have been difficult in part because we do not have animal models that respond well to immunotherapy. The goal  of  this  project  is  to  develop  better  mouse  cancer  models  that  harbor  both  the  driver  and  passenger  mutations  seen in human cancers, and use this to understand mechanisms of response and resistance to immunotherapy  and rationally design more effective combination immunotherapy strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Narrative We recently identified a novel mitochondrial signaling axis centered on MnSOD-K68 which, when its normal acetylation status is altered, disrupts cellular metabolism, leading to aberrant ROS levels (Zhu et al, 2019). This data has been extended to show that LNCaP-MnSODK68Q cells exhibit increased HIF2α, shown to promote a stemness-like phenotype, and two stem cell biomarkers, SOX2, and Oct4, consistent with stemness properties. Thus, is the disruption of cell metabolism surrounding MnSOD-K68-Ac a potential mechanism for radiation resistance as well as enzalutamide resistance and potential molecular target for novel therapies?

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Exercise is an evidence-based intervention for the management of chronic conditions, yet the majority of US adults, including Veterans, are inactive. Telehealth is critically important for providing care to Veterans because it increases access and flexibility. Group telehealth exercise programs combine the benefits of group exercise sessions, such as social support, and telehealth technology. Exercise programs designed to address the different skills needed for exercise initiation and exercise maintenance are critical to ensure sustained exercise participation. This project addresses the high prevalence of inactivity among Veterans. Creation of a group telehealth exercise program that can be widely disseminated and implemented will not only meet physical activity guidelines but will also improve the health and quality of life for Veterans by reducing the burden of health conditions improved with participation in exercise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that has a long “preclinical” stage in which pathological processes have begun but overt cognitive impairment is absent. Understanding mechanisms of initial neuronal changes and corresponding effects on memory abilities is critical for distinguishing between normal and pathological aging, and to improve risk prediction models that can be applied during the preclinical stage of AD. By combining cognitive neuroscience approaches with biofluid/PET quantification of disease, our research program will make significant contributions towards understanding early disease and cognitive aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Genomically unstable cancers such as breast and ovarian cancers are hard to treat due to their ongoing accumulation of copy number aberrations (CNAs) which leads to intratumoral heterogeneity. New single-cell whole genome sequencing (scWGS) methods such as direct library preparation (DLP) can profile CNAs at single-cell resolution, providing new insights on mutational processes and clonal competition within tumors. While previous scWGS analysis has focused on non-replicating cells, this proposal aims to use the S-phase cells captured in DLP libraries to predict clonal proliferation rates and determine the role of aberrant DNA replication across cancers of varying mutational processes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is the primary cause of non-cancer morbidity and mortality among cancer survivors; however, standard of care strategies to prevent cardiovascular disease do not exist. We propose to evaluate the effects of aerobic exercise therapy (AT) program length and volume on cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) response rate and other pertinent outcomes in EBC. Results from this investigation will identify the AT regimen that maximizes CRF response rate and other clinically relevant endpoints in EBC, and ultimately will inform policy, evidence-based guidelines, and standard clinical care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health as it is expected to identify novel epigenetic predictors and targets of stress-associated coronary heart disease (CHD), thereby opening new horizons towards personalized interventions that can beneficially modulate the epigenome of individuals experiencing high stress levels and CHD risk. These expected contributions are relevant to NHLBI’s mission as they have the potential to enhance prevention and treatment of CHD, which is the single leading cause of death in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project proposes brain positron emission tomography (PET) with [11C]ER176, a novel radiotracer for translocator protein (TSPO), a biomarker of glial activation, [11C]WAY-100635, a selective, high-affinity agonist for serotonin 1A receptors, and near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) to measure mitochondrial function in brain of unmedicated major depression compared with healthy volunteers. This cross-sectional study looks simultaneously at relationships between neuroinflammation, serotonin and mitochondrial function, with respect to presence of illness and severity of major depression. Results are relevant to the mission of the NIH as they have potential to unify major theories of depression pathophysiology, and findings may guide new treatment approaches that can be individualized.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: This project will provide important information on the function of pial collaterals, small anastomotic arterioles in the brain that maintain perfusion to the penumbra and provide a level of salvageable tissue during large vessel occlusion (LVO). We will investigate clinically relevant strategies to enhance collateral perfusion during LVO to sustain the penumbra and improve long-term outcome from LVO. These treatments are particularly relevant for patients with co-morbidities and poor collateral flow in which current endovascular therapy or thrombolysis is delayed or inaccessible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose an early stage pilot randomized controlled trial of a non-pharmacological intervention that was co- designed with non-Hispanic black (NHB) safety-net primary care patients and their providers. The intervention is delivered by safety-net providers and involves hypertension self-management education, Mediterranean- Dash Intervention for Neurodegenerative Delay (MIND) diet, and aerobic training. We will evaluate intervention feasibility and processes and investigate intervention effects on cognition in NHB adults with hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lifetime prevalence of alcohol use disorders (AUDs) is ~30% in the U.S. population, and is significantly higher in some subpopulations including those with chronic pain. While the analgesic and anesthetic properties of alcohol are well known, as is the fact that alcohol withdrawal causes hyperalgesic states that can drive negative reinforcement driven alcohol consumption in some patients. We will determine the mechanisms by which endogenous cannabinoids regulate withdrawal-associated hyperalgesia and examine therapeutic potential of endocannabinoid modulation for alcohol-pain co-morbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cigarette smoking prevalence is highest among American Indian and Alaska Native (ANAI) people in Alaska, which results in persistence of many health disparities. The goal of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a culturally-adapted, ANAI family-based incentives intervention for smoking cessation. The study will also explore the potential for adoption and sustainability of the intervention within the Alaska Tribal Health System.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Despite the immense health burden of chronic kidney disease, effective treatment options remain limited. A distinct proximal tubule subpopulation may drive chronic kidney disease progression, so a better understanding of the formation of this subpopulation may lead to clinical breakthroughs. This project aims to identify regulatory elements mediating proximal tubule state transitions that may be therapeutically targetable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Genome editing technologies provide novel opportunities to advance basic research and treat human diseases but approaches that use active nucleases to edit DNA can induce undesired and deleterious effects in the genome, which can reduce their therapeutic potential. Prime editors are a recently emerged gene-editing variant capable of introducing precise modifications to DNA, with minimal damage to the genome. This proposal is focused on creating an integrative prime editing toolkit that will provide investigators with technologies that will enable their use in vivo, improve their specificity and streamline their design and implementation, thereby advancing the applications of this methodology in biotechnology and biomedicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE Alcohol misuse imposes a staggering burden on public health and the global economy. While the root causes of alcohol misuse are complex and heterogeneous, there is ample evidence that many individuals use alcohol to dampen excess anxiety (‘self-medicate’). This study will harness an innovative combination of computational, brain imaging, and smartphone technologies to understand the chain of neurobiological and psychological factors that govern anxiety-fueled alcohol misuse, paving the way for developing more precise and effective treatment strategies for this debilitating illness.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Individuals with lower extremity amputation are often challenged by complications that arise from poor prosthetic fit, including movement of the residual limb in the socket, known as pistoning. Pistoning can lead to gait instability, skin problems, and pain. Different prosthetic suspension systems have been developed to decrease this motion, including elevated vacuum suspension, which utilizes a pump to draw air from the socket. However, scientific analyses to understand the movement between the limb and socket in elevated vacuum systems have yet to be performed with a high level of accuracy. This study will use a state-of-the art imaging technique, known as dynamic stereo x-ray, to quantify the 3D movement of the residual limb in the socket. This information is critical for advancing prosthetic treatments to reduce secondary conditions and degenerative changes that result from poor prosthetic fit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Degenerative rotator cuff injury is one of the leading causes of decreased functional capability of the upper body and increasing evidence suggests that intrinsic tendinous changes, such as those consistent with diabetes and obesity, promote development of degenerative tears. Although diabetes and obesity are among the most common, and rapidly increasing, chronic conditions, their impact on musculoskeletal health is largely understudied. This work directly contributes to understanding whether observed links between diabetes, obesity and degenerative tears of the cuff are merely associational, or causal; and such knowledge can guide strategies in prevention and management of this debilitating condition.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The term "Overlap Syndrome" (OS) is used to describe the presence of both chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in a single patient. Veterans with OS who also have excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) are at highest risk for functional decline yet have the greatest barriers to exercise training. Thus, there is a critical need to identify novel exercise strategies that meet the individual needs and capacities of Veterans with EDS-OS. We propose to test moderate intensity interval training (MIIT), a novel exercise intervention whose translation into durable lifestyle change may be facilitated by the feasibility of short bouts of increased PA. Our proposal addresses key knowledge gaps in rehabilitation research by investigating the clinical phenotype of EDS-OS to determine the association with functional outcomes and response to a novel exercise intervention with the goal to reduce functional decline. Results will inform a larger exercise trial and Merit application that will facilitate my career goal to be an independent scientist in exercise rehabilitation in OS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project investigates the role of the early life gut microbiota in the development of enteric neurons within the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, which form the physiological basis for GI motility. Motility disorders such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) are chronic, costly conditions for which neither cause nor cure is currently known. Through the proposed studies, we expect to gain insights into the fundamental significance of environmental disturbances during development, and the relevance of such disturbances for GI health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Vagal nerve stimulation may hold the key to treating many different conditions, including obesity. Obesity is a growing epidemic in our country. Obese veterans are at risk for hypertension, diabetes, and depression. Stimulating the vagal nerves, which innervate the stomach, with small, therapeutic levels of electricity provides a potential avenue for weight loss, but is not well understood. Successful reduction of excess body weight has been reported, but stimulus parameters are quite variable and it is unclear how parameters map to outcomes. A new, promising method of stimulation has been shown to produce natural sensations when applied to peripheral nerves and the spinal cord and has reduced consumption of high fat diet. This research aims to map the relationship between stimulus parameters and 1) nerve recruitment, 2) brain activity, and 3) food consumption. This research will also evaluate a novel stimulus waveform and interface for delivering more effective vagal nerve stimulation. Studies will be conducted in rats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: The rich information content of advanced imaging methods, combined with the growing capacity to collect multiple types of images from various sources and time points during therapy creates an exciting opportunity for image-based guidance and assessment of interventions for radiation oncology, surgery, and interventional radiology. However, several obstacles prevent the full exploitation of this paradigm including understanding and validating the imaging signals to enable high precision treatment, engaging advanced imaging techniques to assess the patient’s response to treatment, and empowering multi-disciplinary teams of physicians and scientists to address these clinical challenges and technology barriers to enable the translation of innovative science directly to patient care. This post-doctoral training program will provide the multi-disciplinary education needed for tomorrow’s pioneering researchers to advance the field of image guided cancer therapy.
PI_NAMEs: BROCK, KRISTY  (contact);FULLER, CLIFTON DAVID;LAI, STEPHEN Y

PROJECT_TITLE: Image Guided Cancer Therapy Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neonatal hypoxic-ischemic brain injury is the leading cause of neonatal seizures, for which treatment is both ineffective and potentially harmful. The immediate goals of this proposal are to develop two-photon imaging methods for in vivo real-time seizure and cell death monitoring and to define the relationship between neuronal seizure burden and the probability of cell death in a neonatal murine model of hypoxic-ischemic brain injury. The experiments proposed will generate rigorous correlational data between seizure burden and the probability of neuronal death with the necessary temporal and spatial resolution to make possible future studies of causation, which are essential to determine how aggressively to treat patients and how to prioritize future research efforts to develop improved neonatal seizure treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The crucible of evolution has naturally shaped traits over the entire history of life and understanding the genetic basis of this adaptive process has broad applications. Comparatively diverse species, such as the Mexican cavefish Astyanax mexicanus, that have evolved physiological phenotypes and mimic some aspects of human diseases but intriguingly they do not exhibit the same underlying pathophysiological consequences require further study. We propose to build a toolbox of molecular resources for Astyanax mexicanus to significantly advance trait dissection in this amazing model of genetic adaptation.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are a vulnerable group for developing insomnia, with about 37% having comorbid insomnia. Pulmonary rehabilitation is a key component of COPD management, yet it does not address sleep. Comorbid insomnia may interfere with veterans achieving maximum benefits from pulmonary rehabilitation. Implementing an insomnia-specific treatment in veterans with COPD undergoing pulmonary rehabilitation will likely lead to improved sleep that could help improve and sustain the benefits gained from pulmonary rehabilitation. We propose a randomized clinical trial to compare the effects of Internet- based cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia plus home-based pulmonary rehabilitation versus home-based pulmonary rehabilitation only on sleep and health-related functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (three sentences) Many human cancers are caused by mutations or dysfunction of genes for chromatin regulators, which regulate the accessibility of the human genome to DNA repair, replication and expression. To date effective therapeutics have not been devised for these cancers, in part because of a lack of understanding of how they normally function. We will explore the molecular mechanisms that underly the cancers produced by these chromatin regulators with the hope of providing new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is a class I carcinogen and the major cause of cancer in untreated AIDS patients. During KSHV infection there is a dramatic reprogramming of cellular gene expression driven by the virus and this contributes to disease progression. This grant investigates the role of transposable elements in remodeling cellular gene expression during KSHV infection and how this contributes to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over a million patients admitted annually to skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) for post-acute care after a hospitalization have Alzheimer’s Disease or Related Dementias (ADRD), and their outcomes are poor and variable. The current study will examine whether physicians that specialize in SNF-based care (SNFists) improve functional outcomes and reduce healthcare utilization of patients with ADRD receiving care in SNFs. We will also qualitatively evaluate how physician practices differ between high- vs. low-performing SNFs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project Narrative: The conventional clinical management strategy for patients with chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) is to initiate therapy at the time of disease progression and clonal evolution. In this project, we will determine whether inflammatory insults can drive a specific evolutionary adaption known as the `mono-biased' state and disease progression. Importantly, we will determine if this inflammation dependent effect can be mitigated by existing therapeutics and cytokine inhibitors leading to a paradigm shift in CMML management whereby these therapies can be deployed in a clinically asymptomatic state to prevent disease progression.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The drug supply chain is global and susceptible to disruptive unanticipated events, such as the 2019 Corona- virus (COVID-19) pandemic, but the impact of drug shortages during a global public health emergency and the impact on Veteran drug supply and health outcomes are unknown. The proposed research is relevant to Veteran health because policy-makers need real world evidence to plan for future global emergencies, drug shortages at large, and inform VA policy to decrease the impact of drug shortages on Veteran outcomes. Thus, this project is relevant to the priority areas of HSR&D, VA operations, and other federal initiatives to provide timely response to critical questions, ensure the availability of safe and effective drugs to our Vet- erans, measure drug shortages and their impact on patient safety, improve resiliency of the drug supply chain, and achieve health equity, especially in VA priority groups.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Every year about 15,000 Veterans are hospitalized for stroke (Cowper 2004), and one-third of those patients develop stroke-related language disorders (aphasia) (Brady 2012). The first few months of post-stroke recovery is a critical time period where spontaneous changes in language functions and underlying neural processes are observed. Imaging brain changes during this time may help clinicians identify the recovery of neural processes, but must be done in a way that is not confounded by stroke-induced cerebrovascular changes. This CDA2 proposal addresses this gap through development of a set of integrated multi-modal neuroimaging methodologies to accurately identify neural systems associated with language recovery from early sub-acute (2- 6 weeks post-stroke) to late sub-acute phase (12-16 weeks post-stroke) of aphasia recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Deficiencies in mechanosensation contribute to functional gastrointestinal diseases (FGIDs) like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), which collectively affect around 15% of US adults, but mechanosensation has not been directly targeted for treatment because of poor mechanistic understanding of how physical forces influence GI function. Our lab discovered mechanosensitive enteroendocrine cells (EECs) in the GI epithelium that release physiologically active hormones in response to force, so in this proposal we seek to uncover the mechanism by which mechanosensitive proteins work together to make EECs efficient force sensors. Acquiring this knowledge may advance our understanding of mechanosensation in sensory epithelia, and pinpoint targets for the treatment of FGIDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: As biomechanical modeling of the breast is integral to predicting tumor location across multimodal diagnostic imaging and during surgery, surgical planning, generating simulations for physician and patient education, and brassiere and clothing design for optimal breast support, advances in model accuracy have the potential to significantly improve women's health and quality of life. Despite the growing use of breast biomechanical models for different applications, there are persistent knowledge gaps in both the anatomical and biomechanical literature that prevent an accurate model from being developed and deployed to patient-specific applications. This research aims to improve the accuracy of the biomechanical model by determining the anatomical and biomechanical characteristics of the fascial support system of the breast, understanding the sensitivity of the patient-specific parameters across the population, and validating the translation of these models, with their inherent uncertainties, into the patient-specific setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is one of the leading causes of liver disease in the US; however, much remains to be discovered regarding the genetic factors that contribute to its development. The proposed research will demonstrate that genetic variation in SUGP1 contributes to cellular lipid accumulation and NAFLD in animal models, as well as establish patient-derived induced pluripotent stem cells, a novel cellular model for the discovery and functionalization of NAFLD gene variants. Together, these results will enhance our understanding of the genetic contributors to NAFLD, which may lead to precision medicine advancements in NAFLD screening and treatment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulation of transcription dictates cells’ fates, functions, and potential in development and disease. Promoter- proximal RNA Polymerase II Pausing has been shown to be a critical rate-limiting step of transcription that can control transcription’s outcome and response to extracellular signals in certain scenarios. This study aims to understand the mechanisms of Pausing influence on gene regulation and signal response in early mammalian development in vivo and in vitro, which will give insights into how this process may affect cellular response to extracellular signals and open the door to manipulating this process for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The WHO estimates that in 2020, malaria caused 241M clinical episodes and 627,000 deaths. This was a significant increase compared to 2019. While Plasmodium falciparum (Pf) accounts for much of the severe disease and most of the deaths, P. vivax (Pv) represents the most widespread and numerous malaria parasite with a range stretching even into temperate zones. Pv comprise the greatest proportion of infections and cases in some parts of the world; for example, in the Americas 68.3% (446,000) of 653,000 cases were attributable to Pv malaria in 2019. Evidence is accumulating to show that young children and pregnant women are particularly vulnerable to adverse clinical impacts of Pv malaria, including severe presentations, and preventing infections and relapse in these groups is a priority. Pv is responsible for at least 30% of malaria in U.S. travelers [5]. Efforts to prevent and control Pv malaria are impeded by emergence of drug resistant strains and by repeated relapses from dormant liver stage parasites called hypnozoites. A powerful tool is needed for eliminating Pf and Pv malaria from defined geographical areas, ideally a highly effective, long-acting yet low-cost vaccine that prevents infection, disease and parasite transmission. This proposal describes the development, characterization and assessments of a Plasmodium falciparum sporozoite (PfSPZ) vaccine that is late arresting replication competent (LARC) and has 2 genes Pfmei2 and PfLINUP deleted (PfSPZ-LARC2) and in addition a major immunogenic Pv protein the circumsporozoite protein (CSP). We describe the development of a Pf LARC parasite strain that expresses the P. vivax circumsporozoite protein (PvCSP). This parasite strain called PfLARC2-PvCSP is genetically attenuated to arrest development in the late liver stage, and will provide the basis for a bi-valent LARC PfSPZ Vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT)  In this project, we will continue our investigation of two families of Staphylococcus aureus proteins that act as potent inhibitors of key enzyme systems required for an effective innate immune response. The first family of inhibitors, called EAP proteins, targets a series of immune proteases found within human neutrophils, as well as the classical and lectin complement pathways, while the second inhibitor, called SPIN, blocks the myeloperoxidase of neutrophils that generates cytotoxic hypohalous acids from hydrogen peroxide. Completion of this project may reveal new approaches to preventing and/or treating staphylococcal disease, provide new insight into development of anti-inflammatory therapeutics, and further our understanding of the physical phenomena underlying the host species specificity of infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The knowledge gathered from this project is of significant public health relevance as it has potential to advance treatment for youth at clinical high risk for psychosis (CHR) by evaluating the utility of Group and Family-Based Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for youth at CHR and examining whether adding group and family modalities may be more effective in improving psychosocial functioning compared to individual CBT. We will use telehealth delivery to address challenges that youth at CHR may have accessing treatment, including transportation to local clinics, stigma, stress sensitivity, suspiciousness, and emerging negative symptoms. Telehealth adaptations have the potential to make interventions accessible to a larger number of youth and families, to connect them to social support networks of others with similar experiences across geographically disparate locations, to alleviate their suffering, to reduce psychiatric disability, and to decrease economic losses to society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low-income women experience several psychosocial stressors during pregnancy (e.g., poverty, discrimination) that place them at disproportionately higher risk of experiencing prenatal health complications and adverse birth outcomes that can lead to significant long- term health problems for mothers and their infants. This project will address this critical public health problem by providing new insight to the risk factors associated with the intergenerational transmission of stress outcomes from mothers to their children, particularly among low-income families experiencing chronic stressors related to socioeconomic adversity, family instability, and discrimination. This study will extend previous research on fetal programming by prospectively examining the effects of prenatal maternal and fetal cortisol levels, genetic factors (i.e., 5-HTTLPR genotype), and exposure to chronic stressors on changes in infant telomere length (a biological measure of disease risk) over time to identify potential avenues for prevention and treatment, as well as optimize health outcomes for mothers, their children, and subsequent generations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Viral and bacterial infection has emerged as an urgent threat to our aged population, including Veterans. Aging affects us all and brings increased risk of morbidity and mortality, depleting quality of life, and elevating susceptibility to viral pathogens. Recent evidence indicates that damaged, senescent (dying) cells drive aging and age-related morbidity, and adverse outcomes upon acute exposure to pathogens. In this application, we will test the hypothesis that clearing senescent cells from aged, obese and brain compromised (dying brain cells) mice using senolytic drugs (to remove dying cells) protects against morbidity and mortality upon exposure to community acquired viral pathogens. This study will be a proof of concept to use senolytic drugs such as fisetin to prevent and treat viral infection induced complications in patients who are aged, have obesity and/or are suffering from neurodegenerative disorders such as Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is aimed at improving rates of arteriovenous fistula (AVF) maturation and long-term patency for patients with end-stage renal disease requiring hemodialysis. This study supports our long term-goal of understanding the mechanism in the pathogenesis of non-maturing AVFs and develop absorbable, imaging-capable medical devices that could modulate neointimal hyperplasia. Furthermore, development of an imaging technique based on combined ultrasound/photoacoustic (US/PA) and positron emission tomography (PET) imaging will assist with AVF monitoring and lead to an improved understanding of AVF maturation/non-maturation with potential for the development of novel therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because average years of life lost to pediatric sarcomas has remained unacceptably low and unchanged over the last three decades, with less than 30% overall survival in those with relapsed disease. Immunotherapy offers a potential alternative or synergistic approach to chemotherapy; at the conclusion of this study, we will understand if manipulating immune inhibitory signals in the tumor microenvironment using immune check point inhibition safely augments the clinical efficacy of chimeric antigen receptor T cells, and we will prospectively identify factors that improve patient selection and guide interventions. These findings will contribute to opening research avenues into both the feasibility and biology of combination immunotherapy approaches, akin to the historical emergence of multi-drug chemotherapy regimens to improve cancer outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Integrating HIV treatment and prevention into family planning clinics offers a promising approach to reach reproductive aged women, including the priority population of adolescent girls and young women, who may be otherwise missed in a siloed healthcare system. This study will provide necessary information regarding SAIA’s reach, effectiveness, adoption, implementation and maintenance in the real world setting when implemented at scale by Kenyan public health staff to increase HIV counseling, HIV testing, linkage to HIV care, and screening and linkage to PrEP as well as SAIA’s effect on the County budget. SAIA has the potential to dramatically improve women’s sexual and reproductive health by improving HIV prevention and treatment services for women in Kenyan family planning clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Digital health technologies have high potential to promote between-session skill utilization and acquisition when used as a treatment augmentation to outpatient CBT for bulimia nervosa and binge eating disorder, yet little is known about which specific technological components may be needed to enhance skill utilization and acquisition and improve treatment outcomes. The proposed study will use a Multiphasic Optimization Strategy approach, including a full factorial design, in which 264 individuals with transdiagnostic binge eating pathology are assigned to one of six treatment conditions, i.e., representing each permutation of two promising digital health technological components that may enhance skill utilization and acquisition (e.g. self-monitoring complexity (Skills-Monitoring On vs. Skills-Monitoring Off) and micro-intervention complexity (No Micro- Interventions vs. Automated Reminder Messages vs. Just-in-Time Adaptive Interventions)) when used as an augmentation to outpatient CBT. Results of the component analysis set up future work to evaluate an optimized digital health tool containing only effective components (which can be expected to have superior target engagement, efficacy, efficiency and disseminability) and will identify key moderators of treatment outcome to facilitate treatment matching.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE African American adults sleep less and obtain worse quality sleep compared to the national average, and emerging evidence links inadequate sleep with morbidity and mortality from chronic diseases such as diabetes, obesity, and cancer. To address this public health concern, the proposed research seeks to understand social contextual factors related to sleep and obesity by using a multi-method approach, and to use the knowledge gained to adapt a sleep intervention for overweight, sedentary, and chronically sleep-deprived African Ameri- can adults. The goal of the project is to understand how the social context impacts sleep and obesity to reduce cancer-related health disparities among African Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulation of vascular barrier function, the selectively permeable barrier established by endothelial cells that line blood vessels to regulate the exchange of fluids, cells, and nutrients, contributes to a variety of cardiovascular, inflammatory, and neurodegenerative diseases. Despite a critical clinical demand, we lack interventional strategies to repair or modulate vascular barrier, largely due to a poor understanding of the master regulators within the vascular endothelium. This proposal aims to reveal new mechanisms of how the Notch1 receptor activates under shear stress, increasing barrier function, and potentially identify new therapeutic targets for modulating barrier function and other vasculopathies where Notch1 is implicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Craniofacial microsomia is one of the most common birth defects that affects the face. We have identified a gene, Foxi3, that can cause craniofacial microsomia in both humans and mice. We will use mouse genetics to test the contributions of Foxi3 to craniofacial microsomia, and we will create models of human Foxi3 mutations in mice to understand the signals that are disrupted during fetal development in individuals with these birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma continues to be one of most deadly malignant diseases due to the tumor’s highly immunosuppressive nature. In this proposal we seek to engineer dual-target binding antibodies that can preferentially bind pancreatic cancer cells and inhibit immunosuppressive molecules within the tumor, while also better engaging immune cells to eliminate the pancreatic cancer cells. If successful, our work may introduce a promising therapeutic strategy for improved treatment of pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Ionizing radiation (IR) therapy for head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) frequently results in salivary gland dysfunction and xerotomia that leads to mucositis, dental caries, malnutrition and overall decreased quality of life. The primary goals of this study are to determine whether and how inhibition of the P2X7 receptor (P2X7R) can protect the salivary gland from IR-induced dysfunction without having a deleterious effect on IR therapy for HNSCC. Results of these studies will be a major step towards validating a P2X7R-targeted therapy for preventing IR-induced salivary gland damage in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although pregnant persons are at higher risk of severe COVID-19 infection, there is currently limited data to inform COVID-19 immunization policies for this population group. Drawing from national, linked health information for over 870,000 mother-infant pairs, this research will provide large-scale evidence on the uptake, safety and effectiveness of maternal COVID-19 vaccination in terms of perinatal, neonatal and infant health outcomes. Completion of this research will facilitate informed decision-making among pregnant persons, those planning pregnancy and their healthcare providers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Neural tube defects are the second most common birth defect leading to fetal mortality or life-long complications. The risk for developing a neural tube defect can be reduced by increasing folic acid in the diet of pregnant people in some cases, however we cannot predict who this preventative strategy is most beneficial for. The objective of this proposal is to provide insight into how folic acid can support neural tube closure to better inform risk assessment of neural tube defects.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Excess deaths have occurred during the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, most commonly due to heart disease and particularly among vulnerable populations, raising the possibility of suboptimal healthcare utilization or quality of care. Accordingly, we propose an observational, retrospective, national cohort study of Veterans with cardiovascular disease. We will compare potential decreases in cardiovascular healthcare utilization and quality of care and an increase in mortality to that which occurred prior to the pandemic with a focus on vulnerable populations. We will then assess whether the changes in healthcare utilization and quality of care were associated with an increased risk of mortality. A stakeholder advisory panel led by VA operational leaders, investigators, and Veterans, will then be convened to develop recommendations and guide VA policies in the late- and/or post-pandemic period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), caused by excess accumulation of fat in the liver (steatosis), has a global prevalence of 25.2% and is the most common cause of chronic liver disease worldwide. The objective of this application is to identify additional rare variants with effects on NAFLD through whole genome sequencing (WGS) in ethnically diverse populations. In addition, CRISPR/Cas9 will be used to test genes for loss of function effects on hepatic steatosis. Results from our work will help us to understand the genetic architecture of NAFLD and link these associations to genes that can be targeted for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The goal of U-RISE at UMBC is to develop a diverse pool of undergraduates, prioritizing underrepresented races and ethnicities, students with disabilities, and students from disadvantaged backgrounds, who complete their baccalaureate degree, and transition into and complete biomedical, research-focused, higher-degree programs (e.g., Ph.D. or M.D./Ph.D.), and pursue biomedical research careers. Increasing diverse perspectives within the biomedical research workforce will maximize potential for complex scientific problem-solving. The program will provide a combination of activities to ensure: (i) excellence in academic science, (ii) adapting to the intensity of contemporary scientific research, (iii) student interest in pursuing a Ph.D. degree and subsequent career in biomedical research, (iv) selection of graduate school and successful completed applications, and (v) a value placed on student mental health and wellness amongst the rigor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project concerns spatial integration of light by a ganglion cell photoreceptor that connects the eye to the brain and senses light to drive the often-subconscious effects of light on physiology and behavior. The proposed experiments will define how phototransduction is integrated across the photoreceptor cell’s subcellular compartments and how spatial integration emerges at the population level, providing insights that are likely to generalize to other types of sensory neurons. The knowledge gained in this project will be important for developing therapeutics that compensate for disruptions in light’s regulation of critical functions like circadian rhythms, mood, and sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative of Public Health Relevance V-ATPases are present in all cells and help control pH in specific sub-compartments, degrade defective proteins, and respond to environmental stresses. Their dysfunction is associated with diseases like Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, and osteoporosis. V-ATPases are involved in many functions, and it is hard to target subpopulations of V-ATPases therapeutically. We are characterizing regulators of V-ATPases in specific locations. Targeting these regulators might make it possible to treat diseases associated with aberrant V-ATPase activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT  The abysmal survival rate of patients with advanced colon cancer is attributable to resistance to chemotherapies that have been designed to efficiently stop proliferation and initiate apoptosis in cancer cells, but fail to appreciate the pro-chemoresistance signals emanating from cells surrounding the tumor. Proposed studies will explore the impact of enteric glial cells, which form a dense network infiltrating colon adenocarcinomas, and yet have been understudied in colon carcinogenesis, and in particular colon cancer resistance to chemotherapies. Therefore, the outcomes of this project will not only improve our understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms driving colon cancer chemoresistance but may also demonstrate the therapeutic potential of developing strategies combining targeted therapies against enteric glial cell-derived chemoprotective ligands and traditional chemotherapy regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Comorbidity in anxiety disorders is common, exerts tremendous personal and societal costs, is difficult to treat and is associated with increased negative emotionality. Little is known about the neural mechanisms that promote anxiety comorbidity and negative emotionality. The current project focuses on a neural profile that corresponds to increased comorbidity load across the anxiety disorders and could lead to better ways to diagnose and treat the most burdened anxiety patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative: Ventricular tachyarrhythmias are responsible for 300,000 sudden cardiac deaths a year in the US. In addition, the ever-increasing prevalence of obesity also poses a significant burden on the health care system with increased morbidity and mortality associated with fatal ventricular arrhythmias. In this project, we will a multi-modal and multi-scale approach to characterize how obesity induces ventricular arrhythmias in donor human hearts and use that knowledge to potentially develop new markers to predict and treat ventricular arrhythmias in a clinical setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Heroin withdrawal is characterized by aversive physical and emotional states which can lead to recurrent drug seeking and relapse. The goal of the proposed studies is to gain insight into the contribution of paraventricular thalamic circuits in opioid withdrawal syndrome and heroin seeking, such that novel therapeutic strategies can be identified for the treatment of opioid addiction.
